header.emu_comment: Internet Archive Final Burn Alpha 2012 CPS2 romset listing by Zach Morris. This set is for use with the Retroarch core FBA 2012 CPS2 (v0.2.97.29 / MAME v0.149). This list is the full list of compatible roms available for this set.[CR]Final Burn Alpha is a Multiple Arcade Emulator most popular for emulating Neo-Geo, Capcom, Konami, and Cave games. It is developed by the final burn team and originated from FinalBurn by Dave.

game.name: 1944: The Loop Master (Japan 000620)
game.plot: 1944 - The Loop Master (c) 2000 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]Warbirds Fly Again![CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Main CPU: Motorola 68000 (@ 11.8MHz).[CR]Sound CPU: Zilog Z80 (@ 8MHz).[CR]Sound Chips: Q-Sound (@ 4MHz).[CR]Screen Orientation: Horizontal.[CR]Screen Resolution: 384x224[CR]Refresh Rate: 59.629403Hz[CR]Palette Colours: 4096[CR]Controls: 8-way joystick (per player)[CR]Buttons: 2 (per player)[CR]= > [A] Shot/Charging, [B] Bomb[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]1944 - The Loop Master was released on June 20, 2000 in Japan. It was known as the 33th CPS-2 game.[CR]Known export release: [CR][US] "1944 - The Loop Master [Blue Board]" [CR]Like many other large companies as-of-late, Capcom has started farming out the programing of their games to third party companies. In this case, 1944 was made by 'Eighting / Raizing' and published by Capcom.[CR]The game forbids the initials 'SEX' on the high score table. If you try, it gets changed to 'CAP'.[CR]Default High-score table 'Score ranking' :[CR](Rank - Name - Score - Stage - Destroy rate)[CR]1st CAP 1000000pts. 3st1 90%[CR]2nd COM 900000pts. 3st1 85%[CR]3rd CAP 800000pts. 3st1 80%[CR]4th COM 700000pts. 2st1 75%[CR]5th CAP 600000pts. 2st1 70%[CR]6th COM 500000pts. 2st1 65%[CR]7th CAP 400000pts. 1st1 60%[CR]8th COM 300000pts. 1st1 55%[CR]9th CAP 200000pts. 1st1 50%[CR]10th COM 100000pts. 1st1 45%[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* The game features 15 stages & bosses:[CR]Stage 01: The Deep Blue - Boss: High Speed Destroyer 'Nagi'[CR]Stage 02: Iron Beast Warcry - Boss: New type heavy tank 'Shouto'[CR]Stage 03: Jungle Fight - Boss: Prototype Attacker 'Akane'[CR]Stage 04: The Rock Fortress - Boss: Cruising Tank 'Noroshi'[CR]Stage 05: Eagle Territory - Boss: Intercontinental Bomber 'Kyuoh'[CR]Stage 06: Devil Mountain - Boss: Special Attacker 'Haruka'[CR]Stage 07: Nightmare Valley - Boss: Anti-Submarine Battle Cruiser 'Kai'[CR]Stage 08: Fields Of War - Boss: Multi-Cannon Tank 'Ishizue'[CR]Stage 09: Muddy Interceptor - Boss: Middle Class Bomber 'Akatsuki'[CR]Stage 10: Storm Fortress - Boss: Super Gigantic Battleship 'Kaijin'[CR]Stage 11: Oil Legion - Boss: Anti-Aircraft Battleship 'Yu'[CR]Stage 12: Leviathan's Mouth - Boss: Twin-Bodied Transporter 'Take'[CR]Stage 13: Battle Of Green Field - Boss: Gigantic Fighter 'Arashi'[CR]Stage 14: The Last Duel - Boss: Railed Tank 'Goku'[CR]Stage 15: Bell Of Triumph - Boss: Moving Fortress 'Appare Toride'[CR]After destroying Stage 15 boss, the game ends if stage layout is set to 1 loop, or the game continues with stage 1 with enemy firing faster bullets, if the stage layout is set to endless.[CR]* Hold FIRE to charge guns. When it is fully charged release FIRE. The plane will be INVINCIBLE for a short period of time and fire powerful low range projectiles. Then the guns will overheat preventing you from charging them for a short time.[CR]* The mini fighters that appear beside your plane are destroyed after taking two hits. Destroyed side fighters are replaced if you have more in stock. During charge attacking or when there is no bomb, pushing BOMB makes side fighters charge forward for a powerful suicide attack.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. 1942 (1984) [CR]2. 1943 - Midway Kaisen (1987) [CR]3. 1943 Kai - Midway Kaisen (1988) [CR]4. 1941 - Counter Attack [B-Board 89625B-1] (1990) [CR]5. 19XX - The War Against Destiny [Green Board] (1995) [CR]6. 1944 - The Loop Master [Green Board] (2000)[CR]7. 1942 - Joint Strike (2008, PSN/XBLA)[CR]

game.name: 19XX: The War Against Destiny (Japan 960104, yellow case)
game.description: 19XX: The War Against Destiny (Japan 960104, yellow case)
game.plot: 19XX - The War Against Destiny (c) 1996 Capcom.[CR]A vertical shoot'em up game.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: 2[CR]Control: 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons: 2[CR]=> [A] Fire, [B] Bomb[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]19XX The War Against Destiny was released on December 7, 1995 in Japan. It was known as the 13th CPS-II game. [CR]The game forbids the initials 'SEX' on the high score table. If you try, it gets changed to 'SYS'. [CR]Known export releases: [CR]"19XX - The War Against Destiny [Blue Board]" [CR]"19XX - The War Against Destiny [Grey Board]" [CR]"19XX - The War Against Destiny [Orange Board]" [CR]"19XX - The War Against Destiny [Pink Board]" [CR]Soundtrack album releases: [CR]Capcom Game Sound Track -19XX The War Against Destiny- (VICL-2168) [Victor Entertainment] [CR]Victor Entertainment released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Capcom Game Soundtrack : 19XX The War Against Destiny - VICL-2168) on April 3, 1996. Here is the official name of the songs : [CR]Mission 1 - A Bit of Blue Sky Between the Clouds [CR]Mission 2 - The Red Naval Port [CR]Mission 3 - Dance of the Green Gnome [CR]Mission 4 - Silver Ice Sheet [CR]Mission 5 - City Lights in the Black Strait [CR]Final Mission P1 - Grayish Tornado [CR]Final Mission P2 - The Last-Ditch Fight[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Green Board releases : [CR]Revision 1: [CR]* Build Date: 951207 [CR]Revision 2: [CR]* Build Date: 951225[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Change First Stage Music To "1942" BGM : at the title screen after the coin is inserted move Up, Right(x9), Down(x4), left(x2). A sound will be heard once the code is entered.[CR]* Change First Stage Music To An Arranged Version of "1942" BGM : at the title screen after the coin is inserted move Up, Down(x9), Upleft, Downright, Upright, Downleft, Upleft, Downright, Upright, Downleft. A voice will be heard once the code is entered.[CR]* Stronger Bombs : holding the BOMB button will charge your bomb to a stronger level.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. 1942 (1984) [CR]2. 1943 - Midway Kaisen (1987) [CR]3. 1943 Kai - Midway Kaisen (1988) [CR]4. 1941 - Counter Attack [B-Board 89625B-1] (1990) [CR]5. 19XX - The War Against Destiny [Green Board] (1995) [CR]6. 1944 - The Loop Master [Green Board] (2000)[CR]7. 1942 - Joint Strike (2008, PSN/XBLA)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Game designers : I. Satsuma, Tomonori Nonaka, S. Obata (Manhattan)[CR]Program designers : T. Ueno, Batayoni, Hdo, Dress, Ittetsu, You!, Hits[CR]Scroll designers : Taka, Fukumoyan, Ziggy, Imahori, Hiroshi Sugiyama, Kazu, Goro Suzuki, Sawatch[CR]Object designers : Y. Maruno, Misupo Rumu, Yoshino Hiroaki, Mimura Kenji 8, Naoki Fukuda, Yuki, Henoheno, Bow, T. Osumi, GZ, K. Tokunaga, You-Ten Nakano, Takep, Eizi Murabayashi, Kogaman[CR]Music composers : Syun Nishigaki (Kobekko), Tatsuro Zuzuki[CR]Sound designers : Hiroaki Kondo (Mach-2)[CR]All sound produce by Arcade Sound Team.[CR]

game.name: Alien vs. Predator (Japan 940520)
game.plot: Alien vs. Predator (c) 1994 Capcom Company, Limited. [CR]Two Space Marines and two Predators go after hordes of H.R. Giger's most fearsome creations! Each character has special projectile weapons in addition to the standard super moves.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 3.[CR]Control: 8-Way Joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 3 per player.[CR]=> [1] Attack, [2] Jump, [3] Weapon Attack[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Alien vs. Predator was released on May 20, 1994 in Japan. It was known as the 4th CPS-II game.[CR]Known export releases:[CR]"Alien vs. Predator [Blue Board]"[CR]"Alien vs. Predator [Grey Board]"[CR]"Alien vs. Predator [Orange Board]"[CR]This game is based on the Dark Horse comics: Aliens vs. Predator (1989-1990) (5 comics). Also, it combines enemies from the two Twentieth Century Fox films entitled Alien and Predator. This is the first title to ever combine elements from two separate, non-related films into a single game.[CR]Lieutenant Linn Kurosawa made a cameo appearance in the background of Ken's stage in "Street Fighter Alpha 2".[CR]Chad Johnson holds the record for this game with 3074408 points.[CR]Comics published after the release of the game :[CR]Aliens vs. Predator - Booty (1996) (1 comic)[CR]Aliens vs. Predator - Eternal (1999) (4 comics)[CR]Aliens vs. Predator - Xenogenesis (1999) (4 comics)[CR]Aliens vs. Predator - Thrill of the Hunt (2004) (1 comic)[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Here are the 4 available characters and their statistics...[CR]Predator Warrior : Speed 6 - Power 4 - Skill 5[CR]Major D. Schaefer : Speed 2 - Power 8 - Skill 4[CR]Lieutenant Linn Kurosawa : Speed 5 - Power 1 - Skill 8[CR]Predator Hunter : Speed 6 - Power 5 - Skill 4[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Planners : Kame, Garuda Tetsu, Uda. T[CR]Programmers : Cham Cho Choy, Arikichi Kiyoko, Pon, Hard. Yas, Shinchan[CR]Character Designers : Hayashi, Yus, Shisui, Vlad T, Ban, Kawatori, Shige, Jun 26[CR]Artist : Iwai, Hiroki Ohnishi, Konishi. H, Norisaki Chie, Fukunoyan, Kisa, Angus[CR]Music Composer : Hideki Okugawa (Hideki Ok)[CR]Sound Designer : Toshio Kajino[CR]Capcom USA Supporters : David Winstead, Alex Jimenez (Alex Jimerez)[CR]Special Thanks : Noritaka Funamizu (Poo), Akira Yasuda (Akiman), Tom[CR]

game.name: Battle Circuit (Japan 970319)
game.plot: Battle Circuit (c) 1997 Capcom.[CR]In this side-scrolling beat'em up, 5 wacky colour-coded characters fight to arrest 'Dr. Saturn' and stop the 'Shiva System' from taking over the world! Earn money to buy special moves and power-ups. This game has 7 stages...[CR]* Stage 1: Inside enemy ship.[CR]* Stage 2: Fever in disco, den of evil.[CR]* Stage 3: Dead heat in desert.[CR]* Stage 4: Sneak in and foil Dr. Saturn's plans.[CR]* Stage 5: Jungle Battle, escape from death line.[CR]* Stage 6: Chase Zipang as you go down river.[CR]* Final Stage : Showdown, desperate battle with Shiva system.[CR]* Secret : Last battle, stop Master Program.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 4.[CR]Control: 8-way joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 2 per player.[CR]=> [1] Attack, [2] Jump[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Battle Circuit was released in March 1997. It was known as the 21th CPS-II game.[CR]Known export releases:[CR]"Battle Circuit [Blue Board]"[CR]"Battle Circuit [Grey Board]"[CR]Some of the game's characters seem to borrow moves & stuff from other Capcom games :[CR]* Cyber Blue : His battle armor seems VERY inspired by the one used by "Captain Commando", also his Cyber Cannon is reminiscent of Iron Man's Proton Cannon in "Marvel Super Heroes".[CR]* Captain Silver : One of his special attacks is clearly based on Iceman's Artic Attack in "X-Men - Children of the Atom".[CR]* Yellow Iris : Her Speed Up power attack is based on Psylocke's Gem Ability in "Marvel Super Heroes" in which she summons copies of herself that attack enemies.[CR]* Pink Ostrich : She borrows LOTS of moves from Zelkin Fiskerkogen, the bird alien from "Star Gladiator - Episode : I Final Crusade". Also her anklet is quite reminiscent of the spiky bracelets that Chun-li wears in the Street Fighter games.[CR]* Alien Green : His jump & slam throw is clearly based on Haggar's Pile Driver in "Final Fight".[CR]Johnny (the second boss) is based on Elvis Presley. When you defeat him, he becomes fat.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]Pink Ostrich and Alien Green are very hard to clear stage 2 & 3. So if you can put only one credit in the machine, play with another character.[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Planner : Burns Fuji, Dave Matumoto, Ryozo Tsujimoto, Satoshi. M[CR]Program Designers : Tomohiro Ueno, Batayon, HDO, Dress[CR]Character Graphics : Nakamu, Pinopu, Ino, Kimo Kimo (Hana Kimo Komo), Shinya Kitamura, M. Nakatani, Yorio, Dekao, Dai, Tomohiko Ohsumi, Takep, Michiru[CR]Title Designer : Shoei[CR]Arts : Hiroki Ohnishi, Yamamoto Kouji, Nakamura Takako, Hirokazu Yonezuka, Nissui Asae, Nukeo, Hiro, Tokio. game.name: Janpai Puzzle Choukou (Japan 010820)
game.plot: Jong Pai Puzzle Choko (c) 2001 Mitchell Corp.[CR]An adult shanghai game from Mitchell. The objective is to clear the board of matching tiles before the timer runs out.[CR]Each level consists a board with two or more columns of tiles and walls slowly moving toward the center of the board. Every time a matching pair of tiles is cleared from the board the two columns momentarily shift away from the center. The game is lost if the opposing columns of tiles run into each other or into the wall. In order to legally remove matching tiles no walls or other tiles can be in a path with two or fewer bends between the matching tiles. Once per stage, the player can request help and the two columns will shift to their starting positions and matching tiles will be highlighted for a short time. If the player cannot legally remove any more tiles then the board is 'deadlocked', and the game is lost.[CR]If the player clears the board before the timer runs out, the background girl will change into a more revealing state of undress and this new image of her will be the background for the next stage. If the timer reaches zero the player can still attempt to clear the board but the background image will not change. The game features four girls with two background images each and a topless image that is revealed after defeating the girl's second stage within the time limit. [CR]If the game is lost, upon continuing the player may select to attempt to clear the same board or try a new board of tiles.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Board: Green (Japan)[CR]Players: Up yo 2.[CR]Control: 8-way Joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 6 per player.[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Jong Pai Puzzle Choko was released in August 2001 in Japan only. It was known as the 37th game released for the CPS-II hardware.[CR]The title translates from Japanese as 'Yangtze River Mahjong Tile Puzzle'. The kanji 'Choko' is the Japanese name of the Chinese Yangtze River.[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Concept Designer : Akihiro Akaishi[CR]Planner : Futoshi Kuwahara, Satoru Tsujita[CR]Programmer : Kaname Wada, Shigeru Komiya[CR]Graphic Designer Object : Eiko Kato, Kazue Matsunaga, TTO[CR]Graphic Designer Scroll : Satoshi Ida, Sachiko Shibuya, Hiroshi Katayama[CR]Sound BGM Composer : Takafumi Wada, Takashi Kouga, Tomoyuki Takano[CR]Sound SE Designer : Shin Yamazaki[CR]Executive Producer : Roy Ozaki, Koichi Niida[CR]

game.name: Capcom Sports Club (Japan 970722)
game.plot: Capcom Sports Club (c) 1997 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]Capcom Sports Club is a multi-event sports game for one or two players who can choose to play any one of three different sports games: Tennis (Smash Stars), Football (Kick Stars) and Basketball (Dunk Stars).[CR]The game's look and feel is typical of Capcom's output of the time and is skewed heavily towards fast, cartoon-like arcade action.[CR]Of the three games on offer, "Smash Stars" Tennis is by far the most accomplished and would easily stand up as an arcade machine in its own right.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 2.[CR]Control: 8-way joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 3 per player.[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Capcom Sports Club was released in July 1997 in Japan. It was known as the 24th CPS-II game.[CR]Known export release:[CR]"Capcom Sports Club [Blue Board]"[CR]"Capcom Sports Club [Grey Board]"[CR]"Capcom Sports Club [Orange Board]"[CR]In the Smash Stars tennis game, the Chinese tennis player bares more than a passing resemblance to one of Capcom's most famous characters, 'Street Fighter's Chun Li, here known as 'Li-li'.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Select New Teams/Player : After 1997 credits have been entered into the machine, the title page changes by adding a girl with a dog on the left side of the screen. This also unlocks 3 new teams (one for each game) as follows...[CR]Dunk Stars - Golden USA[CR]Smash Stars - Melody Love[CR]Kick Stars - All Stars[CR]* Play against secret teams : To play against the secret teams (Smash Stars - Melody, Kick Stars - Star Team and Dunk Stars - Golden USA) you must reach 200.000 points before winning the finals.[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Planner : Yoshifumi Fukuda[CR]Programmers : Yoshinobu Inada, Masahito Oh!Ya! (as 'Masahito Ohya'), Kazuhiko Komori[CR]CG-Works : Eiji Kuratani, Naoki Fujisawa, Naoki Fukushima, Shinya Kitamura[CR]Object Designers : Shinji Sakashita, Kazuo Yorikane, Koichi Kikutani, Masao Ueda, Motohiro Shigeyama, Tsunenori Shirahama, Tomohiko Ohsumi, Tadashi Noyama[CR]Scroll designers : Kazumi Teramoto, Maeno Megumi, Hirokazu Yoneduka, Chie Nakayama, Yoichi Tanoue, Atsushi Kanno[CR]Sound : Hideki Okugawa, Ryoji Yamamoto[CR]Designers : Daigo Ikeno, Masae Okano, Satoshi Ukai, Shinchiro Komizu[CR]Voice Actors : Tomoyuki Morikawa, Jin Yamanoi, Miyuki Yamamoto (Arts Vision)[CR]Producer : Yoshimi Ohnishi[CR]General Producer : Noritaka Funamizu[CR]Supervisor : Yoshiki Okamoto[CR]

game.name: Cyberbots: Fullmetal Madness (Euro 950424)
game.plot: Cyberbots - Fullmetal Madness (c) 1995 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]North American & European release. Game developed in Japan. For more information about the game itself, please see the original Japanese release entry; "Cyberbots - Fullmetal Madness [Green Board]".[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Blue Board [USA & Europe][CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]In the original Japanese version's Vs. screen, a chapter title is displayed as well as the model number of each players' VA. The titles and model numbers are missing from these Export versions.[CR]After a 1P vs 2P match in the original Japanese version, the winning character speaks his (or her) victory quote and it is written on screen as well. In the export versions, the victory quote is just written on screen (without the voice sample).[CR]There is a POWEREDGEAR HIGHSCORE CAMPAIGN sequence after the staff credits missing on the export versions.[CR]Devilotte's servants, Dr. Shutain and Jigoku Daishi, are renamed Xavier and Gary.[CR]Gawaine's sword is called 'Magnablade' in the Japanese version. It is not referred to by name in the Export versions.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]The USA version has the Winners Don't Use Drugs screen.[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR](Non-Japanese ports only)[CR]* Consoles :[CR]Sony PlayStation [US] (September 13, 2011, "PSOne Classics")[CR]

game.name: Cyberbots: Fullmetal Madness (Japan 950420)
game.plot: Cyberbots - Fullmetal Madness (c) 1995 Capcom.[CR]A mecha-based fighting game featuring six selectable pilots and twelve selectable mechs with intertwining storylines.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 2.[CR]Control: 8-way joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 4 per player.[CR]=> [1] Attack 1, [2] Attack 2, [3] Weapon, [4] Boost[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Cyberbots was released in April 1995 in Japan. It was known as the 10th CPS-II game.[CR]All of the mechs in this game appeared originally in "Armored Warriors".[CR]Devilot (on the S-008 Super-8) appear as a secret character in "Super Puzzle Fighter 2 Turbo" and as a striker character in "Marvel vs. Capcom - Clash of Super Heroes".[CR]Jin also appears as a selectable fighter in "Marvel vs. Capcom - Clash of Super Heroes", accompanied by the Blodia mech.[CR]Sony Music Entertainment released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Cyberbots Arcade Game Track - SRCL-3274, 3275) on August 2, 1995.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Play As S-008 Super-8 : After you choose your V.A. before the Vs screen do the following quickly Up, Right, Down, Left, Up, Right, Attack 1, Up, Left, Down, Right, Attack 2.[CR]* Play As P-10033 gaits : After you choose your V.A. before the Vs screen do the following quickly Attack 1, Attack 2, Boost, Weapon, Attack 1, Boost.[CR]* Play As UVA-02 Helion : After you choose your V.A. before the Vs screen do the following quickly Up, Up, Down, Down, Left, Right, Boost, Weapon.[CR]* Play As X-0 Warlock : After you choose your V.A. before the Vs screen do the following quickly Left, Attack 1, Up, Attack 2, Right, Boost, Down, Weapon.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Armored Warriors [CP-S II No. 07] (1994)[CR]2. Cyberbots - Fullmetal Madness [CP-S II No. 10] (1995)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Game Designers : Shochan, Tobanjan, Tequila Saddy, Jun Keiba, Haruo Murata (Mucchi), Tatsuya Nakae (Daichan), 12BW1B[CR]Programmers : Kid, Stefano Komorini with T, Shaver, Hiroshi Nakagawa, Dress, Garamon, Mr. Kato[CR]Object Designers : Atta Kutta, Eiji, Naoki Fujisawa, Vanira, Yutaka Maruno, Yoshino, K. Tokunaga, You-Tenkozow, Urabe Yakkyoku 8, Naoki Fukuda, H. Shibaki, Hiroshi Shibata, Shisui, Yorio, Takep, Gappa, Eizi Murabayashi, Heno Heno, Yuki[CR]Scroll Designers : Fukumoyan, Nissui, Kisabon, Iwai, Go, May, Hiroko N., Kichinosuke, Kazu, Akiko O., Saru, Kuwatch, Sm, Tabu, Mago, Mr. Holland[CR]Sound Designers : Tomuyuki Kawakami (T.K NY), Takeshi Kitamura (Moe. T)[CR]Sound Composers : Takayuki Iwai (Anarchy Takapon), Akari Kaida (Akari. K -Lemon-), Masato Koda (Kda Mto), Naoaki Iwami (Super 8 Iwami)[CR]Producer : Iyono Pon[CR]* CAST :[CR]Jin Saotome : Furuya Tooru[CR]Mary Miyabi : Takano Urara[CR]Santana Laurence : Yanada Kiyoyuki[CR]Gawaine Murdock : Genda Tesshou[CR]Bao : Kappei Yamaguchi[CR]Mao : Araki Kae[CR]Arieta : Kanai Mika[CR]Hagane Tessan : Ginga Banjou[CR]Kagura Chiyomaru : Ryo Horikawa[CR]Shade : Shozo Iizuka[CR]Dr. Shutain (Xaiver in the US version) : Ginga Banjou[CR]Jigoku Daishi (Gary in the US version) : Yanami Jouji[CR]Princess Devilotte Do Deathsatan IX : Kozakura Etsuko[CR]Special Thanks : Noritaka Funamizu (Poo)[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR](Japanese ports only)[CR]* Consoles :[CR]Sega Saturn [JP] (March 28, 1997) "Cyberbots - Fullmetal Madness [Limited Edition] [Model T-1216G]"[CR]Sega Saturn [JP] (March 28, 1997) "Cyberbots - Fullmetal Madness [Model T-1217G]"[CR]Sony PlayStation [JP] (December 25, 1997) "Cyberbots - Fullmetal Madness [Model SLPS-01011]"[CR]Sony PlayStation [JP] (February 9, 2011, "PSOne Classics")[CR]

game.name: Dungeons & Dragons: Shadow over Mystara (Japan 960619)
game.plot: Dungeons & Dragons - Shadow Over Mystara (c) 1996 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]Based on the famous RPG system Dungeons & Dragons. Six characters straight out of the Dungeons and Dragons Player's Manual take up arms in order to rid the kingdom of the evil sorceress Synn and her droves of annoying little Kobolds.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 4.[CR]Control: 8-way joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 4 per player.[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Dungeons & Dragons - Shadow Over Mystara was released in February 1996 in Japan. It was known as the 14th CPS-II game.[CR]Known Export releases:[CR]"Dungeons & Dragons - Shadow Over Mystara [Blue Board]"[CR]"Dungeons & Dragons - Shadow Over Mystara [Grey Board]"[CR]"Dungeons & Dragons - Shadow Over Mystara [Orange Board]"[CR]"Dungeons & Dragons - Shadow Over Mystara [Pink Board]"[CR]The game forbids the initials 'SEX' on the name selection screen. If you try, it gets changed to (depending of the character you choose) : [CR]Fighter: 'CRASSUS'[CR]Cleric: 'GRELDON'[CR]Elf: 'LUCIA'[CR]Magic user: 'SYOUS'[CR]Victor Entertainment released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Dungeons & Dragons - Shadow Over Mystara - VICL-2169) on May 22, 1996.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Green Board revisions : [CR]REVISION 1 :[CR]* Build date: 960206[CR]REVISION 2 :[CR]* Build date: 960619[CR]* Name Bug corrected (see 'Tips And Tricks' section for more info).[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Bug : very beneficial trick in some cases but leads to lockups. Choose a character with a 6-character name (Blue Dwarf and possibly 2 others). Press the name button and then erase it and start pressing buttons to put your own letters in. The timer to enter your name will reset as long as you are pressing buttons to enter letters. What happens is that you can continue to enter more letters than the code expects and you begin to over-write the area of memory that contains character information and inventory. Depending on what letters you enter and how many you enter you can continue the game at the beginning of the next stage and already be hasted, invulnerable, invisible, possessing powerful weapons, etc... The character info on screen is all garbled. Once you make it to the first shop you can drag apparently empty inventory items into the trash for large sums of silver. The game will lock up quite frequently though - especially when you pick up items that hold specific places in memory. Try using about 110 ''M''s for a name. This glitch was removed with the later revision.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Dungeons & Dragons - Tower of Doom [Green Board] (1994)[CR]2. Dungeons & Dragons - Shadow Over Mystara [Green Board] (1996)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Planners : Kenkun Kataoka, Malachie[CR]Character Designer : Kinu Nishimura[CR]Object Designers : "S" is a Criminal, Hiroaki Minobe, Shinya Miyamoto, Dway Nishimura, Kanako Takami, Miwa Shigenaga, Toshihiro Suzuki, Kako, Masayo Tsujimoto, Tsunenori Shirahama, Ino, R. Sato, Sagata, Masanori Kondo, Shinji Sakashita (Shinz. Sakashita), Satoru Yamashita, Yosinori Yamamoto, Dja, Jon, Iwasaki Inukichi, Jun Matsumura (28)[CR]Scroll Designers : Nissui, Saru, Shake, Hisoya, S. Kuwatch, J. Son, Ojiji, Takky, Iwai, Meiko. K[CR]Music Composer : Masato Koda[CR]Sound Designer : Moe. T[CR]Sound Effects : Moe. T, Hachi Bee, Satoshi Ise[CR]Sound Producer by Arcade Sound Team.[CR]Programmers : O.G.T, Kazuo Yamawaki, Motsu, Tora&Yume&Hide, Ryota Forever, K.A.T.S.U.O, Knishi-MadDogMc[CR]Original Script : Alex Jimenez[CR]Special Thanks : Lee, Mta (Groovy) Nshi, Shinichi Yasuki, Takuya Shiraiwa (Mr. Shiraiwa)[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]Sega Saturn [JP] (March 4, 1999, "Dungeons & Dragons Collection") [Model T-1224G][CR]Sega Saturn [JP] (March 4, 1999, "Dungeons & Dragons Collection [4MRAM Doukori Ban]") [Model T-1245G][CR]

game.name: Dungeons & Dragons: Tower of Doom (Japan 940412)
game.plot: Dungeons & Dragons - Tower of Doom (c) 1994 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]Based on the famous RPG system Dungeons & Dragons. Four warriors set a course for the evil Tower of Doom and battle lots of enemies straight out of the Monstrous Compendium![CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 4.[CR]Control: 8-Way Joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 4 per player.[CR]=> Attack, Jump, Use Item, Select Item[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Tower of Doom was released in January 1994 in Japan. It was known as the second game released on the CPS-II hardware.[CR]Known export releases:[CR]"Dungeons & Dragons - Tower of Doom [Blue Board]"[CR]"Dungeons & Dragons - Tower of Doom [Grey Board]"[CR]"Dungeons & Dragons - Tower of Doom [Orange Board]"[CR]The little sword-swinging flourish the fighter does after defeating a major enemy is taken directly from Capcom's previous side-scrolling sword fighting game, "Knights Of The Round".[CR]Jorel Chisolm holds the official record for this game with 238452 experience points on November 10, 2005.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Green Board revisions : [CR]REVISION 1 : [CR]* Build date: 940113[CR]REVISION 2 : [CR]* Build date: 940125[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Extended Ending : During the last fight with Deimos activate all 4 players, than defeat the boss. If all 4 characters are alive then an extra scene will be played after the ending credits where the party sets off for their next adventure.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Dungeons & Dragons - Tower of Doom [Green Board] (1994)[CR]2. Dungeons & Dragons - Shadow Over Mystara [Green Board] (1996)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Dungeon Masters : Tomoshi Sadamoto (11255), Magigi Fukunishi, George Kamitani, Alex Jimenez[CR]Character Designers : Hitoshi Nishio (T), Shinji Sakashita (Sinz. Sakashita), Jun Matsumura (25), Youjiro, Yukari Ogawa, Minobeyan, Popozu. Boo, Seigo Kawakami, Masako Sato, Tiyuki Sawada, Takemoto[CR]Artists : Fukumoyan, Ziggy, Miyao Masako, Hisashi Kisanuki, Junsuke, Angus, Hiropon[CR]Programmers : Kazuo Yamawaki, Belphegor Ogachy, Tsutumu Uragou, Teruaki Hirokado, Toshiyuki Furuko[CR]Music Composers : Isao Abe (Oyaji), Takayuki Iwai (Anarchy Takapon), Ok Production[CR]Sound Designers : Toshio Kajino, Tomuyuki Kawakami (T.K NY)[CR]Special Thanks : Kazumasa Yamanouchi, Ikusan Z, Yorio, Rikagon, Prof. Hayashi, Takuya Shiraiwa[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]Sega Saturn [JP] (March 4, 1999, "Dungeons & Dragons Collection") [Model T-1224G][CR]Sega Saturn [JP] (March 4, 1999, "Dungeons & Dragons Collection [4MRAM Doukori Ban]") [Model T-1245G][CR]

game.name: Darkstalkers: The Night Warriors (Euro 940705)
game.plot: Darkstalkers - The Night Warriors (c) 1994 Capcom.[CR]North American & European release. Game developed in Japan. For more information about the game itself, please see the original Japanese release entry; "Vampire - The Night Warriors [Green Board]".[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Blue Board [USA & Europe][CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Darkstalkers - The Night Warriors was released in July 1994 outside Japan. It is known in Japan as "Vampire - The Night Warriors".[CR]In these export versions:[CR]- Gallon is named Jon Talbain.[CR]- Zabel Zarock is named Lord Raptor.[CR]- Aulbath is named Rikuo.[CR]- Phobos is named Huitzil.[CR]Huitzil is the diminutive of 'Huitzilopochtli' (which means 'Blue Hummingbird on the Left'). He was the chief god of the great Aztec city Tenochtitlan and after his death became the Aztec god of the Sun and War.[CR]Justin Wong holds the official record for this game with 687800 points on May 30, 2008.[CR]A Darkstalkers unit appears in the 1995 movie 'The Net'.[CR]Michael Jackson used to own this game (Serial number: 305260). It was sold at the official Michael Jackson Auction on Apr. 24th, 2009.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Blue Board releases : [CR]REVISION 1[CR]* Build date: 940705[CR]* US and EUROPE releases.[CR]REVISION 2[CR]* Build date: 940818[CR]* US release.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Darkstalkers - The Night Warriors [Blue Board] (1994)[CR]2. Night Warriors - Darkstalkers' Revenge [Blue Board] (1995)[CR]3. Vampire Savior - The Lord of Vampire [CP-S II No. 22] (1997)[CR]4. Vampire Savior 2 - The Lord of Vampire [CP-S II No. 26] (1997)[CR]5. Vampire Hunter 2 - Darkstalkers' Revenge [CP-S II No. 27] (1997)[CR]6. Darkstalkers 3 - Vampire Savior (1999, Sony PlayStation)[CR]7. Darkstalkers Chronicles - The Chaos Tower (2005, Sony PSP)[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]Here is a list of ports released in North America and Europe.[CR]* Consoles : [CR]Sega 32X [Unreleased Prototype] [CR]Sony PlayStation [US] (March 28, 1996) "Darkstalkers - The Night Warriors [Model SLUS-00036]" [CR]Sony PlayStation [EU] (November 1996) "Darkstalkers - The Night Warriors [Model SLES-00251]"[CR]

He was the chief god of the great Aztec city Tenochtitlan and after his death became the Aztec god of the Sun and War.[CR]Justin Wong holds the official record for this game with 687800 points on May 30, 2008.[CR]A Darkstalkers unit appears in the 1995 movie 'The Net'.[CR]Michael Jackson used to own this game (Serial number: 305260). It was sold at the official Michael Jackson Auction on Apr. 24th, 2009.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Blue Board releases : [CR]REVISION 1[CR]* Build date: 940705[CR]* US and EUROPE releases.[CR]REVISION 2[CR]* Build date: 940818[CR]* US release.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. game.name: Giga Wing (Japan 990223)
game.plot: Giga Wing (c) 1999 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]'Medallions' are mystic stones sent from heaven, brought evolution to human technology and lead tremendous progress to the armories. To gain their powers which the 'Stones' hold for the promised victory, many nations fought over the mystic stones and reheated the world of war. Within all the 'Stones' is the 'Medallion of Wisdom', known as the power source of all mystic stones, it had enough energy to terminate humanity. The whole world was in despair. And now, four brave worriers have risen to fly straight into the combat zone! All four had different reasons, but their ultimate goal was the same : to destroy the Medallion of Wisdom! Fight to save the humanity![CR]Giga Wing is a shoot-em-up set during a fictional war. The player controls one of four different futuristic aircraft and must destroy enemy aircraft, tanks, ships, and buildings using both guns and missiles mounted on the aircraft and a limited supply of bombs which damage or destroy all enemies on-screen when used.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 2.[CR]Control: 8-way joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 2 per player.[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Giga Wing was released in February 1999 in Japan. It was known as the 30th video game released for the CPS-II hardware.[CR]Known export releases: [CR]"Giga Wing [Blue Board]" [CR]"Giga Wing [Grey Board]" [CR]"Giga Wing [Orange Board]" [CR]"Giga Wing [Pink Board]" [CR]It was the first arcade video game to show scores in the trillions![CR]The game forbids the initials 'SEX' on the high score table. If you try, it gets changed to 'CAP'.[CR]Note: There are 20 different endings! 10 of them are bad endings if you reach level 6 using more than one credit and the other 10 are good endings if you beat the game using only one credit.[CR]Sony Music Entertainment released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (GigaWing Original Soundtrack - CPCA-1026) on April 21, 1999.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Giga Wing [CP-S II No. 30] (1999)[CR]2. Giga Wing 2 (2000)[CR]3. Giga Wing Generations (2005)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Planner : I. Satou, R. Hazuki[CR]Character designer : K. Toume[CR]Mechanic designers : S. Satou, Tadahiro Mukaide, Toshihiro Suzuki, Ken Taketoshi, Y. Ono[CR]Object designers : Tadahiro Mukaide, S. Satou, Toshihiro Suzuki, I. Matsumura, Hiroki Akiyama, Ken Taketoshi[CR]Scroll designers : M. Oose, Kazumi Yogi, Akemi Ootaka, K. Kusaka[CR]Music composers & arrangers : Yasushi Kaminishi, Masahiro Yuge[CR]Programmers : Y. Kobayashi, T. Nishi, Kaju Ishii, N. Hasimoto[CR]Producers : Y. Ozaki, T. Minami[CR]Executive producers : T. Fujimoto, Yoshiki Okamoto, Noritaka Funamizu[CR]Coordinators : Tomoshi Sadamoto, T. Saitou[CR]Sound advisers : Hiroaki Kondo (X68K), Tomohiro Masuda[CR]Program support : K. Kaneko, M. Shinohara, S. Yamazaki, Cham Cho Choy[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles : [CR]Sega Dreamcast [JP] (November 11, 1999) [Model T-1208M][CR]

game.name: Great Mahou Daisakusen (Japan 000121)
game.plot: グレート魔法大作戦 (c) 2000 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR](Great Mahou Daisakusen)[CR]In this impressive blend of an overhead shoot'em up with RPG characteristics, you must help a group of mystic bounty hunters save the earth against the evil Gobligan Underground Empire. Features excellent 2-D graphics and sound, awesome character & enemy artwork designs, a level-up and elemental-based weapon system and LOTS of hidden items![CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 2[CR]Control: 8-way joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 3 per player.[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Great Mahou Daisakusen was released in January 2000 by Capcom. Developed by Eighting/Raizing. It was known as the 31th CPS-II game.[CR]Known Export release: "Dimahoo [Blue Board]" [CR]The title of this game translates from Japanese as 'Magic Great Military Operation'. The 'Dai' prefix in 'Daisakusen' means 'great', so to get technical the translation of this came could be 'Great Magic Great Military Operation'.[CR]Miyamoto the Dragon has appeared in previous Eighting games such as "Mahou Daisakusen", "Shippu Mahou Daisakusen" as a selectable character and as a secret character in "Armed Police Batrider".[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* To show up a menu of your collected treasures, press (ingame) Start for 2-3 sec. and press (while holding Start) Button 1.[CR]* Secret Characters : Insert a coin and press Up(x2), Left, Down(x2), Right, A, B, A, B, A, Start. Four new planes are now selectable.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Mahou Daisakusen (1993)[CR]2. Shippuu Mahou Daisakusen - Kingdom-Grandprix (1994)[CR]3. Great Mahou Daisakusen [Green Board] (2000)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Main programmer: Yuichi Toyama[CR]Planner & Designer: Ken-Ichi Yokoh[CR]Progress control: Susumu Hibi[CR]Producers: Masato Toyoshima, Tatsuya Minami[CR]Sound: Manabu Namiki[CR]Staff: Kazuyuki Nakashima, Yasunari Watanabe, Yoshitaka Ikeda, Hiroshi Satoh, Kenji Kawakita, Yukiko Sugiyama, Toshikazu Sahoda, Atsuhiro Motoyama, Ken-ichi Koyano, Nobuyuki Irie, Hiroshi Tahara, Tatsuya Uemura, Masahiro Yuge, Haruhisa Udagawa[CR]Support from Capcom: Tomoshi Sadamoto[CR]

game.name: Hyper Street Fighter II: The Anniversary Edition (Japan 040202)
game.description: Hyper Street Fighter II: The Anniversary Edition (Japan 040202)
game.title_clean: Hyper Street Fighter II: The Anniversary Edition
game.plot: Hyper Street Fighter II - The Anniversary Edition (c) 2004 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]Here comes a new challenger... Every character, every move, every combo: one massive game to celebrate the 15 years of one of the greatest fighting game of all time.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 2 [CR]Control: 8-way joystick per player[CR]Buttons: 6 per player.[CR]= > [1] LP (Jab), [2] MP (Strong), [3] HP (Fierce) [CR]= > [4] LK (Short), [5] MK (Forward), [6] HK (Roundhouse)[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Hyper Street Fighter II - The Anniversary Edition was released in December 2003 in Japan. It was known as the 38th CPS-II video game.[CR]Known Export releases:[CR]"Hyper Street Fighter II - The Anniversary Edition [Blue Board]"[CR]"Hyper Street Fighter II - The Anniversary Edition [Grey Board]"[CR]The core of the game is based on "Super Street Fighter II Turbo", but now players have up to five different versions of each character to choose from. [CR]The arcade intro has reverted back to the one found in "Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers" with the new addition being the title screens from the previous SFII games alternating between lightning flashes. [CR]The title screens for the CPS1 games "Street Fighter II - The World Warrior", "Street Fighter II' - Champion Edition", and "Street Fighter II' - Hyper Fighting" are presented for the first time on the CPS2 hardware via this game's intro. [CR]Though the character select screen layout is the same as the one found in "Super Street Fighter II Turbo", its music has changed back to the character select music found in "Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers, " which itself is a remixed version of the character select music from the CPS1 Street Fighter II games. [CR]The version of the character corresponds to the SFII game that they were playable in : [CR]'NORMAL' - "Street Fighter II - The World Warrior" [CR]'CHAMP' - "Street Fighter II' - Champion Edition"[CR]- Japanese version : 'DASH' - "Street Fighter II' - Champion Edition"[CR]'TURBO' - "Street Fighter II' - Hyper Fighting"[CR]'SUPER' - "Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers" [CR]'SUPER T' - "Super Street Fighter II Turbo"[CR]- Japanese version : 'SUPER X' - "Super Street Fighter II X - Grand Master Challenge" [CR]Note: In 1-player mode and attract mode, the CPU only uses the 'SUPER X'/'SUPER T' version of each character. [CR]The playback format of the background music has changed from "Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers". In the previous game, the background music will change to the 'Heavy Damage' version of the music on the second round onward when the KO sign flashes. In this game, the background music will change to the 'Heavy Damage' version of the music only if the character that triggered the KO sign to flash is in danger of losing his or her final round. [CR]Color schemes for the stage backgrounds are still the same as for "Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers" and "Super Street Fighter II Turbo". However, a few background elements originally seen exclusively in "Street Fighter II - The World Warrior" have returned : [CR]1) The dual barrels and stack of boxes in Ken's stage (from "Champion Edition" to "Super Turbo" there was just a single barrel). [CR]2) The breakable 'Fuurinkazan' signs in Ryu's stage. [CR]3) The lantern on the left side of E. Honda's stage (originally seen exclusively on the SNES port of "Street Fighter II - The World Warrior"). [CR]Conversely, background elements that were present since "Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers" are now missing : [CR]1) The toucan that flies away at round's end in Dee Jay's stage. [CR]Another change from the previous episodes can be seen at the character selection screen, when you go on Fei Long's profile, the colonial flag of Hong Kong was changed to the flag of China due to the handover in 1997. Street Fighter has to keep up with the times![CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Holding Start while selecting 'SUPER' for the version of your character will select the secret 'Super' version of the character as found in "Super Street Fighter II Turbo". [CR]* Pressing the Start button to select your character when using the 'NORMAL', 'SUPER', or 'Old Super' version of the character will select them in an alternate classic outfit, used originally when two players simultaneously used the old version of the same character in "Super Street Fighter II Turbo". [CR]* Holding Start while selecting 'SUPER T' for the version of your character will allow certain characters to 'store' their super combos.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Street Fighter (1987)[CR]2. Street Fighter II - The World Warrior [B-Board 90629B] (1991)[CR]3. Street Fighter II' - Champion Edition [B-Board 91634B-2] (1992)[CR]4. Street Fighter II' - Hyper Fighting [B-Board 91635B-2] (1992)[CR]5. Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [Green Board] (1993)[CR]6. Super Street Fighter II Turbo [Blue Board] (1994)[CR]7. Street Fighter Alpha - Warriors' Dreams [Blue Board] (1995)[CR]8. Street Fighter Alpha 2 [Blue Board] (1996)[CR]9. Street Fighter III - New Generation (1997)[CR]10. Street Fighter III - 2nd Impact : Giant Attack (1997)[CR]11. Street Fighter Alpha 3 [Blue Board] (1998)[CR]12. Street Fighter III - 3rd Strike : Fight For The Future (1999)[CR]13. Hyper Street Fighter II - The Anniversary Edition [Green Board] (2003)[CR]14. Street Fighter IV (2008)[CR]15. Super Street Fighter IV - Arcade Edition (2010)[CR]16. game.name: Jyangokushi: Haoh no Saihai (Japan 990527)
game.plot: Jangokushi - Haou no Saihai (c) 1999 Capcom.[CR]A mahjong game from Capcom.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Main CPU : Motorola 68000 (@ 11.8 Mhz), Zilog Z80 (@ 8 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : Q-Sound (@ 4 Mhz)[CR]Players : 2[CR]Buttons : 6[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Jangokushi Haou no Saihai was released in May 1999[CR]The title of this game translates from Japanese as 'Jong Countries' Intentions - Supreme Ruler's Dice and Tiles'.[CR]The title 'Jangokushi' is a pun on 'Sangokushi', the saga of the Three Kingdoms, which this game is based on.[CR]

game.name: Mars Matrix: Hyper Solid Shooting (Japan 000412)
game.plot: Mars Matrix - Hyper Solid Shooting (c) 2000 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]In the 25th century, Mars is home to millions of immigrants. This is because Earth was going to be overcrowded, and thus the colonization of a terraformed Mars was the only solution. The problem is, at some point, an unknown source of energy, located in the south pole, is discovered by the local government. All of a sudden, a declaration of independence arrives on Earth. What's going on? The Earth fleet goes to reveal it, with the new 'Mosquito fighters' acting as intruders...[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 2.[CR]Control: 8-way joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 1 per player.[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Developed by Takumi (see Staff section for more info), Mars Matrix was released in April 2000 by Capcom. It was known as the 32th video game released for the CPS-II hardware.[CR]The original arcade version could actually be maxed out, score wise: this means that you could get 999999999990 points (that's twelve digits), if you played in a flawless way. Note: This feature has been removed in the Dreamcast version, since that port added two extra digits in the score.[CR]Suleputer released a 2-CD limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Mars Matrix, Giga Wing 2 Original Soundtrack - CPCA-1050, 1051) on January 11, 2001.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Mars Matrix weapons :[CR]1) Normal rapid-fire : light-damage shooting is carried out by tapping the button.[CR]2) Load (or beam) : By pausing between attacks, and then shooting, the beam-weapon will fire. This attack is relatively powerful, can hit multiple targets, but has a much shorter range.[CR]3) Barrier : the absorption of enemy shots is performed by holding the attack button down. The player can choose the duration of absorption, and if they leave it pressed until the maximum, an explosion will result which destroys all enemies and shots displayed on the screen. On the other hand, absorbing only partially acts as a reflection attack: enemy projectiles are thrown back at the enemy.[CR]* Experience system : in Mars Matrix, there is a system which makes it possible to improve the protagonist vessel(s) by collecting gold cubes. The cubes, which come from the destruction or damage to every object in the game, add to an 'experience bar' at near the top of the screen when collected in a continuous combo. A greater amount of these gold cubes will be unleashed if the player uses reflection attacks. Once the experience bar is filled, the player's weapons will become more powerful, and then the meter zeroes out for the next experience level. A small bar located in top of the screen indicates the amount of remaining time until the combo runs out; if this happens the meter zeroes out for the current level. The meter will also reset if the player's ship is destroyed while a combo is active.[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Developed by Takumi.[CR]Programmers: Takafumi Nishi, Kaju Ishii, Toshihiko Onodera, Naoto Sakurada[CR]Object designers: Ken Taketoshi, Tatsuhiro Suzuki, Hiroki Akiyama, Yuki Ootou[CR]Scroll designers: Kazumi Yogi, Tadahiro Mukaide, Akemi Ootaka[CR]Music composer: Yasushi Kaminishi[CR]Sound programmer: Masahiro Yuge[CR]Concept mechanic designers: Choco, Shorp, Nadialove Kitty, Norihiro Takikawa[CR]Planner: Ikuwo Satoh[CR]Producer: Yukikazu ozaki[CR]Executive producer: Tomoaki Fujimoto[CR]Produced by Capcom.[CR]Producer : Tatuya Minami[CR]Support from R&Dept. #3 : Tomoshi Sadamoto[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles : [CR]Sega Dreamcast [JP] (November 9, 2000) [Model T-1238M][CR]

game.name: Mighty! Pang (Japan 001011)
game.plot: Mighty! Pang (c) 2000 Mitchell.[CR]Mighty! Pang is the fourth game in the superb Pang series. While the artistic design has been drastically changed, Mighty! Pang retains the same gameplay of its predecessors. The game features three modes of play: panic, tour and expert modes.[CR]Tour mode is the standard mode of play featuring 57 stages. The player goes on a tour of the world, popping balloons and picking up power-ups. Each location on the tour features a number of stages which feature a new background of a famous tourist attraction. Each stage is cleared by popping all of the balloons within that stage.[CR]Expert mode is a mode for advanced players. Play is broken up into stages like in tour mode but the stages are much more difficult.[CR]Panic mode is a basic one-stage mode of play where new balloons continuously fall from the sky. The single stage is a basic one with no platforms or barriers. Some of the smallest balloons will flash and shooting these balloons will pause all of the balloons in place for a short duration of time.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 2.[CR]Control: 8-way joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 6 per player.[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Mighty Pang was released in October 2000 in the Japanese arcades. It was known as the 34th video game released on the CPS-II. It was also the first Mitchell game for this hardware.[CR]Released outside Japan as "Mighty! Pang [Blue Board]".[CR]The game forbids the initials 'SEX' on the high score table. If you try, it gets changed to 'MIT'.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Pang (1989)[CR]2. Super Pang (1990)[CR]3. Pang! 3 [B-Board 94916-10] (1995)[CR]4. Mighty! Pang [Green Board] (2000)[CR]5. Pang - Magical Michael (2010, Nintendo DS)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Planners : Futoshi Kuwahara, Taiji Miyajima[CR]Lead programmers : Shigeru Komiya[CR]Lead artist : Eiko Kato[CR]Character designer : Satoshi Ida[CR]Art supervisor : Tetuhiro Kuroda[CR]Assistants : Kazue Matunaga, Makoto Kobayashi, Hiroki Narisawa, Daigo Ota[CR]Music composer : Takafumi Wada[CR]SE designer : Yoko Mizumoto[CR]Executive producer : Roy Ozaki[CR]Producer : Kouichi Niida[CR]

game.name: Marvel Super Heroes (Japan 951117)
game.plot: Marvel Super Heroes (c) 1995 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]Ten characters straight out of Marvel Comics prove their worthiness to meet Dr. Doom and Thanos. Includes special power-up gems that can be used and acquired during a match.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 2.[CR]Control: 8-way joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 6 per player.[CR]=> [1] LP (Jab), [2] MP (Short), [3] HP (Fierce)[CR]=> [4] LK (Strong), [5] MK (Forward), [6] HK(Roundhouse)[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Marvel Super Heroes was released in October 1995 in the Japanese arcades. It was known as the 12th video game released for the CPS-II hardware.[CR]Known export releases:[CR]"Marvel Super Heroes [Blue Board]"[CR]"Marvel Super Heroes [Grey Board]"[CR]"Marvel Super Heroes [Orange Board]"[CR]"Marvel Super Heroes [Pink Board]"[CR]The game background is mainly inspired by the famous comic saga called the Infinity Gauntlet, published in 1991. This gauntlet is wielded by Thanos and allows him to use all the Infinity gems simultaneously.[CR]There are 10 characters available plus the 2 bosses which appears in different Marvel comic books :[CR]Black Heart - Daredevil #270[CR]Captain America (aka Steve Rogers) - Captain America Comics #1[CR]Doctor Doom (aka Victor Von Doom) - Fantastic Four #5[CR]Hulk (aka Robert Bruce Banner) - Incredible Hulk #1[CR]Iron Man (aka Anthony 'Tony' Stark) - Tales of Suspense #39 [CR]Juggernaut (aka Cain Marko) - X-Men #12[CR]Magneto (aka Erik 'Magnus' Lehnsherr) - X-Men #1[CR]Psylocke (aka Elizabeth 'Betsy' Braddock) - New Mutants Annual #2[CR]Shuma-Gorath - Marvel Premiere #6[CR]Spider-Man (aka Peter Parker) - Amazing Fantasy #15[CR]Thanos - Iron Man #55[CR]Wolverine (aka James 'Logan' Howlett) - Incredible Hulk #180[CR]Marvel Super Heroes was released by Capcom in memory of 'Jack Kirby' (aka 'The King of the Comics') [1917 / 1994] who was the most influential and respected illustrator and creator of comic books, at least of the super-hero/adventure variety. He was so important that, with that field now in recession, some are saying that when Jack Kirby died, he took the industry with him.[CR]Soundtrack releases:[CR]Marvel Super Heroes / Sony Records - SRCL-3448 - December 1, 1995[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Green Board revisions : [CR]REVISION 1:[CR]Build date: 951024[CR]REVISION 2:[CR]Build date: 951117[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Play as Anita : Press MP, LP, Left, LK, MK at the character selection screen.[CR]* Play as Dr. Doom : Press MK, LP, Down, LK, MP at the character selection screen.[CR]* Play as Thanos : Press LK, HK, MP(x2), Up at the character selection screen.[CR]* Double Power : Select a fighter at the character selection screen, then press Player One Start + Player Two Start.[CR]* Continue Fighting : Press Start immediately after winning a round to continue hitting the defeated character.[CR]* Disable Gems : To disable Gems in two player mode both players must press and hold Start after choosing their character until the round starts.[CR]* Change Character Color : At the character select screen move to the desired character then hold Up (if on top row) or Down (if on bottom row). After 3 seconds press any punch or kick button to select character.[CR]* Here are the different gem effects (which acts during a short time) and when you can get them :[CR]Time gem (Red) : You are much more faster than usual.[CR]Space gem (Purple) : Your character get unstoppable with this super armor power.[CR]Soul gem (Green) : Your fighter slowly recovers life.[CR]Power gem (Pink) : Your attacks are more powerful.[CR]Reality gem (Orange, on the fifth opponent) : Your attacks have additional effects which makes them more powerful.[CR]Mind gem (Blue, owned by Thanos) : The character can recover about 2 energy levels in a few seconds.[CR]The gems are owned by different opponents: we have one at the beginning, then the first opponent have the following one then the second, then the third and finally the fifth (the last one is on Thanos). Characters have some special effects using some gems (for instance Magneto got an energy field around him with the Space gem, Spiderman divides himself in two similar being for symmetrical attacks using the Power gem).[CR]Notice that we can only use the first gem in our gem stack. If you press the Start button during the fight, you will change the gem order in your stack, allowing for you to use any desired gem at any time.[CR]When we reach the final fight against Thanos, he steal all the gems and collects them in his gauntlet. He uses them his way (for instance : space gem creates a warp which attracts and throws rocks on his enemy).[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Planners : Takeshi Tezuka, Tetsuya Iijima, Tomichi, Kiyoshi Nishikawa, Kei Hiratou, Satoru Kimura[CR]Programmers : Tarabar Hori (Tarabar-Black), Aoi-Peach, Kaw-K. Marichan, Silver-Kadontz, Nobu-Sasami, Knishi- (MadDogMc), Pon, Dna, Frk, Yama, Tomohiro Ueno, Youji[CR]Scroll Designers : Konomi (Powerful Konomi), Buppo, Shibata Kayoko, Daisuke Nakagawa, Yumiko, Takapon, Akiko Matsunaga, Satomi Ishii, R.K, Yoichi Tanoue, M[CR]Music Composers : Takayuki Iwai (Anarchy Takapon), Yuki Satomura (Wewe), Tatsuro Zuzuki[CR]Sound Designers : Picard Mij, Satoshi Ise (Ayano), Ryoji Yamamoto (Ryoji)[CR]Sound Producer : Arcade Sound Team[CR]Voice Designers : Hiroaki Kondo (New-X?)[CR]* Object Designers :[CR]Thanos : Shinji Sakashita (Sakashita Thing), D-Kurita, Takayuki Kosaka, Masako. Satoh[CR]Dr. Doom : Satoru Yamashita, Ino, Seigo Kawakami[CR]Wolverine : Akira Yasuda (Akiman)[CR]Spider-man : Arahijuf, Rumi Yamaguchi, Tsunenori Shirahama[CR]Captain America : Masaaki Tanaka, Chimorin Shogun, Misako Yamamoto[CR]Psylocke : Eripyon. N[CR]Hulk : Makoto Ishi, K. Takechan, Miwa, Kanako Takami[CR]Iron Man : Yoshino Hiroaki, Kiai Ryuken, Yukikaze, You-Ten Nakano, Yutaka Maruno, Cepezou, Mimura Kenji, K. Tokunaga, Eizi Murabayashi, Naoki Fukuda, Takep, Henoheno, Yuki[CR]Magneto : A. Iwasaki[CR]Shuma-Gorath : Masayo Tsujimoto, Jun Matsumura (27), Shinya Miyamoto, Kako, Masanori Kondo[CR]Blackheart : Alien. Pole, Fnyaco. F. Fnyao, Dway Nishimura, Oyabin[CR]Juggernaut : Minobe Hiroaki, R. Sato, Kazuko Kawanaka[CR]Effect : Ntengm Nakatani, Sagata, Tanuki, Kimo Kimo[CR]* Voice Actors :[CR]Captain America : Cathal J. Dodd[CR]Wolverine : Cathal J. Dodd[CR]Black Heart : Jaimz Woolvett[CR]Psylocke : Catherine Disher[CR]Shuma-Gorath : Franck Perry[CR]Spider-Man : Patrick Chilvers[CR]Hulk : Andrew Jackson[CR]Thanos : Andrew Jackson[CR]Juggernaut : Rick Bennett[CR]Iron Man : Christopher Britton[CR]Doctor Doom : Lorne Kennedy[CR]Magneto : Lorne Kennedy[CR]Anounncer : Lorne Kennedy[CR]Special Thanks : Takuya Shiraiwa (Mr. Shiraiwa), Alex Jimenez, Eric Luther (Eric Luthr), Phillp Reed (Phil Reed)[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles : [CR]Sega Saturn [JP] (August 8, 1997) "Marvel Super Heroes [Model T-1215G]" [CR]Sony PlayStation [JP] (September 25, 1997) "Marvel Super Heroes [Model SLPS-00763]" [CR]Notes: Anita is now hidden character and only playable in Japanese console version.[CR]

game.name: Marvel Super Heroes (Japan 951024)
game.plot: Marvel Super Heroes (c) 1995 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]Ten characters straight out of Marvel Comics prove their worthiness to meet Dr. Doom and Thanos. Includes special power-up gems that can be used and acquired during a match.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 2.[CR]Control: 8-way joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 6 per player.[CR]=> [1] LP (Jab), [2] MP (Short), [3] HP (Fierce)[CR]=> [4] LK (Strong), [5] MK (Forward), [6] HK(Roundhouse)[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Marvel Super Heroes was released in October 1995 in the Japanese arcades. It was known as the 12th video game released for the CPS-II hardware.[CR]Known export releases:[CR]"Marvel Super Heroes [Blue Board]"[CR]"Marvel Super Heroes [Grey Board]"[CR]"Marvel Super Heroes [Orange Board]"[CR]"Marvel Super Heroes [Pink Board]"[CR]The game background is mainly inspired by the famous comic saga called the Infinity Gauntlet, published in 1991. This gauntlet is wielded by Thanos and allows him to use all the Infinity gems simultaneously.[CR]There are 10 characters available plus the 2 bosses which appears in different Marvel comic books :[CR]Black Heart - Daredevil #270[CR]Captain America (aka Steve Rogers) - Captain America Comics #1[CR]Doctor Doom (aka Victor Von Doom) - Fantastic Four #5[CR]Hulk (aka Robert Bruce Banner) - Incredible Hulk #1[CR]Iron Man (aka Anthony 'Tony' Stark) - Tales of Suspense #39 [CR]Juggernaut (aka Cain Marko) - X-Men #12[CR]Magneto (aka Erik 'Magnus' Lehnsherr) - X-Men #1[CR]Psylocke (aka Elizabeth 'Betsy' Braddock) - New Mutants Annual #2[CR]Shuma-Gorath - Marvel Premiere #6[CR]Spider-Man (aka Peter Parker) - Amazing Fantasy #15[CR]Thanos - Iron Man #55[CR]Wolverine (aka James 'Logan' Howlett) - Incredible Hulk #180[CR]Marvel Super Heroes was released by Capcom in memory of 'Jack Kirby' (aka 'The King of the Comics') [1917 / 1994] who was the most influential and respected illustrator and creator of comic books, at least of the super-hero/adventure variety. He was so important that, with that field now in recession, some are saying that when Jack Kirby died, he took the industry with him.[CR]Soundtrack releases:[CR]Marvel Super Heroes / Sony Records - SRCL-3448 - December 1, 1995[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Green Board revisions : [CR]REVISION 1:[CR]Build date: 951024[CR]REVISION 2:[CR]Build date: 951117[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Play as Anita : Press MP, LP, Left, LK, MK at the character selection screen.[CR]* Play as Dr. Doom : Press MK, LP, Down, LK, MP at the character selection screen.[CR]* Play as Thanos : Press LK, HK, MP(x2), Up at the character selection screen.[CR]* Double Power : Select a fighter at the character selection screen, then press Player One Start + Player Two Start.[CR]* Continue Fighting : Press Start immediately after winning a round to continue hitting the defeated character.[CR]* Disable Gems : To disable Gems in two player mode both players must press and hold Start after choosing their character until the round starts.[CR]* Change Character Color : At the character select screen move to the desired character then hold Up (if on top row) or Down (if on bottom row). After 3 seconds press any punch or kick button to select character.[CR]* Here are the different gem effects (which acts during a short time) and when you can get them :[CR]Time gem (Red) : You are much more faster than usual.[CR]Space gem (Purple) : Your character get unstoppable with this super armor power.[CR]Soul gem (Green) : Your fighter slowly recovers life.[CR]Power gem (Pink) : Your attacks are more powerful.[CR]Reality gem (Orange, on the fifth opponent) : Your attacks have additional effects which makes them more powerful.[CR]Mind gem (Blue, owned by Thanos) : The character can recover about 2 energy levels in a few seconds.[CR]The gems are owned by different opponents: we have one at the beginning, then the first opponent have the following one then the second, then the third and finally the fifth (the last one is on Thanos). Characters have some special effects using some gems (for instance Magneto got an energy field around him with the Space gem, Spiderman divides himself in two similar being for symmetrical attacks using the Power gem).[CR]Notice that we can only use the first gem in our gem stack. If you press the Start button during the fight, you will change the gem order in your stack, allowing for you to use any desired gem at any time.[CR]When we reach the final fight against Thanos, he steal all the gems and collects them in his gauntlet. He uses them his way (for instance : space gem creates a warp which attracts and throws rocks on his enemy).[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Planners : Takeshi Tezuka, Tetsuya Iijima, Tomichi, Kiyoshi Nishikawa, Kei Hiratou, Satoru Kimura[CR]Programmers : Tarabar Hori (Tarabar-Black), Aoi-Peach, Kaw-K. Marichan, Silver-Kadontz, Nobu-Sasami, Knishi- (MadDogMc), Pon, Dna, Frk, Yama, Tomohiro Ueno, Youji[CR]Scroll Designers : Konomi (Powerful Konomi), Buppo, Shibata Kayoko, Daisuke Nakagawa, Yumiko, Takapon, Akiko Matsunaga, Satomi Ishii, R.K, Yoichi Tanoue, M[CR]Music Composers : Takayuki Iwai (Anarchy Takapon), Yuki Satomura (Wewe), Tatsuro Zuzuki[CR]Sound Designers : Picard Mij, Satoshi Ise (Ayano), Ryoji Yamamoto (Ryoji)[CR]Sound Producer : Arcade Sound Team[CR]Voice Designers : Hiroaki Kondo (New-X?)[CR]* Object Designers :[CR]Thanos : Shinji Sakashita (Sakashita Thing), D-Kurita, Takayuki Kosaka, Masako. Satoh[CR]Dr. Doom : Satoru Yamashita, Ino, Seigo Kawakami[CR]Wolverine : Akira Yasuda (Akiman)[CR]Spider-man : Arahijuf, Rumi Yamaguchi, Tsunenori Shirahama[CR]Captain America : Masaaki Tanaka, Chimorin Shogun, Misako Yamamoto[CR]Psylocke : Eripyon. N[CR]Hulk : Makoto Ishi, K. Takechan, Miwa, Kanako Takami[CR]Iron Man : Yoshino Hiroaki, Kiai Ryuken, Yukikaze, You-Ten Nakano, Yutaka Maruno, Cepezou, Mimura Kenji, K. Tokunaga, Eizi Murabayashi, Naoki Fukuda, Takep, Henoheno, Yuki[CR]Magneto : A. Iwasaki[CR]Shuma-Gorath : Masayo Tsujimoto, Jun Matsumura (27), Shinya Miyamoto, Kako, Masanori Kondo[CR]Blackheart : Alien. Pole, Fnyaco. F. Fnyao, Dway Nishimura, Oyabin[CR]Juggernaut : Minobe Hiroaki, R. Sato, Kazuko Kawanaka[CR]Effect : Ntengm Nakatani, Sagata, Tanuki, Kimo Kimo[CR]* Voice Actors :[CR]Captain America : Cathal J. Dodd[CR]Wolverine : Cathal J. Dodd[CR]Black Heart : Jaimz Woolvett[CR]Psylocke : Catherine Disher[CR]Shuma-Gorath : Franck Perry[CR]Spider-Man : Patrick Chilvers[CR]Hulk : Andrew Jackson[CR]Thanos : Andrew Jackson[CR]Juggernaut : Rick Bennett[CR]Iron Man : Christopher Britton[CR]Doctor Doom : Lorne Kennedy[CR]Magneto : Lorne Kennedy[CR]Anounncer : Lorne Kennedy[CR]Special Thanks : Takuya Shiraiwa (Mr. Shiraiwa), Alex Jimenez, Eric Luther (Eric Luthr), Phillp Reed (Phil Reed)[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles : [CR]Sega Saturn [JP] (August 8, 1997) "Marvel Super Heroes [Model T-1215G]" [CR]Sony PlayStation [JP] (September 25, 1997) "Marvel Super Heroes [Model SLPS-00763]" [CR]Notes: Anita is now hidden character and only playable in Japanese console version.[CR]

game.name: Marvel Super Heroes Vs. Street Fighter (Japan 970707)
game.description: Marvel Super Heroes Vs. Street Fighter (Japan 970707)
game.title_clean: Marvel Super Heroes Vs. Street Fighter
game.plot: Marvel Super Heroes vs. Street Fighter (c) 1997 Capcom.[CR]The second 'Capcom Vs.' series fighter, featuring 17 Marvel and Street Fighter characters teaming up to face the extremely cheap Mech-Akuma![CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 2.[CR]Control: 8-way joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 6 per player.[CR]= > [1] LP, [2] MP, [3] HP[CR]= > [4] LK, [5] MK, [6] HK[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Marvel Super Heroes vs. Street Fighter was released in June 1997 in the Japanese arcades. It was known as the 23th video game released on the CPS-II hardware.[CR]Known export releases:[CR]"Marvel Super Heroes vs. Street Fighter [Blue Board]"[CR]"Marvel Super Heroes vs. Street Fighter [Grey Board]"[CR]"Marvel Super Heroes vs. Street Fighter [Orange Board]"[CR]"Marvel Super Heroes vs. Street Fighter [Pink Board]"[CR]9 characters are coming from Marvel comic books-followed by their first appearance : [CR]Apocalypse (aka En Sabah Nur) - X-Factor #5 [CR]Blackheart - Daredevil #270 [CR]Captain America (aka Steve Rogers) - Captain America Comics #1 [CR]Cyclops (aka Scott Summers) - X-Men #1 [CR]Hulk (aka Robert Bruce Banner) - Incredible Hulk #1 [CR]Omega Red (aka Arkady Rossovich) - X-Men #4 [CR]Shuma-Gorath - Marvel Premiere #6 [CR]Spider-Man (aka Peter Parker) - Amazing Fantasy #15 [CR]Wolverine (aka James 'Logan' Howlett) - Incredible Hulk #180 [CR]9 other character come from several Street Fighter games : [CR]Akuma ('Gouki' in Japan) - "Super Street Fighter II X - Grand Master Challenge" in Japan; "Super Street Fighter II Turbo" in all other regions [CR]Chun-Li - "Street Fighter II - The World Warrior" [CR]Dan Hibiki - "Street Fighter Alpha - Warriors' Dreams" in North America and Europe; "Street Fighter Zero" in Japan, Southeast Asia, Brazil, and Hispanic regions [CR]Dhalsim - "Street Fighter II - The World Warrior" [CR]Ken Masters - "Street Fighter" [CR]Major Bison ('Vega' in Japan) - "Street Fighter II - The World Warrior" [CR]Ryu - "Street Fighter" [CR]Sakura Kasugano - "Street Fighter Alpha 2" in the United States, Canada, and Europe; "Street Fighter Zero 2" in Japan, Southeast Asia, Brazil, Oceania, and Hispanic regions[CR]Zangief - "Street Fighter II - The World Warrior" [CR]Charlie, Gambit, Rogue, and Rose appear in the background in the 'Showdown in the Park' stage. [CR]Blanka (of "Street Fighter" fame) can be seen within the background in the 'Death Valley' stage. [CR]Dan's ending is an obvious parody of the ending of the SNK game, "Art of Fighting". [CR]Sunburned (or Evil) Sakura has two separate endings (Japanese version): Kei chases Gouki and Sunburned Sakura after they teleport away [CR]1) Across the entire screen from right to left. [CR]2) Across half the screen before she trips, falls, and falls asleep. [CR]There are several cameos of Rockman in this game: [CR]1) In the mall stage, there's a cameo of a Rockman cut-out (perhaps someone in a Rockman suit). And in relation to Capcom celebrating Rockman's "10th Anniversary" in 1997, they put a banner saying '10th Anniversary: Rockman'. [CR]2) In one of Norimaro's super combos, he does a cosplay of Rockman. [CR]There is one rumored reason why Iron Man was not in this game. It is because Acclaim made an Iron Man game called "Iron Man and X-O Manowar in Heavy Metal" which was released for several consoles. [CR]Firstsmile released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Marvel Super Heroes Vs. Street Fighter Original Soundtrack & Arrange - FSCA-10017) on September 19, 1997.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Green Board revisions : [CR]REVISION 1:[CR]* Build date: 970625[CR]REVISION 2:[CR]* Build date: 970702[CR]REVISION 3:[CR]* Build date: 970707[CR]ADDITIONAL NOTES: [CR]The Japanese version features an extra playable character (his character slot on the character select screen is replaced by the MSH vs. SF logo on all non-Japanese versions), Norimaro, a silly otaku (Japanese geek specializing in anime and manga) who is a huge Chun-Li fanboy as evidence by his reaction in seeing her before the match begins. While his true intentions of entering the competition is unknown, we can assume that it was to take pictures of Chun-Li and the many superheroes. He is voiced by the comedian Kinashi Noritake and created by Capcom as being a joke character like Dan (modeled after a Japanese comedian Noritake Kinashi). He was originally going to appear in non-Japanese versions of the game, but due to cultural differences and a reference to stealing Chun-Li's panties in his ending, he was cut out. However, his programming still exists in the ROM and he even has English dialogs in the game. He even has an ending with pictures, but his ending dialogs was cut out.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Play as Evil Sakura : At the character selection screen, highlight Hulk, hold Right for 5 sec. and press LP+HP or LK+HK.[CR]* Play as Evil Zanglief : At the character selection screen, highlight Blackheart, hold Left for 5 sec. and press LP+HP or LK+HK.[CR]* Play as Armored Spiderman : At the character selection screen, highlight Ryu, move down and hold Down for 5 sec. and press LP+HP or LK+HK.[CR]* Play as Mephisto : At the character selection screen, highlight Omega Red, hold Down for 5 sec. and press LP+HP or LK+HK.[CR]* Play as U.S. Agent : At the character selection screen, highlight Bison, hold Up for 5 sec. and press LP+HP or LK+HK.[CR]* Play as Shadow Charlie : At the character selection screen, highlight Dhalsim, hold Up for 5 sec. and press LP+HP or LK+HK.[CR]* Play as Gambit : Go to Dhalsim, hold Start, then move Left(x2), Down(x4), Right(x2), Up(x2), Right and press and hold LP+MK+HP together.[CR]* Play as Norimaro (Japanese version only) : Norimaro will show on the character select screen (bottom middle square) if the machine is set to Freeplay or 1 coin X credit. A setting of 2 coins or above and you will only see the Marvel Super Heroes Vs. Street Fighter logo in his square.[CR]* Beat 'em While They're Down : After defeating your opponents, press and hold Start. Normally your character wont be able to move after the round is over but by holding Start you will not only be able to move freely (until the next round starts) but you will be able to hit your opponent and even do a Super on them![CR]* Change Battle Order : When the screen shows which teams will be battling, press Punch or Kick three times to change the order of battle.[CR]* Double Team Spidermen : Start a new game and choose any character for your first choice followed by Spiderman as the second character. Deliberately lose, then continue and choose Silver Spiderman as your first character. The other Spiderman should be selected as your second character.[CR]* Fight Secret Characters (Japanese Version) : To fight a secret character in the Japanese version you must do a certain amount of team super finishes :[CR]Character #[CR]Evil Sakura 5[CR]Evil Zangief 6[CR]Shadow Charlie 7[CR]* Hyper Mode : At the vs. screen, hold LK+MP+HK.[CR]* Dan's Explosion : Pick Dan as your fighter and anyone else. At the Vs. screen hold LP until the word fight disappears. When the match begins Dan will fall into a small explosion.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]Note: also called the 'Capcom vs.' series.[CR]1. X-Men vs. Street Fighter [Green Board] (1996)[CR]2. Marvel Super Heroes vs. Street Fighter [Green Board] (1997)[CR]3. Marvel vs. Capcom - Clash of Super Heroes [Green Board] (1998)[CR]4. Marvel vs. Capcom 2 - New Age of Heroes (2000)[CR]5. Marvel vs. Capcom 3 (2011)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Planners : Atsushi Tomita, Nakano Tau! Masahiro, Dave Matumoto[CR]Original art works : Akira Yasuda (Akiman), Sakomizu, Ukabin[CR]Object designers : Minobe Hiroaki Da!!, Sagata, G.Kamina, Miwaringo, Kohichi Kikutani, Hiroshi Yoshioka, Shinya Miyamoto, Kondo Masanori, Satou Rie, Takep, Yosinori Yamamoto, Jon Narancha, Toshihiro Suzuki, R. Naoi, Kanako Takami[CR]Scroll designers : Iwai, Konomi, Hisashi Sawada, Dear Akirakun 1997, May, Inoyan, Youko Fukumoto, Kisabon, Takashi Fujiwara, Hiroshi Yuugen, Chie Morisaki, Holly Genki?, Shinnosuke, Manga-Chop[CR]Music composers & arrange : Yuki Iwai, Yuko Kadota[CR]Sound director : Hiroaki Kondo (X68K) (cipher)[CR]Sound assistants : Hachi & Ise & lee, Moe.T (cipher)[CR]Recording director : Susan Hart[CR]Recording enginners : Paul Shubat, Dave Hatt[CR]Programmers : Motsu, Eternal Sailor, Kaw, Silver Kadontz, You![CR]Producer : Kenji Kataoka[CR]General producer : Noritaka Funamizu[CR]Executive producer : Yoshiki Okamoto[CR]* Voice Actors :[CR]Zangief : Wataru Takagi[CR]M. Bison : Tomomichi Nishimura[CR]Dhalsim : Yoshiharu Yamada[CR]Sakura Kasugano : Yuko Sasamoto[CR]Akuma : Tomomichi Nishimura[CR]Chun-Li : Yuko Miyamura[CR]Ken Masters : Iwanaga Tetsuya[CR]Ryu : Toshiyuki Morikawa[CR]Dan Hibiki : Osamu Hosoi[CR]Cyclops : Norman Spencer[CR]Captain America : Cathal J. Dodd[CR]Spider-Man : Patrick Chilvers[CR]Shuma-Gorath : Franck Perry[CR]Wolverine : Cathal J. Dodd[CR]The Incredible Hulk : Andrew Jackson[CR]Blackheart : Jaimz Woolvett[CR]Omega Red : Len Doncheff[CR]Norimaro : Noritake Kinashi[CR]Apocalypse : Lorne Kennedy[CR]Narrator : Tony Daniels[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles : [CR][JP] Sega Saturn (Oct.22, 1998) "Marvel Super Heroes vs. Street Fighter [4MRAM Doukori Ban] [Model T-1238G]" [CR][JP] Sega Saturn (Oct.22, 1998) "Marvel Super Heroes vs. Street Fighter [Model T-1239G]" [CR][JP] Sony PlayStation (Feb.25, 1999) "Marvel Super Heroes vs. Street Fighter EX Edition [Model SLPS-01915]"[CR]

[CR]Sunburned (or Evil) Sakura has two separate endings (Japanese version): Kei chases Gouki and Sunburned Sakura after they teleport away [CR]1) Across the entire screen from right to left. [CR]2) Across half the screen before she trips, falls, and falls asleep. [CR]There are several cameos of Rockman in this game: [CR]1) In the mall stage, there's a cameo of a Rockman cut-out (perhaps someone in a Rockman suit). And in relation to Capcom celebrating Rockman's "10th Anniversary" in 1997, they put a banner saying '10th Anniversary: Rockman'. [CR]2) In one of Norimaro's super combos, he does a cosplay of Rockman. [CR]There is one rumored reason why Iron Man was not in this game. It is because Acclaim made an Iron Man game called "Iron Man and X-O Manowar in Heavy Metal" which was released for several consoles. [CR]Firstsmile released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Marvel Super Heroes Vs. Street Fighter Original Soundtrack & Arrange - FSCA-10017) on September 19, 1997.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Green Board revisions : [CR]REVISION 1:[CR]* Build date: 970625[CR]REVISION 2:[CR]* Build date: 970702[CR]REVISION 3:[CR]* Build date: 970707[CR]ADDITIONAL NOTES: [CR]The Japanese version features an extra playable character (his character slot on the character select screen is replaced by the MSH vs. SF logo on all non-Japanese versions), Norimaro, a silly otaku (Japanese geek specializing in anime and manga) who is a huge Chun-Li fanboy as evidence by his reaction in seeing her before the match begins. While his true intentions of entering the competition is unknown, we can assume that it was to take pictures of Chun-Li and the many superheroes. He is voiced by the comedian Kinashi Noritake and created by Capcom as being a joke character like Dan (modeled after a Japanese comedian Noritake Kinashi). He was originally going to appear in non-Japanese versions of the game, but due to cultural differences and a reference to stealing Chun-Li's panties in his ending, he was cut out. However, his programming still exists in the ROM and he even has English dialogs in the game. He even has an ending with pictures, but his ending dialogs was cut out.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Play as Evil Sakura : At the character selection screen, highlight Hulk, hold Right for 5 sec. and press LP+HP or LK+HK.[CR]* Play as Evil Zanglief : At the character selection screen, highlight Blackheart, hold Left for 5 sec. and press LP+HP or LK+HK.[CR]* Play as Armored Spiderman : At the character selection screen, highlight Ryu, move down and hold Down for 5 sec. and press LP+HP or LK+HK.[CR]* Play as Mephisto : At the character selection screen, highlight Omega Red, hold Down for 5 sec. and press LP+HP or LK+HK.[CR]* Play as U.S. Agent : At the character selection screen, highlight Bison, hold Up for 5 sec. and press LP+HP or LK+HK.[CR]* Play as Shadow Charlie : At the character selection screen, highlight Dhalsim, hold Up for 5 sec. and press LP+HP or LK+HK.[CR]* Play as Gambit : Go to Dhalsim, hold Start, then move Left(x2), Down(x4), Right(x2), Up(x2), Right and press and hold LP+MK+HP together.[CR]* Play as Norimaro (Japanese version only) : Norimaro will show on the character select screen (bottom middle square) if the machine is set to Freeplay or 1 coin X credit. A setting of 2 coins or above and you will only see the Marvel Super Heroes Vs. Street Fighter logo in his square.[CR]* Beat 'em While They're Down : After defeating your opponents, press and hold Start. Normally your character wont be able to move after the round is over but by holding Start you will not only be able to move freely (until the next round starts) but you will be able to hit your opponent and even do a Super on them![CR]* Change Battle Order : When the screen shows which teams will be battling, press Punch or Kick three times to change the order of battle.[CR]* Double Team Spidermen : Start a new game and choose any character for your first choice followed by Spiderman as the second character. Deliberately lose, then continue and choose Silver Spiderman as your first character. The other Spiderman should be selected as your second character.[CR]* Fight Secret Characters (Japanese Version) : To fight a secret character in the Japanese version you must do a certain amount of team super finishes :[CR]Character #[CR]Evil Sakura 5[CR]Evil Zangief 6[CR]Shadow Charlie 7[CR]* Hyper Mode : At the vs. screen, hold LK+MP+HK.[CR]* Dan's Explosion : Pick Dan as your fighter and anyone else. At the Vs. screen hold LP until the word fight disappears. When the match begins Dan will fall into a small explosion.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]Note: also called the 'Capcom vs.' series.[CR]1. X-Men vs. Street Fighter [Green Board] (1996)[CR]2. Marvel Super Heroes vs. Street Fighter [Green Board] (1997)[CR]3. Marvel vs. Capcom - Clash of Super Heroes [Green Board] (1998)[CR]4. Marvel vs. Capcom 2 - New Age of Heroes (2000)[CR]5. Marvel vs. Capcom 3 (2011)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Planners : Atsushi Tomita, Nakano Tau! Naoi, Kanako Takami[CR]Scroll designers : Iwai, Konomi, Hisashi Sawada, Dear Akirakun 1997, May, Inoyan, Youko Fukumoto, Kisabon, Takashi Fujiwara, Hiroshi Yuugen, Chie Morisaki, Holly Genki?, Shinnosuke, Manga-Chop[CR]Music composers & arrange : Yuki Iwai, Yuko Kadota[CR]Sound director : Hiroaki Kondo (X68K) (cipher)[CR]Sound assistants : Hachi & Ise & lee, Moe.T (cipher)[CR]Recording director : Susan Hart[CR]Recording enginners : Paul Shubat, Dave Hatt[CR]Programmers : Motsu, Eternal Sailor, Kaw, Silver Kadontz, You![CR]Producer : Kenji Kataoka[CR]General producer : Noritaka Funamizu[CR]Executive producer : Yoshiki Okamoto[CR]* Voice Actors :[CR]Zangief : Wataru Takagi[CR]M. Bison : Tomomichi Nishimura[CR]Dhalsim : Yoshiharu Yamada[CR]Sakura Kasugano : Yuko Sasamoto[CR]Akuma : Tomomichi Nishimura[CR]Chun-Li : Yuko Miyamura[CR]Ken Masters : Iwanaga Tetsuya[CR]Ryu : Toshiyuki Morikawa[CR]Dan Hibiki : Osamu Hosoi[CR]Cyclops : Norman Spencer[CR]Captain America : Cathal J. Dodd[CR]Spider-Man : Patrick Chilvers[CR]Shuma-Gorath : Franck Perry[CR]Wolverine : Cathal J. Dodd[CR]The Incredible Hulk : Andrew Jackson[CR]Blackheart : Jaimz Woolvett[CR]Omega Red : Len Doncheff[CR]Norimaro : Noritake Kinashi[CR]Apocalypse : Lorne Kennedy[CR]Narrator : Tony Daniels[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles : [CR][JP] Sega Saturn (Oct.22, 1998) "Marvel Super Heroes vs. Street Fighter [4MRAM Doukori Ban] [Model T-1238G]" [CR][JP] Sega Saturn (Oct.22, 1998) "Marvel Super Heroes vs. Street Fighter [Model T-1239G]" [CR][JP] Sony PlayStation (Feb.25, 1999) "Marvel Super Heroes vs. Street Fighter EX Edition [Model SLPS-01915]"[CR]
