game.plot: Marvel Super Heroes vs. Street Fighter (c) 1997 Capcom.[CR]The second 'Capcom Vs.' series fighter, featuring 17 Marvel and Street Fighter characters teaming up to face the extremely cheap Mech-Akuma![CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 2.[CR]Control: 8-way joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 6 per player.[CR]= > [1] LP, [2] MP, [3] HP[CR]= > [4] LK, [5] MK, [6] HK[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Marvel Super Heroes vs. Street Fighter was released in June 1997 in the Japanese arcades. It was known as the 23th video game released on the CPS-II hardware.[CR]Known export releases:[CR]"Marvel Super Heroes vs. Street Fighter [Blue Board]"[CR]"Marvel Super Heroes vs. Street Fighter [Grey Board]"[CR]"Marvel Super Heroes vs. Street Fighter [Orange Board]"[CR]"Marvel Super Heroes vs. Street Fighter [Pink Board]"[CR]9 characters are coming from Marvel comic books-followed by their first appearance : [CR]Apocalypse (aka En Sabah Nur) - X-Factor #5 [CR]Blackheart - Daredevil #270 [CR]Captain America (aka Steve Rogers) - Captain America Comics #1 [CR]Cyclops (aka Scott Summers) - X-Men #1 [CR]Hulk (aka Robert Bruce Banner) - Incredible Hulk #1 [CR]Omega Red (aka Arkady Rossovich) - X-Men #4 [CR]Shuma-Gorath - Marvel Premiere #6 [CR]Spider-Man (aka Peter Parker) - Amazing Fantasy #15 [CR]Wolverine (aka James 'Logan' Howlett) - Incredible Hulk #180 [CR]9 other character come from several Street Fighter games : [CR]Akuma ('Gouki' in Japan) - "Super Street Fighter II X - Grand Master Challenge" in Japan; "Super Street Fighter II Turbo" in all other regions [CR]Chun-Li - "Street Fighter II - The World Warrior" [CR]Dan Hibiki - "Street Fighter Alpha - Warriors' Dreams" in North America and Europe; "Street Fighter Zero" in Japan, Southeast Asia, Brazil, and Hispanic regions [CR]Dhalsim - "Street Fighter II - The World Warrior" [CR]Ken Masters - "Street Fighter" [CR]Major Bison ('Vega' in Japan) - "Street Fighter II - The World Warrior" [CR]Ryu - "Street Fighter" [CR]Sakura Kasugano - "Street Fighter Alpha 2" in the United States, Canada, and Europe; "Street Fighter Zero 2" in Japan, Southeast Asia, Brazil, Oceania, and Hispanic regions[CR]Zangief - "Street Fighter II - The World Warrior" [CR]Charlie, Gambit, Rogue, and Rose appear in the background in the 'Showdown in the Park' stage. [CR]Blanka (of "Street Fighter" fame) can be seen within the background in the 'Death Valley' stage. [CR]Dan's ending is an obvious parody of the ending of the SNK game, "Art of Fighting". [CR]Sunburned (or Evil) Sakura has two separate endings (Japanese version): Kei chases Gouki and Sunburned Sakura after they teleport away [CR]1) Across the entire screen from right to left. [CR]2) Across half the screen before she trips, falls, and falls asleep. [CR]There are several cameos of Rockman in this game: [CR]1) In the mall stage, there's a cameo of a Rockman cut-out (perhaps someone in a Rockman suit). And in relation to Capcom celebrating Rockman's "10th Anniversary" in 1997, they put a banner saying '10th Anniversary: Rockman'. [CR]2) In one of Norimaro's super combos, he does a cosplay of Rockman. [CR]There is one rumored reason why Iron Man was not in this game. It is because Acclaim made an Iron Man game called "Iron Man and X-O Manowar in Heavy Metal" which was released for several consoles. game.name: Marvel Vs. Capcom: Clash of Super Heroes (Euro 980123)
game.description: Marvel Vs. Capcom: Clash of Super Heroes (Euro 980123)
game.title_clean: Marvel Vs. Capcom: Clash of Super Heroes
game.plot: Marvel vs. Capcom - Clash of Super Heroes (c) 1998 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]North American & European release. Game developed in Japan. For more information about the game itself, please see the original Japanese release entry; "Marvel vs. Capcom - Clash of Super Heroes [Green Board]".[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Blue Board [USA & Europe][CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Most people probably already know that some of the characters' names were changed in the export versions (e.g., Rockman was changed to Megaman, etc.). [CR]When they recorded the announcer's voice, she had to say both the original names and the 'Export' ones during the recording. But for some of the characters' names that were NOT changed, there were alternate pronunciations recorded.[CR]For example, when you select Chun-Li in the original Japanese version, the way the announcer pronounces 'Chun' rhymes with 'noon'. [CR]In the Export versions, the way she pronounces 'Chun' rhymes with 'fun'. There is also an unused alternate pronunciation of Zangief (which sounds like 'Zain-geef') that can be heard in the Sound Test. [CR]Megaman's 'Rock Upper' move in the original Japanese version is called 'Mega Upper' in the Export versions, simply because the name of the character is different in Japan and Worldwide.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Blue Board revisions : [CR]REVISION 1:[CR]* Build date: 971222[CR]* US release.[CR]REVISION 2:[CR]* Build date: 980112[CR]* EUROPE release.[CR]REVISION 3:[CR]* Build date: 980123[CR]* US & EUROPE releases.[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]Sega Dreamcast [US] (September 30, 1999) "Marvel vs. Capcom - Clash of Super Heroes [Model T-1202N]" : Re-released as Sega All Stars edition (2000)[CR]Sony PlayStation [US] (January 27, 2000) "Marvel vs. Capcom - Clash of Super Heroes [Model SLUS-01059]" [CR]Sony PlayStation [EU] (January 31, 2000) Marvel vs. Capcom - Clash of Super Heroes [Model SLES-02305]" [CR]Sega Dreamcast [EU] (June 23, 2000) "Marvel vs. Capcom - Clash of Super Heroes [Model T-7002D-61] [CR]Sony PlayStation 3 [PSN] [US] (September 25, 2012) "Marvel vs. Capcom Origins" [CR]Microsoft XBOX 360 [XBLA] [US] [EU] [AU] (September 26, 2012) "Marvel vs. Capcom Origins" [CR]Sony PlayStation 3 [PSN] [EU] (October 10, 2012) "Marvel vs. Capcom Origins"[CR]

game.plot: Marvel vs. Capcom - Clash of Super Heroes (c) 1998 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]Fifteen characters from all walks of the Marvel and Capcom lineups tag-battle each other including loads of special assist characters. Their only goal : beat the supreme and terrific Onslaught![CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 2.[CR]Control: 8-way joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 6 per player.[CR]= > [1] LP, [2] MP, [3] HP[CR]= > [4] LK, [5] MK, [6] HK[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]First revision is from December 1997, but most arcades didn't get the game until January 1998. It was known as the 28th video game released on the CPS-II hardware.[CR]The game was shown at the 1998 AOU Amusement Expo show, in Japan.[CR]Known export releases:[CR]"Marvel vs. Capcom - Clash of Super Heroes [Blue Board]"[CR]"Marvel vs. Capcom - Clash of Super Heroes [Grey Board]"[CR]"Marvel vs. Capcom - Clash of Super Heroes [Orange Board]"[CR]"Marvel vs. Capcom - Clash of Super Heroes [Pink Board]"[CR]The game was also re-edited in Japan as "Marvel vs. Capcom - Clash of Super Heroes [Black Board]".[CR]Here are the debut comics for the 21 Marvel characters including the Guest Characters (For those with alter-egos, they are also listed) : [CR]Captain America (aka Steve Rogers) - Captain America Comics #1 [CR]Carnage (aka Cletus Kasady) - Amazing Spider-Man #359 [CR]Colossus (aka Piotr Nikolaievitch Rasputin) - Giant-Size X-Men #1 [CR]Cyclops (aka Scott Summers) - X-Men #1 [CR]Gambit (aka Jean-Luc 'Remy' LeBeau) - Uncanny X-Men #266 [CR]Hulk (aka Robert Bruce Banner) - Incredible Hulk #1 [CR]Iceman (aka Robert 'Bobby' Drake) - Uncanny X-Men #1 [CR]Jubilee (aka Jubilation Lee) - Uncanny X-Men #244 [CR]Juggernaut (aka Cain Marko) - X-Men #12 [CR]Magneto (aka Erik 'Magnus' Lehnsherr) - X-Men #1 [CR]Onslaught - X-Men (Vol. 2) #53 [CR]Psylocke (aka Elizabeth 'Betsy' Braddock) - New Mutants Annual #2 [CR]Rogue - Avengers Annual #10 [CR]Sentinel - Uncanny X-Men #14 [CR]Spider-Man (aka Peter Parker) - Amazing Fantasy #15 [CR]Storm (aka Ororo Munroe) - Giant Size X-Men #1 [CR]Thor (aka Jake Olsen) - Journey Into Mystery #83 [CR]U.S. Agent (aka John F. 'Johnny' Walker) - Captain America #351 [CR]Venom (aka Edward 'Eddie' Brock) - Amazing Spider-Man #300 [CR]War Machine (aka James R. 'Rhodey' Rhodes) - Iron Man #281 [CR]Wolverine (aka James 'Logan' Howlett) - Incredible Hulk #180 [CR]Here are the debut games for the 19 Capcom characters including the Guest Characters : [CR]Anita - "Night Warriors - Darkstalkers' Revenge" ("Vampire Hunter - Darkstalkers' Revenge" in Japan) [CR]Arthur - "Ghosts'n Goblins" ("Makaimura" in Japan) [CR]Captain Commando - "Captain Commando" [CR]Chun-Li - "Street Fighter II - The World Warrior" [CR]Devilotte Do Dethsatan IX (aka Devilot) - "Cyberbots - Fullmetal Madness" [CR]Jin Saotome - "Cyberbots - Fullmetal Madness" [CR]Lou - "Three Wonders" ("Wonder 3" in Japan) [CR]Megaman (Rockman in Japan) - Megaman (Rockman in Japan) [CR]Michelle Heart - "Legendary Wings" ("Ares No Tsubasa - The Legendary Soldiers" in Japan) [CR]Morrigan Aensland - "Darkstalkers - The Night Warriors" ("Vampire - The Night Warriors" in Japan) [CR]Pure and Fur - "Capcom World 2 - Adventure Quiz" [CR]Roll - Megaman (Rockman in Japan) [CR]Ryu - "Street Fighter" [CR]Saki - "Quiz Nanairo Dreams - Nijiirochou no Kiseki" [CR]Shadow - "Marvel Super Heroes vs. Street Fighter" [CR]Strider Hiryu - "Strider" ("Strider Hiryu" in Japan) [CR]Ton-Pooh - "Strider" ("Strider Hiryu" in Japan) [CR]Unknown Soldier - "Forgotten Worlds" ("Lost Worlds" in Japan) [CR]Zangief - "Street Fighter II - The World Warrior" [CR]Strider's ending is a reference to that of the ending in his own game ("Strider") [CR]Jin's ending is a reference to Gawaine's ending in "Cyberbots - Fullmetal Madness" (but with Jin taking the place of Gawaine, Onslaught taking the place of the Final Weapon of Destruction, Jin's headband taking the place of Gawaine's sword and Ryu taking the place of Jin). [CR]Megaman's ending is a reference to what happens in his own games ("Mega Man - The Power Battle") when he beats a boss. [CR]Captain Commando's ending is a reference to the ending in his own game ("Captain Commando"). [CR]Rumors exist for the reason War Machine was in the roster instead of Iron Man (although Hyper-Armor War Machine in the game had similar moves with Iron Man). The most popular reason being that Capcom, at the time, did not have the rights to use the Iron Man character. [CR]The game background is mainly inspired by the famous comic saga called Onslaught, published in 1996. As in the comic books, Onslaught appears under his two main forms (after defeating the first one, he reveals its ultimate appearance). [CR]Shirley Burton holds the official record for this game with 1119300 points. [CR]Suleputer released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Marvel Vs. Capcom OST - CPCA-1005) on March 21, 1998. [CR]Michael Jackson used to own this game. It was sold at the official Michael Jackson Auction on April 24, 2009.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Green Board revisions : [CR]REVISION 1:[CR]* Build date: 980112[CR]REVISION 2:[CR]* Build date: 980123[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Play As Hyper-Armor War Machine : At the character selection screen, highlight Zanglief and press Left(x2), Down(x2), Right(x2), Down(x2), Left(x2), Up(x4), Right(x2), Left(x2), Down(x4), Right(x2), Up(x2), Left(x2), Down(x2), Right(x2), Down(x4). Hyper-Armor War Machine will appear above Zangief. Hyper Armor War Machine got the same moves as War Machine (with some little variations), can't jump very high, can't block attacks but can't be stopped during his attacks.[CR]* Play As Shadow Lady : At the character selection screen, highlight Morrigan and press Up, Right(x2), Down(x4), Left(x2), Up(x4), Right(x2), Left (x2), Down(x2), Right(x2), Down(x2), Left(x2), Up(x2), Right(x2), Up(x2), Left(x2), Down(x5). Shadow Lady will appear below Gambit. Her attacks came from several characters in the game.[CR]* Play As MSH Seinou Hulk (Marvel Super Heroes Ability Hulk) : At the character selection screen, highlight Chun Li and press Right(x2), Down(x2), Left(x2), Right(x2), Down(x2), Left(x2), Up(x4), Down(x2), Right(x2), Up(x2), Down(x4), Up(x4), Left, Up. MSH Seinou Hulk will appear above Ryu. His moves are very similar from the original Hulk.[CR]* Play As Lilith-Kaze Morrigan (Lilith-style Morrigan) : At the character selection screen, highlight Zanglief and press Left(x2), Down(x2), Right(x2), Up(x2), Down(x4), Left(x2), Up(x4), Right, Left, Down(x4), Right(x2), Up(x4), Left(x2), Down(x4), Right, Down. Lilith-Kaze Morrigan will appear below War Machine. She makes moves a little bit different from Morrigan ones.[CR]* Play As Roll-chan (-chan is a ''suffix for familiar 'female' person'') : At the character selection screen, highlight Zanglief and press Left(x2), Down(x2), Right(x2), Down(x2), Left(x2), Up, Right, Up(x2), Right(x2). Roll-chan will appear to the right of Megaman. Her moves are the same as Megaman.[CR]* Play As Carnage (looks like a bloody Venom) : At the character selection screen, higlight Chun Li and press Right, Down(x4), Left, Up(x4), Right(x2), Down(x2), Left(x2), Down(x2), Right(x2), Up(x4), Left(x2), Up. High-speed Venom will appear above Chun-Li. He got the same moves as Venom but can do them very quickly.[CR]* Change Character Lineup : Press all three Punch buttons at the 'vs.' screen to change the lineup (second chosen character is now first up). You can repeat this code again to reset the lineup.[CR]* Continue Attacking : Press Start immediately after winning the match to move almost everywhere and have the ability to continue hitting the defeated character, even with super moves.[CR]* Choose Your Helper : To obtain the helper of you choice, you must always hold down start and then the designated buttons, just before selecting your second character.[CR]Shadow - LP+MK+HP[CR]Sentinel - MP+MK+HP[CR]Storm - LP+LK+HP[CR]Thor - LK+MP[CR]Unknown Soldier - LP[CR]Pure and Fur - LK[CR]Anita - LP+MP+HP[CR]Lou - MP[CR]Rogue - LP+MP+HP+LK[CR]Colossus - LP+MP+MK[CR]Michelle Heart - LP+LK[CR]King Arthur - LP+MP[CR]Saki - HP[CR]Ton-Pooh - LP+HP[CR]Iceman - MP+MK[CR]Cyclops - LP+LK+MP[CR]Magneto - LK+HP[CR]U.S. Agent - MK+HP[CR]Psylock - MK[CR]Devilot - MP+HP[CR]Juggernaut - LP+MK[CR]* Dark Charlie-As Your Special Partner : Simultaneously press Light Punch, Medium Kick and Hard Punch after you choose your team.[CR]* Use Opponent's Helper : Defeat your opponent's helper in a single player game. Then, hold LK+MK+HK at the screen that displays the name of the character that won until the next match. If done correctly, your helper in the last match will be from your previous opponent's team.[CR]* Name Changes : Enter --- as a name to have the game change it to 'SIN'. Enter AAA as a name to have the game change it to 'CAP'. Enter MMM as a name to have the game change it to 'MOT'.[CR]* Fight Hidden Characters : In every case, you cannot lose a character. You can give up first attacks and have opponents join in, unlike what other sources tell you. A Super Finish is defined as either a Hyper Combo Finish, a Crossover Combination (or Variable Combination) Finish, or a Duo Team Attack (or Variable Cross) Finish.[CR]1) To fight the team of Orange Hulk and Wolverine, get 3 Super Finishes.[CR]2) To fight the team of Hyper-Armor War Machine and Captain America, get 5 Super Finishes, two of which must be Duo Team Attack Finishes.[CR]3) To fight the team of Carnage and Spider-Man, get 6 Super Finishes, four of which must be Duo Finishes and finish six rounds under a certain amount of time.[CR]4) To fight Lilith-Style Morrigan and Chun-Li, get 3 Super Finishes and drain your helper stocks in two matches.[CR]5) To fight Roll and Megaman, get 5 Super Finishes, 2 of which are Duo Finishes and drain your helper stocks in six matches.[CR]6) To fight Shadow Lady and Jin, get 6 Super Finishes, 4 of which are Duo finishes, drain your helper stocks in six matches and finish six matches under a certain amount of time.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]Note: also called the 'Capcom vs.' series.[CR]1. X-Men vs. Street Fighter [Green Board] (1996)[CR]2. Marvel Super Heroes vs. Street Fighter [Green Board] (1997)[CR]3. Marvel vs. Capcom - Clash of Super Heroes [Green Board] (1998)[CR]4. Marvel vs. Capcom 2 - New Age of Heroes (2000)[CR]5. Marvel vs. Capcom 3 (2011)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Planners : Atsushi Tomita, Dave Matumoto, Nakano Tau! Masahiro[CR]Original art works : Akira Yasuda (Akiman), Shoei, Sakomizu[CR]Object designers : Minobe Hiroaki, Akemi Kurihira, Fuji=Kazu, Sagata, G. Kamina, Miwa Sagaguchi, Kohichi Kikutanii, Masanori Kondo, Hiroshi Yoshioka, Shinya Miyamoto, Takep, Toshihiro Suzuki, Jon Narancha, Yamancha, Naony, Yuugen, Kanako Takami, Ino, Eripyon.N, Kimo Kimo[CR]Scroll designers : Konomi, Iwai, Sawatch, M. Nakagawa, M. Kitamura, Nissui, Kanno, Himago, Kazu T, Oonisi, Takapon, Kenichi Yamahashi, Stamp Rally[CR]Music Composers & Arrangers : Yuko K. Takehara, Masato Koda[CR]Sound director : Ryoji Yamamoto[CR]Recording director : Susan Hart[CR]Recording engineers : Paul Shubat, David Stinson[CR]Second engineers : Dave Hatt, Rick Pacholko[CR]Programmers : Motsu, Eternal Sailor, Kaw, You!, Silver Kadontz, Teruaki Hirokado (Bakunetsu Hirokado)[CR]Producer : Kenji Kataoka[CR]General producer : Noritaka Funamizu[CR]Executive producer : Yoshiki Okamoto[CR]* Voice Actors (Art Vision):[CR]Capcom heroes...[CR]Strider Hiryu : Fube Tomomi [CR]Mega Man, Roll : Fujino Kahoru [CR]Morrigan : Jinguji Yayoi[CR]Chun Li : Miyamura Yuko [CR]Ryu : Toshiyuki Morikawa[CR]Captain Commando : Nagasako Takashi [CR]Zangief : Takagi Wataru [CR]Jin : Ueda Yuji[CR]Marvel heroes...[CR]Jubilee : Alyson Court[CR]Hulk : Andrew Jackson[CR]Captain America, Wolverine : Cathal J. Dodd[CR]Onslaught : Maurice Wint[CR]Spider-Man : Patrick Chilvers[CR]Venom, Thor : Rod Wilson[CR]Gambit : Tony Daniels[CR]War Machine : Wayne Ward[CR]Narrator : Sally Cahill[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles : [CR]Sega Dreamcast [JP] (March 25, 1999) "Marvel vs. Capcom - Clash of Super Heroes [Model T-1202M]"[CR]Sony PlayStation [JP] (November 11, 1999) "Marvel vs. Capcom EX Edition [Model SLPS-02368]"[CR]

game.plot: Marvel vs. Capcom - Clash of Super Heroes (c) 1998 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]Japanese re-release. For more information about the game itself, please see the original Japanese release entry; "Marvel vs. Capcom - Clash of Super Heroes [Green Board]".[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Black Board [Japan][CR]This is the Single PCB release of Marvel Vs. Capcom, it has the Program ROM stored on SIMMs similar to CPS3. All ROM data (including the code) is identical to the regular Green Board just in different sized ROMs.[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Released in Japan only.[CR]

game.name: Marvel Vs. Capcom: Clash of Super Heroes (Euro 980112)
game.description: Marvel Vs. Capcom: Clash of Super Heroes (Euro 980112)
game.title_clean: Marvel Vs. Capcom: Clash of Super Heroes
game.plot: Marvel vs. Capcom - Clash of Super Heroes (c) 1998 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]North American & European release. Game developed in Japan. For more information about the game itself, please see the original Japanese release entry; "Marvel vs. Capcom - Clash of Super Heroes [Green Board]".[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Blue Board [USA & Europe][CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Most people probably already know that some of the characters' names were changed in the export versions (e.g., Rockman was changed to Megaman, etc.). [CR]When they recorded the announcer's voice, she had to say both the original names and the 'Export' ones during the recording. But for some of the characters' names that were NOT changed, there were alternate pronunciations recorded.[CR]For example, when you select Chun-Li in the original Japanese version, the way the announcer pronounces 'Chun' rhymes with 'noon'. [CR]In the Export versions, the way she pronounces 'Chun' rhymes with 'fun'. There is also an unused alternate pronunciation of Zangief (which sounds like 'Zain-geef') that can be heard in the Sound Test. [CR]Megaman's 'Rock Upper' move in the original Japanese version is called 'Mega Upper' in the Export versions, simply because the name of the character is different in Japan and Worldwide.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Blue Board revisions : [CR]REVISION 1:[CR]* Build date: 971222[CR]* US release.[CR]REVISION 2:[CR]* Build date: 980112[CR]* EUROPE release.[CR]REVISION 3:[CR]* Build date: 980123[CR]* US & EUROPE releases.[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]Sega Dreamcast [US] (September 30, 1999) "Marvel vs. Capcom - Clash of Super Heroes [Model T-1202N]" : Re-released as Sega All Stars edition (2000)[CR]Sony PlayStation [US] (January 27, 2000) "Marvel vs. Capcom - Clash of Super Heroes [Model SLUS-01059]" [CR]Sony PlayStation [EU] (January 31, 2000) Marvel vs. Capcom - Clash of Super Heroes [Model SLES-02305]" [CR]Sega Dreamcast [EU] (June 23, 2000) "Marvel vs. Capcom - Clash of Super Heroes [Model T-7002D-61] [CR]Sony PlayStation 3 [PSN] [US] (September 25, 2012) "Marvel vs. Capcom Origins" [CR]Microsoft XBOX 360 [XBLA] [US] [EU] [AU] (September 26, 2012) "Marvel vs. Capcom Origins" [CR]Sony PlayStation 3 [PSN] [EU] (October 10, 2012) "Marvel vs. Capcom Origins"[CR]

game.name: Pocket Fighter (Japan 970904)
game.plot: Pocket Fighter (c) 1997 Capcom.[CR]A superb, abstract and humorous fighting game featuring miniaturized renditions from several Capcom fighting games; including the legendary "Street Fighter" series, as well as "Darkstalkers" and the little-known "Red Earth".[CR]During a bout, players will be able to release coloured gems from successful attacks against their opponent, as well as from wooden chests that regularly appear. Collecting these gems will 'power-up' the player's character, giving them more powerful attacks. There are two bars and three sub-bars in the interface. The two main bars are the life bar and the super bar; the first indicates the player's health and the second their ability to throw super combos. The Super Bar itself can be filled up to nine levels, allowing players to execute more super combos. Each super combo has a level assigned to it, and it uses Super Bars depending on it.[CR]The 3 sub-bars show the level of 3 of each player's special moves. Each character has at least three special moves, as shown in the sub-bars, and each of these corresponds to a color. Some characters have one or two additional Special Moves that aren't affected by sub-bars. Each time a player shoots their opponent, gems pop out of him or her, and the attacker can take them to power up their own special moves according to the colors.[CR]There are 4 buttons : PUNCH, KICK, SPECIAL, and TAUNT. The Special button is a chargeable move that cannot be blocked and upon impact drops gems in the opponent's possession. More gems will be dropped depending on how much the player charges the attack. Holding Down, Forward or no direction at all when using the Special button will cause a specific gem color to drop from the enemy. Holding Back along with the Special button allows for a defense that is specific against the unblockable Special attacks. Other kinds of attacks do no damage when blocked, and unlike most 2-D fighting games, this includes special and super moves.[CR]Pocket Fighter also features Flash Combos in which a player can execute a combo by pressing the KICK or PUNCH button after they have hit their opponent using the PUNCH button for a total of 4 hits. Flash Combos will usually cause a player's fighter (except Ryu) to change into various costumes during the sequence, and perform a powerful attack in the end. This final hit is usually the hardest in the sequence to connect with. These costumes range from uniforms (such as traffic cops or schoolgirls), to swimsuits, and even cameos of other Capcom characters. For example, Chun-Li may turn into Jill Valentine from the Resident Evil series, while Felicia may turn into Mega Man or other Darkstalkers characters not playable in the game.[CR]The commands are also very easy compared to the Street Fighter series, thanks to SPECIAL button. By doing a motion (for example : qcf or hcf) and pressing the Special Button the fighter will launch his or her super combo.[CR]In addition to the usual punches, kicks and fireballs, each character has a couple of very abstract yet powerful 'special' attacks; which can range from the player producing a huge mallet (Ken), to standing on a podium and motioning a bicycle race through the opposing fighter (Chun Li).[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 2.[CR]Control: 8-way joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 3 per player.[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Pocket Fighter was released in September 1997 in the Japanese arcades. It was known as the 25th video game released for the CPS-II hardware.[CR]It was known outside Japan as Super Gem Fighter. Here is a list of known Export releases:[CR]"Super Gem Fighter - Mini Mix [Blue Board]"[CR]"Super Gem Fighter - Mini Mix [Grey Board]"[CR]"Super Gem Fighter - Mini Mix [Orange Board]"[CR]Many elements of the game come from "Super Puzzle Fighter 2 X" (basically gems and sounds).[CR]When you talk about cameos in fighting games, this game is way packed in this category! Here are some famous ones :[CR]Felicia : Can disguise herself as Megaman ("Mega Man - The Power Battle"), Rikuo / Sasquatch / Huitzil ("Darkstalkers - The Night Warriors"), Gamof & Rimgal ("Star Gladiator - Episode : I Final Crusade").[CR]Ibuki : Among her costumes are Rolento (Street Fighter Zero) and Chaka ("Jojo's Bizarre Adventure").[CR]Chun Li : She disguises herself as Jun May Williams ("Star Gladiator - Episode : I Final Crusade") & Jill Valentine ("Resident Evil").[CR]Gouki : He disguises himself as Leo ("Warzard").[CR]Also when performing his Shun Goku Satsu the old way (Punch, Punch, Towards, Kick, Special) he parodies Guy's Musou Renge Super Combo! ("Street Fighter Zero").[CR]Lord Raptor's graveyard makes a cameo in Gouki's ending![CR]Ken : Some disguises are a soccer player ("Capcom Sports Club") and Hol Horse ("Jojo's Bizarre Adventure").[CR]Tessa : In one of her costumes she disguises as Midler ("Jojo's Bizarre adventure").[CR]Also when she is low on energy and she blocks an attack she summons Pao ("Warzard") and uses her as a living shield!. :([CR]Morrigan : When performing her 'Darkness Ilussion' she summons her kid sister Lillith ("Vampire Savior - The Lord Of Vampire").[CR]Hauzer : The huge monster who appears on Ryu's ending is a boss character in "Warzard".[CR]Zanglief : His Leaping Bite super combo actually happens to be a parody of Birdie's Murder Chain super combo (However Zangief modifies the second part of the move by biting the opponent instead of slamming them on the ground as Birdie does!).[CR]The 'Capsy' soft drink (seen in Felicia's ending) is a parody of the Pepsi cola!. :)[CR]Additionally you can find lots of famous Capcom characters on the game's backgrounds, some of these are :[CR]Blanka, Dhalsim & his wife Sari, E. Honda, M. Bison, Cammy, Fei Long, Guile, Charlie, Vega, Dee Jay, Birdie, Gen, Sodom, Guy & Rolento (Street Fighter games).[CR]Rikuo & Riki, Victor, Bishamon, Jon Talbain, Hsien Ko (disguised as Santa Claus!), Sasquatch, Demitri, Jedah (as a woman!), Donovan & Anita, Baby Bonnie Hood, Lin lin (in the game's logo!) & Huitzil (Darkstalkers/Vampire Savior games).[CR]Chris Redfield (looking quite pale & angry!), the giant snake boss (that is trying to gobble up Rikuo!) & a few zombies! (Resident Evil games).[CR]Helena ("Street Fighter III - New Generation").[CR]Vampire Mistress in Red Dress (seen in Demitri's stage in "Vampire Savior - The Lord Of Vampire").[CR]Demitri's girlfriends (seen in his own stage as well as in his ending in Darkstalkers & Nightwarriors games).[CR]Jun May Williams & Rimgal ("Star Gladiator - Episode : I Final Crusade").[CR]Don Tacos ("Pang! 3").[CR]Pao & Leo ("Warzard").[CR]Son Gokuu ("Son Son").[CR]All of the death scenes that occur when a character is defeated are taken from famous old games, such as "Son Son"'s 'splash down the drain' or the famous "Final Fight" / "Double Dragon" 'blink-out'.[CR]The long-nosed karate character bearing a halo that appears with Dan during certain moves is Dan's father who was killed by Sagat. The long-nosed karate fighter is a hilarious parody of Mr. Karate, aka Takuma Sakazaki of the AOF/KOF series, who wore a long-nosed Tengu mask in the original "Art of Fighting" when disguised as the final boss.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Play as Gouki : at the character select screen, highlight Ryu and press Left.[CR]* Play as Dan : at the character select screen, highlight Ken and press Right.[CR]* Alternate ending : after beating the game, hold the 'Special' button before the credits appear to listen an alternate ending tune (Note : This trick works only in the Japanese version).[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Object designers : Ino, Nishimura Masaru, Yorio, Shigeyama, Ohsumi Tomohiko, Mayano, Kimikimo & Sema, Iwasaki, Ikusan Z, Kitasan, Rumichan, Tamura Chizuko[CR]Scroll designers : Takako Nakamura, Hiroki Ohnishi, Ojiji, Hirokazu Yonezuka, Yoichi Tanoue, R.Uno[CR]Character Designers : Edayan, I.Yamazaki, Jiwasaki, Sakomizu, Babatin, Uka-Bin[CR]Music composers & Arrangement : Isao Abe, Yuki Iwai, Setsuo Yamamoto[CR]Sound designers : Satoshi Ise, Ryoji, Hiroshi Ohno[CR]Programmers : Knight Rider Giu, Senor, Pon, Ittetsu, Shinchan (as 'Hyper Shinchan'), Minomiya, Cham Cho Choy, Hard.Yas (- Enemy -), Team Dirty Beret[CR]Game designers : Spp Iorya, Muraski Umagoyashi, Burns Fuji, Ohashi Mamoru, Team Sadogatake[CR]Producer : Takashi Sado[CR]General producer : Noritaka Funamizu[CR]Executive producer : Yoshiki Okamoto [CR]Voice Actors : [CR]Ibuki : Amano Yuri[CR]Felicia : Araki Kae[CR]Tessa : Ishii Naoko[CR]Ken Masters : Tetsuya Iwanaga[CR]Sakura Kasugano : Sasamoto Yuko[CR]Morrigan : Jinguji Yayoi[CR]Zangief : Takagi Wataru[CR]Akuma : Tomomichi Nishimura[CR]Hsien-Ko : Neya Michiko[CR]Ryu : Hoshi Souichiro[CR]Dan Hibiki : Hosoi Osamu[CR]Chun-Li : Miyamura Yuko[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles : [CR]Sony PlayStation [JP] (June 11, 1998) [Model SLPS-01360] [CR]Sony PlayStation [JP] (February 24, 2000) PS The Best edition [Model SLPS-91191]") [CR]Sega Saturn [JP] (July 9, 1998) [Model T-1230G] [CR]Bandai WonderSwan [JP] (April 6, 2000) [Model SWJ-BAN00A] [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [JP] (May 25, 2006) "Street Fighter Zero Fighter's Generation" [Model SLPM-66409] [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [JP] (November 15, 2007) "Street Fighter Zero Fighter's Generation [Best Price]" [Model SLPM-66854][CR]Sony PlayStation 3 [PSOne Classics] [JP] (April 13, 2011)[CR]

game.name: Powered Gear: Strategic Variant Armor Equipment (Japan 941024)
game.description: Powered Gear: Strategic Variant Armor Equipment (Japan 941024)
game.title_clean: Powered Gear: Strategic Variant Armor Equipment
game.plot: Powered Gear - Strategic Variant Armor Equipment (c) 1994 Capcom Company, Limited. [CR]An up-to-3-player side-scrolling beat'em up game where four selectable mechs and their respective pilots try to save Earth from battle with a sister planet's renegade army. Parts of destroyed mechs can be outfitted onto your mech to create interesting and deadly combinations.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 3.[CR]Control: 8-way joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 3 per player.[CR]=> [1] Arm attack, [2] Jump, [3] Weapon attack[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Powered Gear - Strategic Variant Armor Equipment was released on September 16, 1994 in Japan. It was known as the 7th CPS-II game.[CR]This game is known outside Japan as "Armored Warriors". Here is a list of known export releases:[CR]"Armored Warriors [Blue Board]"[CR]"Armored Warriors [Grey Board]"[CR]Sony Music Works released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Powered Gear Arcade Game Track - SRCL-3089) on December 1, 1994.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Green Board releases : [CR]REVISION 1 :[CR]* Build date : 940916[CR]REVISION 2 :[CR]* Build date : 941024[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Selecting Joint Parts : While the demo appears for joint machine, the player who gets the radio machine must enter the following keys...[CR]Beta-Cannon - Hold Up.[CR]Gamma-Battler - Hold Left or Right.[CR]Alpha-Fortress - Hold Down.[CR]* Selecting Parts : At the stage title screen, hold B+C (over 1 sec.) and then enter the following keys...[CR]Bomber - Leftup[CR]Death Drill - Up[CR]Missile - Rightup[CR]Laser blade - Left[CR]Force claw - Right[CR]Flame - Leftdown[CR]Chain spark - Down[CR]Laser - Rightdown[CR]Note : You can select both the arm and the sub weapon at the same time, but, if you enter codes for arm or sub weapon twice only the later code will work.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Powered Gear - Strategic Variant Armor Equipment [Green Board] (1994)[CR]2. Cyberbots - Fullmetal Madness (1995)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Planners: Kiyo, T.H.T.Fuji, Tuchihashi Bakabon[CR]Programmers: Y. Tunazaki Forever, Hero Hero, H. HASssssY, Hamachan, Dress[CR]Mechanical and object designers: Yochabare, E. Kuratani, H. Uemura, Naoki Fujisawa, Y. Maruno, H. Yoshino, You-Tenkozow (You.Ten Kozow), Igami, Nekokan, U.F.O, Naoki Fukuda, Bakky[CR]Art designers: Matsumoto, Y. Maruyama, M. Oshino, Takuji Mishima, Saru, Kohei Akiyama[CR]Sound composer: Takayuki Iwai (Anarchy Takapon)[CR]Sound designer: Tomuyuki Kawakami (T.K NY)[CR]Special adviser: Noritaka Funamizu (Poo), Shochan, Kenkn, Meshi, Furoboh[CR]Character designer: T.O.M[CR]AD designers: Sensei, Sakomizu[CR]Director: Yoshiki Okamoto (Kihaji Okamoto)[CR]

game.name: Progear no Arashi (Japan 010117)
game.plot: Progear no Arashi (c) 2001 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]In a time when the industrialization of the world had just begun, various inventions appeared and changed the life of the peaceful kingdom. One of them was a propeller that evolved from pure wind generation by using the created electricity to re-rotate it. It was called 'The Professional Gear', or just 'Progear'. This invention was the key to conquer the great wide open sky. Another discovery made the ancient dream of the immortal body come true. But it was affordable only by some wealthy elderly. They formed a new council called 'the Motorouin' and declared the current government as a corruptive and greedy establishment and that they want to correct it by a new educational system, in order to create a new race of man. So they built a military force to realize the first step of their plan, which was the takeover of the kingdom. The government decided to stop the aggression by putting it's own army in motion. It was a dreadful battle with many victims. But it was won by the Motorouin. This battle is mentioned in the books of history as 'The Punishment of the Sages'.[CR]A group of young pilots, actually children whose families were killed in that war, finally decided to fight back. They secretly developed a new powerful weapon which adults were not able to use. They called it 'Gun Flyer' and installed it in all of their planes. The Storm of Progear was about to begin![CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 2.[CR]Control: 8-way joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 2 per player.[CR]=> [1] Shot/Gunner shot, [2] Bomb[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Progear no Arashi was released in January 2001 in the Japanese arcades. It was known as the 35th game released on the CPS-II hardware.[CR]The title of this game translates from Japanese as 'Storm of Progear'.[CR]Developed by Cave, this is their first horizontal-scrolling shoot'em up.[CR]The game is known outisde Japan as just 'Progear'. Here is a list of known Export releases:[CR]"Progear [Blue Board]"[CR]"Progear [Grey Board]"[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* The game features 2 different planes with their own statistics :[CR]Gambler (Ring Reed) - blue plane : Weapon : Wide shot - Speed : Normal[CR]Militant (Bolt Voiyer) - green plane : Weapon : Focus shot - Speed : Fast[CR]After choosing a plane, the player will pick a gunner from the three following :[CR]Alpha gun flyer (Chain) : Explosion missile[CR]Beta gun flyer (Nail) : Cannon ball[CR]Gamma gun flyer (Rivet) : Homing missile[CR]* Extra Gun-flyer Formation forward : Press Button 1 and 2 the same time with pressing 2P start button when you decide a gunner to enable extra Gun-flyer formation.[CR]* Extra Gun-flyer Formation middle : Press Button 1 and 2 the same time when you decide a gunner to enable extra Gun-flyer formation.[CR]* Extra Gun-flyer Formation back : Press Button 1 or 2 the with pressing 2P start button when you decide a gunner to enable extra Gun-flyer formation.[CR]* Extra Character Costume : You can select an extra character costume on the character selection screen during holding Start Button.[CR]* To enable the 2nd loop of the game you need to use 2 bombs or less during the whole game.[CR]* The endings for each Pilot and Gunner combination changes depending on the Gunner's Data level at the end of the game.[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Developed by Cave.[CR]Producer : Kenichi Takano[CR]Director : Junya Inoue[CR]Chief Programmer : Tsuneki Ikeda[CR]Programmer : Satoshi Kohyama, Takashi Ichimura[CR]Designer : Akira Wakabayashi, Hiroyuki Tanaka, Fusayuki Watariguchi, Kengo Arai[CR]Sound Producer : Junya Inoue[CR]Music Composer : Yukinori Kikuchi[CR]Sound Effecter : Ryuichi Yabuki[CR]Special Assist : Toshiaki Tomizawa[CR]Character Voice : Mitsuo Furusawa, Junya Inoue, Aki Sibata, Midori Katou, Masayo Hirasaka[CR]Special Thanks : Yasushi Imai[CR]Character & Mechanic Design : Junya Inoue[CR]Produced by Capcom.[CR]Producer : Tatsuya Minami[CR]Support Capcom R&D Dept. #3 : Tomoshi Sadamoto[CR]

game.name: Puzz Loop 2 (Japan 010226)
game.plot: Puzz Loop 2 (c) 2001 Capcom Co.[CR][B]Gameplay:[/B] is exactly the same as its predecessor, with the player needing to deplete all the colored balls before they hit the center of the screen.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Board: Green (Japan)[CR]Players: Up to 2.[CR]Control: Spinner per player.[CR]Buttons: 4 per player.[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Developed by Mitchell Corp., Puzz Loop 2 was released in February 2001 in the Japanese arcades. It was known as the 36th video game released for the CPS2 hardware.[CR]The most popular new feature of Puzz Loop 2 was the two-player versus mode.[CR]The game forbids the initials 'SEX' on the high score table. If you try, it gets changed to 'MIT'.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Green Board revisions : [CR]REVISION 1:[CR]* Build date: 010205[CR]REVISION 2:[CR]* Build date: 010226[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. game.description: Quiz Nanairo Dreams: Nijiirochou no Kiseki (Japan 960826)
game.title_clean: Quiz Nanairo Dreams: Nijiirochou no Kiseki
game.plot: Quiz Nanairo Dreams - Nijiirochou no Kiseki (c) 1996 Capcom.[CR]A quiz game where your goal is to befriend a number of female and obtain the crystals which are used to defeat the Devil King.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Board: Green (Japan)[CR]Players: Up to 2.[CR]Buttons: 4 per player.[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Quiz Nanairo Dreams was released in August 1996 in the Japanese arcades. It was known as the 19th video game released for the CPS2 hardware.[CR]The title of this game translates from Japanese as 'Quiz Seven Color Dreams - Miracle of Rainbow Color Village'.[CR]One of Quiz Nanairo Dreams' very pretty girls (Saki) appears as an assist character in "Marvel vs. Capcom - Clash of Super Heroes".[CR]Victor Entertainment released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Quiz Nanairo Dreams Nijiirochou no Kiseki, Super Puzzle Fighter II X - VICL-40210) on 22/01/1997.[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Staff : Kadontz, Isao Abe, Setsuo Yamamoto, Masato Koda, Hiroaki Kondo (X68K), Moe-T, Saru, Hiro, Umazono[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles : [CR]Sony PlayStation [JP] (June 27, 1997) [Model SLPS-00875] [CR]Sega Saturn [JP] (June 27, 1997) [Model T-1220G][CR]

game.name: Ring of Destruction: Slammasters II (Euro 940902)
game.plot: Ring of Destruction - Slammasters II (c) 1994 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]European release. Game developed in Japan. For more information about the game itself, please see the original Japanese release entry; "Super Muscle Bomber - The International Blowout [Green Board]".[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Blue Board [Europe][CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]The names of several characters and the name of the game itself were changed in the Export releases. These changes re not reflected in the Tokyo stage, however. In this stage there is a jumbo monitor in the background which displays the original names of the characters who are fighting (in Japanese) and then displays the Super Muscle Bomber logo. Below is a list of the name changes.[CR](Japanese name - Export version name)[CR]Alexei Zalazof - Biff Slamkovich 'The Rocking Ruskie'[CR]Mysterious Budo - Great Oni[CR]El Stinger - El Stingray[CR]Sheep The Royal - Alexander 'The Grater'[CR]Kimala The Bouncer - Jumbo 'Flap' Jack[CR]Lucky Colt - Gunlock[CR]Titan The Great - Titanic Tim[CR]'Missing IQ' Gomes - King Rasta 'Mon'[CR]Astro - The Scorpion[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. game.name: Rockman 2: The Power Fighters (Japan 960708)
game.plot: Rockman 2 - The Power Fighters (c) 1996 Capcom.[CR]Building upon the previous game, you must battle Dr. Wily's evil robot criminals with the help of Megaman, Protoman, Bass & Duo. Features cool 2-D graphics and the same tried & true Mega Man controls. Pay attention to Dr. Light's advice and you may reach Dr. Wily's fortress and come out victorious![CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 2.[CR]Control: 8-way joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 3 per player.[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Rockman 2 - The Power Fighters was released in July 1996 in the Japanese arcades. It was known as the 17th video game released for the CPS-II hardware.[CR]The game is known outside Japan as "Mega Man 2 - The Power Fighters". Here is the list of known export releases:[CR]"Mega Man 2 - The Power Fighters [Blue Board]"[CR]"Mega Man 2 - The Power Fighters [Grey Board]"[CR]The music may seem familiar since the Japan-only Rockman Memories series uses the same music in some stages.[CR]The game forbids the initials 'SEX' on the high score table. If you try, it gets changed to 'HKD'.[CR]Victor Entertainment released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Rockman 2 - The Power Fighters : Capcom Game Soundtrack - VICL-2173) on September 21, 1996.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Execute a special move by pushing UP when releasing a charged attack.[CR]* Alternate ending sequence : Play the game with 2 characters instead of one. The ending sequence will change depending on the 2 characters you used.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Rockman - The Power battle [CP-S No. 32] (1995)[CR]2. Rockman 2 - The Power fighters [CP-S II No. 17] (1996)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Game designer : Ohko[CR]Programmers : Teruaki Hirokado, Pon, You![CR]Character designers : Shinji Sakashita, Satoru Yamashita, Shinua.M, "Ba-Ji Aasuki "Runta, Dja[CR]Scroll designers : Kisabon, Buchi, Koichi Takeda, Inoyan[CR]Sound effects : Moe.T[CR]Music : Yuki, Hideki Okugawa (Hideki Ok), Kadota Yuko, Masato Koda, Tatsuro Zuzuki (Tatsuro-), Syun Nishigaki, Setsuo Yamamoto[CR]Voice actors : Hekiru Shiina, Jin Yamanoi, Koji Tobe, Takashi Nagasako, Takko Ishimori[CR]Producer : Yoshimi Ohnishi[CR]General producer : Noritaka Funamizu[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles :[CR]SNK Neo-Geo Pocket Color [JP] (July 6, 2000; "Rockman - Battle & Fighters [Model NEOP00940]") [CR]Sony PS2 [JP] (August 5, 2004; "Rockman Power Battle Fighters [Model SLPM-62491]")[CR]

game.name: Street Fighter Alpha: Warriors' Dreams (Euro 950727)
game.plot: Street Fighter Alpha - Warriors' Dreams (c) 1995 Capcom USA.[CR]North American & European release. Game developed in Japan. For more information about the game itself, please see the original Japanese release entry; "Street Fighter Zero [Green Board]".[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Blue Board [USA & Europe][CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Street Fighter Alpha - Warriors' Dreams was released in June 1995 in North America and Europe.[CR]In these export versions, to maintain consistency with the previous games: [CR]* Nash is named Charlie.[CR]* Gouki is named Akuma.[CR]* Vega is named M. Bison.[CR]Also, the original Japanese version plays an instrumental version of 'Itoshisato Setsunasato Kokorotsuyosato' during Dramatic Battle mode, the song which is played in the animated SFII movie during the 2-on-1 battle between Ryu and Ken with Vega (M. Bison in the export versions). It was not only changed in the export versions, but also in the home ports.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Blue Board revisions:[CR]NOTE: US releases also cover Canada. [CR]REVISION 1:[CR]* Build date: 950605[CR]* EUROPE release. [CR]REVISION 2:[CR]* Build date: 950627[CR]* US and EUROPE releases.[CR]REVISION 3:[CR]* Build date: 950718[CR]* EUROPE release. [CR]REVISION 4:[CR]* Build date: 950727[CR]* EUROPE release.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Street Fighter (1987)[CR]2. Street Fighter II - The World Warrior [B-Board 90629B] (1991)[CR]3. Street Fighter II' - Champion Edition [B-Board 91634B-2] (1992)[CR]4. Street Fighter II' - Hyper Fighting [B-Board 91635B-2] (1992)[CR]5. Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [Green Board] (1993)[CR]6. Super Street Fighter II Turbo [Blue Board] (1994)[CR]7. Street Fighter Alpha - Warriors' Dreams [Blue Board] (1995)[CR]8. Street Fighter Alpha 2 [Blue Board] (1996)[CR]9. Street Fighter III - New Generation (1997)[CR]10. Street Fighter III - 2nd Impact : Giant Attack (1997)[CR]11. Street Fighter Alpha 3 [Blue Board] (1998)[CR]12. Street Fighter III - 3rd Strike : Fight For The Future (1999)[CR]13. Hyper Street Fighter II - The Anniversary Edition [Green Board] (2003)[CR]14. Street Fighter IV (2008)[CR]15. Super Street Fighter IV - Arcade Edition (2010)[CR]16. Ultra Street Fighter IV (2014)[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]Here is a list of ports released in North America, Europe, and Australia.[CR]* Consoles : [CR]Sony PlayStation [US] (December 21, 1995) "Street Fighter Alpha - Warriors' Dreams [Model SLUS-00197]" [CR]Sony PlayStation [EU] (May 1996) "Street Fighter Alpha - Warriors' Dreams [Model SLES-00199]" [CR]Sega Saturn [US] (1996) "Street Fighter Alpha - Warriors' Dreams [Model T-1206H]" [CR]Sega Saturn [EU] (January 25, 1996) "Street Fighter Alpha - Warriors' Dreams [Model T-7008H-50]" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [AU] (2006) "Street Fighter Alpha Anthology" by THQ[CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [US] (June 13, 2006) "Street Fighter Alpha Anthology [Model SLUS-21317]" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [EU] (July 7, 2006) "Street Fighter Alpha Anthology [Model SLES-54085]" [CR]* Handhelds : [CR]Nintendo Game Boy Color [EU] (1999) "Street Fighter Alpha - Warriors' Dreams [Model CGB-AFZP-EUR]" [CR]Nintendo Game Boy Color [US] (March 2000) "Street Fighter Alpha - Warriors' Dreams [Model CGB-AFZE-USA]" [CR]* Computers : [CR]PC [Windows 9x, CD-ROM] [US] (June 14, 2000) [CR]* Others : [CR]Mobile Phones [US] (April 2, 2005) "Street Fighter Alpha - Rapid Battle" [CR]Windows Mobile [US] (December 16, 2009)[CR]BlackBerry [US] (December 21, 2009) "Street Fighter Alpha [Model 5342]"[CR]

game.name: Street Fighter Alpha 2 (Euro 960229)
game.plot: Street Fighter Alpha 2 (c) 1996 Capcom.[CR]North American & European release. Game developed in Japan. For more information about the game itself, please see the original Japanese release entry; "Street Fighter Zero 2 [Green Board]".[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Blue Board [USA & Europe][CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Street Fighter Alpha 2 was released in February 1996 in Europe and in March 1996 in the USA.[CR]In these export releases: [CR]Nash is named Charlie.[CR]Vega is named M. Bison. [CR]Gouki is named Akuma.[CR]Shin Gouki is named Shin Akuma.[CR]Satsui no Hadou ni Mezameta Ryu is named Evil Ryu.[CR]In the original Japanese version, specific locations are displayed on the 'next stage' screen. All export versions just tell you which country the stage is in. Perhaps someone at Capcom USA was too lazy to translate the location-specific text (which is in Japanese) and just used the country name (which is in English). Below are the place names that were left out of the non-Japanese versions, translated into English... [CR](Character : Stage location) [CR]Ryu : Suzaku Castle, Japan [CR](Sagat vs.) Ryu : a big prairie, Australia [CR]Ken : San Francisco Bay, USA [CR]Chun-Li : Beijing, China [CR]Sagat : Ayuthaya Temple Ruins, Thailand [CR]Adon : Bank of the Chao Phraya River, Thailand [CR]Birdie : London Station Underground, England [CR]Charlie ('Nash' in Japan) : Detroit Highway, USA [CR]Guy : Metro City, USA [CR]Rose : Genova City Port, Italy [CR]Sodom : Arizona Desert, USA [CR]M. Bison ('Vega' in Japan) : Atop the VTOL, Brazil [CR](Charlie vs.) M. Bison : Guiana Highlands - Great Waterfalls, Venezuela [CR]Akuma ('Gouki' in Japan) : Gokuentou, Japan [CR]Dan : Temple Street, Hong Kong [CR]Dhalsim : Bank of the Ganges River, India [CR]Zangief : Bilsk Steelworks, USSR [CR]Gen : Shanghai, China [CR]Rolento : New York, USA [CR]Sakura : Setagaya-ku, 2-Choume, Tokyo, Japan[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Blue Board revisions : [CR]REVISION 1[CR]* Build date: 960229[CR]* EUROPE release[CR]REVISION 2[CR]* Build date: 960306[CR]* US release[CR]REVISION 3[CR]* Build date: 960430[CR]* US release[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Street Fighter (1987)[CR]2. Street Fighter II - The World Warrior [B-Board 90629B] (1991)[CR]3. Street Fighter II' - Champion Edition [B-Board 91634B-2] (1992)[CR]4. Street Fighter II' - Hyper Fighting [B-Board 91635B-2] (1992)[CR]5. Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [Green Board] (1993)[CR]6. Super Street Fighter II Turbo [Blue Board] (1994)[CR]7. Street Fighter Alpha - Warriors' Dreams [Blue Board] (1995)[CR]8. Street Fighter Alpha 2 [Blue Board] (1996)[CR]9. Street Fighter III - New Generation (1997)[CR]10. Street Fighter III - 2nd Impact : Giant Attack (1997)[CR]11. Street Fighter Alpha 3 [Blue Board] (1998)[CR]12. Street Fighter III - 3rd Strike : Fight For The Future (1999)[CR]13. Hyper Street Fighter II - The Anniversary Edition [Green Board] (2003)[CR]14. Street Fighter IV (2008)[CR]15. Super Street Fighter IV - Arcade Edition (2010)[CR]16. Ultra Street Fighter IV (2014)[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]These are ports released in North America, Europe, and Australia.[CR]* Consoles : [CR]Sega Saturn [EU] (1996) "Street Fighter Alpha 2 [Model T-7026H-50]" [CR]Sega Saturn [US] (September 30, 1996) "Street Fighter Alpha 2 [Model T-1213H]" [CR]Sony PlayStation [US] (September 30, 1996) "Street Fighter Alpha 2 [Model SLUS-00258]" [CR]Nintendo SNES [US] (November 1996) "Street Fighter Alpha 2 [Model SNS-AUZE-USA]" [CR]Sony PlayStation [EU] (December 1996) "Street Fighter Alpha 2 [Model SLES-00496]" [CR]Nintendo SNES [EU] (December 19, 1996) "Street Fighter Alpha 2 [Model SNSP-AUZP-EUR]" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [AU] (2006) "Street Fighter Alpha Anthology" by THQ[CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [US] (June 13, 2006) "Street Fighter Alpha Anthology [Model SLUS-21317]" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [EU] (July 7, 2006) "Street Fighter Alpha Anthology [Model SLES-54085]" [CR]* Computers : [CR]PC [MS Windows 9x, CD-ROM] [US] (November 1, 1997) [CR]PC [MS Windows 9x, CD-ROM] [EU] (1998)[CR]

game.name: Street Fighter Alpha 3 (Euro 980904)
game.plot: Street Fighter Alpha 3 (c) 1998 Capcom.[CR]North American & European release. Game developed in Japan. For more information about the game itself, see the original Japanese release entry; "Street Fighter Zero 3 [Green Board]".[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Blue Board [USA & Europe][CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Bam Margera of MTV's 'Jackass' and 'Viva La Bam' has owned this game before in his house. In the episode of 'Viva La Bam' called "Uncivil War", one of the arcade cabinets in Bam's laundry room running "Street Fighter Alpha 3" can be briefly shown for a second.[CR]In all Export releases : [CR]- Gouki is named Akuma.[CR]- M. Bison is named Balrog.[CR]- Nash is named Charlie. [CR]- Vega is named M. Bison.[CR]- Shin Vega is named Final Bison.[CR]- Balrog is named Vega.[CR]In Europe and the Western Hemisphere : [CR]- The Z-ISM is called A-ISM (representing Alpha).[CR]In the original Japanese version, specific locations were given for each stage (in Japanese) along with the name of the country (in English). Only the country name is given in all Export versions, with the more specific info being removed instead of being translated. Here is the list:[CR]Adon: Khmer Historic Ruins, Thailand [CR]Akuma ('Gouki' in Japan): Oni Fang Cave, Japan [CR]Balrog ('M. Bison' in Japan), M. Bison ('Vega' in Japan), Juni & Juli: Secret Point 48106 (since there was no country given for 'Secret Point 48106', its name is left completely blank in the Export versions)[CR]Birdie: Train Cemetery, England [CR]Blanka: Madeira River branch - swampland, Brazil [CR]Cammy: Mikonos Island, Greece [CR]Charlie ('Nash' in Japan): Frankfort Hangar, U.S.A. [CR]Chun-Li: Zhidan Plaza, China [CR]Cody: Metro City - City Police Detention Center, U.S.A. [CR]Dan: Hinode Park (translated from Japanese as 'Sunrise Park'), Japan [CR]Dhalsim: In front of Jaunpur Monument, India [CR]E. Honda: Higashikomagata - Katomi kontou, Japan [CR]Gen: Victoria Harbor, Hong Kong [CR]Guy: Under 22nd Street overhead, U.S.A. [CR]Karin, Sakura: Flower Shoutengai (translated from Japanese as Flower Shopping Street), Japan (NOTE: In Sakura's version, the sky is daylight; in Karin's version, night has fallen.) [CR]Ken: Hotel Masters, U.S.A. [CR]R. Mika: Sardine Beach Special Ring, Japan [CR]Rolento: New York Camouflaged Subway, U.S.A. [CR]Rose: Palazzo Mistero (Translated from Italian as Palace of Mystery), Italy [CR]Ryu: Genbugahara (translated from Japanese as 'Genbu Plain'), Japan [CR]Sagat: Nagpa Resting Shakyamuni the Buddha Statue, Thailand [CR]Sodom: Manhattan Building 49 F, U.S.A. [CR]Vega ('Balrog' in Japan): Requena Spiral Tower, Spain [CR]Zangief: Akademu Gorodowa blast furnace, U.S.S.R.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Blue Board revisions : [CR]REVISION 1:[CR]* Build date: 980629[CR]* US release[CR]REVISION 2:[CR]* Build date: 980904[CR]* US and EUROPE releases[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Street Fighter (1987)[CR]2. Street Fighter II - The World Warrior [B-Board 90629B] (1991)[CR]3. Street Fighter II' - Champion Edition [B-Board 91634B-2] (1992)[CR]4. Street Fighter II' - Hyper Fighting [B-Board 91635B-2] (1992)[CR]5. Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [Green Board] (1993)[CR]6. Super Street Fighter II Turbo [Blue Board] (1994)[CR]7. Street Fighter Alpha - Warriors' Dreams [Blue Board] (1995)[CR]8. Street Fighter Alpha 2 [Blue Board] (1996)[CR]9. Street Fighter III - New Generation (1997)[CR]10. Street Fighter III - 2nd Impact : Giant Attack (1997)[CR]11. Street Fighter Alpha 3 [Blue Board] (1998)[CR]12. Street Fighter III - 3rd Strike : Fight For The Future (1999)[CR]13. Hyper Street Fighter II - The Anniversary Edition [Green Board] (2003)[CR]14. Street Fighter IV (2008)[CR]15. Super Street Fighter IV - Arcade Edition (2010)[CR]16. Ultra Street Fighter IV (2014)[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]NOTE: These are only ports released in North America, Europe, and Australia. [CR]* Consoles :[CR]Sony PlayStation [US] (April 30, 1999) "Street Fighter Alpha 3 [Model SLUS-00821]" [CR]Sony PlayStation [EU] (2000) "Street Fighter Alpha 3 [Model SLES-01863]" [CR]Sony PlayStation [US] (2000) "Street Fighter Alpha 3 [Greatest Hits] [Model SLUS-00821GH]" [CR]Sega Dreamcast [US] (May 31, 2000) "Street Fighter Alpha 3 [Model T-1203N]" [CR]Sega Dreamcast [EU] (September 29, 2000) "Street Fighter Alpha 3 [Model T-7005D-50]" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [AU] (2006) "Street Fighter Alpha Anthology" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [US] (June 13, 2006) "Street Fighter Alpha Anthology [Model SLUS-21317]" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [EU] (July 7, 2006) "Street Fighter Alpha Anthology [Model SLES-54085]" [CR]* Handhelds : [CR]Nintendo Game Boy Advance [EU] (November 29, 2002) "Street Fighter Alpha 3 [Model AGB-AZUP-EUR]" [CR]Nintendo Game Boy Advance [US] (December 1, 2002) "Street Fighter Alpha 3 [Model AGB-AZUE-USA]" [CR]Sony PSP [AU] (2006) "Street Fighter Alpha 3 MAX" by THQ[CR]Sony PSP [US] (February 7, 2006) "Street Fighter Alpha 3 MAX [Model ULUS-10062]" [CR]Sony PSP [EU] (March 10, 2006) "Street Fighter Alpha 3 MAX [Model ULES-00235]" [CR]For further details, please see the "Street Fighter Zero 3 Upper" entry.[CR]

game.name: Street Fighter Alpha 3 (USA 980904)
game.plot: Street Fighter Alpha 3 (c) 1998 Capcom.[CR]North American & European release. Game developed in Japan. For more information about the game itself, see the original Japanese release entry; "Street Fighter Zero 3 [Green Board]".[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Blue Board [USA & Europe][CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Bam Margera of MTV's 'Jackass' and 'Viva La Bam' has owned this game before in his house. In the episode of 'Viva La Bam' called "Uncivil War", one of the arcade cabinets in Bam's laundry room running "Street Fighter Alpha 3" can be briefly shown for a second.[CR]In all Export releases : [CR]- Gouki is named Akuma.[CR]- M. Bison is named Balrog.[CR]- Nash is named Charlie. [CR]- Vega is named M. Bison.[CR]- Shin Vega is named Final Bison.[CR]- Balrog is named Vega.[CR]In Europe and the Western Hemisphere : [CR]- The Z-ISM is called A-ISM (representing Alpha).[CR]In the original Japanese version, specific locations were given for each stage (in Japanese) along with the name of the country (in English). Only the country name is given in all Export versions, with the more specific info being removed instead of being translated. Here is the list:[CR]Adon: Khmer Historic Ruins, Thailand [CR]Akuma ('Gouki' in Japan): Oni Fang Cave, Japan [CR]Balrog ('M. Bison' in Japan), M. Bison ('Vega' in Japan), Juni & Juli: Secret Point 48106 (since there was no country given for 'Secret Point 48106', its name is left completely blank in the Export versions)[CR]Birdie: Train Cemetery, England [CR]Blanka: Madeira River branch - swampland, Brazil [CR]Cammy: Mikonos Island, Greece [CR]Charlie ('Nash' in Japan): Frankfort Hangar, U.S.A. [CR]Chun-Li: Zhidan Plaza, China [CR]Cody: Metro City - City Police Detention Center, U.S.A. [CR]Dan: Hinode Park (translated from Japanese as 'Sunrise Park'), Japan [CR]Dhalsim: In front of Jaunpur Monument, India [CR]E. Honda: Higashikomagata - Katomi kontou, Japan [CR]Gen: Victoria Harbor, Hong Kong [CR]Guy: Under 22nd Street overhead, U.S.A. [CR]Karin, Sakura: Flower Shoutengai (translated from Japanese as Flower Shopping Street), Japan (NOTE: In Sakura's version, the sky is daylight; in Karin's version, night has fallen.) [CR]Ken: Hotel Masters, U.S.A. [CR]R. Mika: Sardine Beach Special Ring, Japan [CR]Rolento: New York Camouflaged Subway, U.S.A. [CR]Rose: Palazzo Mistero (Translated from Italian as Palace of Mystery), Italy [CR]Ryu: Genbugahara (translated from Japanese as 'Genbu Plain'), Japan [CR]Sagat: Nagpa Resting Shakyamuni the Buddha Statue, Thailand [CR]Sodom: Manhattan Building 49 F, U.S.A. [CR]Vega ('Balrog' in Japan): Requena Spiral Tower, Spain [CR]Zangief: Akademu Gorodowa blast furnace, U.S.S.R.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Blue Board revisions : [CR]REVISION 1:[CR]* Build date: 980629[CR]* US release[CR]REVISION 2:[CR]* Build date: 980904[CR]* US and EUROPE releases[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Street Fighter (1987)[CR]2. Street Fighter II - The World Warrior [B-Board 90629B] (1991)[CR]3. Street Fighter II' - Champion Edition [B-Board 91634B-2] (1992)[CR]4. Street Fighter II' - Hyper Fighting [B-Board 91635B-2] (1992)[CR]5. Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [Green Board] (1993)[CR]6. Super Street Fighter II Turbo [Blue Board] (1994)[CR]7. Street Fighter Alpha - Warriors' Dreams [Blue Board] (1995)[CR]8. Street Fighter Alpha 2 [Blue Board] (1996)[CR]9. Street Fighter III - New Generation (1997)[CR]10. Street Fighter III - 2nd Impact : Giant Attack (1997)[CR]11. Street Fighter Alpha 3 [Blue Board] (1998)[CR]12. Street Fighter III - 3rd Strike : Fight For The Future (1999)[CR]13. Hyper Street Fighter II - The Anniversary Edition [Green Board] (2003)[CR]14. Street Fighter IV (2008)[CR]15. Super Street Fighter IV - Arcade Edition (2010)[CR]16. Ultra Street Fighter IV (2014)[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]NOTE: These are only ports released in North America, Europe, and Australia. [CR]* Consoles :[CR]Sony PlayStation [US] (April 30, 1999) "Street Fighter Alpha 3 [Model SLUS-00821]" [CR]Sony PlayStation [EU] (2000) "Street Fighter Alpha 3 [Model SLES-01863]" [CR]Sony PlayStation [US] (2000) "Street Fighter Alpha 3 [Greatest Hits] [Model SLUS-00821GH]" [CR]Sega Dreamcast [US] (May 31, 2000) "Street Fighter Alpha 3 [Model T-1203N]" [CR]Sega Dreamcast [EU] (September 29, 2000) "Street Fighter Alpha 3 [Model T-7005D-50]" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [AU] (2006) "Street Fighter Alpha Anthology" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [US] (June 13, 2006) "Street Fighter Alpha Anthology [Model SLUS-21317]" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [EU] (July 7, 2006) "Street Fighter Alpha Anthology [Model SLES-54085]" [CR]* Handhelds : [CR]Nintendo Game Boy Advance [EU] (November 29, 2002) "Street Fighter Alpha 3 [Model AGB-AZUP-EUR]" [CR]Nintendo Game Boy Advance [US] (December 1, 2002) "Street Fighter Alpha 3 [Model AGB-AZUE-USA]" [CR]Sony PSP [AU] (2006) "Street Fighter Alpha 3 MAX" by THQ[CR]Sony PSP [US] (February 7, 2006) "Street Fighter Alpha 3 MAX [Model ULUS-10062]" [CR]Sony PSP [EU] (March 10, 2006) "Street Fighter Alpha 3 MAX [Model ULES-00235]" [CR]For further details, please see the "Street Fighter Zero 3 Upper" entry.[CR]

game.name: Street Fighter Alpha: Warriors' Dreams (Euro 950727 Phoenix Edition) (bootleg)
game.description: Street Fighter Alpha: Warriors' Dreams (Euro 950727 Phoenix Edition) (bootleg)
game.plot: Street Fighter Alpha - Warriors' Dreams (c) 1995 Capcom USA.[CR]North American & European release. Game developed in Japan. For more information about the game itself, please see the original Japanese release entry; "Street Fighter Zero [Green Board]".[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Blue Board [USA & Europe][CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Street Fighter Alpha - Warriors' Dreams was released in June 1995 in North America and Europe.[CR]In these export versions, to maintain consistency with the previous games: [CR]* Nash is named Charlie.[CR]* Gouki is named Akuma.[CR]* Vega is named M. Bison.[CR]Also, the original Japanese version plays an instrumental version of 'Itoshisato Setsunasato Kokorotsuyosato' during Dramatic Battle mode, the song which is played in the animated SFII movie during the 2-on-1 battle between Ryu and Ken with Vega (M. Bison in the export versions). It was not only changed in the export versions, but also in the home ports.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Blue Board revisions:[CR]NOTE: US releases also cover Canada. [CR]REVISION 1:[CR]* Build date: 950605[CR]* EUROPE release. [CR]REVISION 2:[CR]* Build date: 950627[CR]* US and EUROPE releases.[CR]REVISION 3:[CR]* Build date: 950718[CR]* EUROPE release. [CR]REVISION 4:[CR]* Build date: 950727[CR]* EUROPE release.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Street Fighter (1987)[CR]2. Street Fighter II - The World Warrior [B-Board 90629B] (1991)[CR]3. Street Fighter II' - Champion Edition [B-Board 91634B-2] (1992)[CR]4. Street Fighter II' - Hyper Fighting [B-Board 91635B-2] (1992)[CR]5. Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [Green Board] (1993)[CR]6. Super Street Fighter II Turbo [Blue Board] (1994)[CR]7. Street Fighter Alpha - Warriors' Dreams [Blue Board] (1995)[CR]8. Street Fighter Alpha 2 [Blue Board] (1996)[CR]9. Street Fighter III - New Generation (1997)[CR]10. Street Fighter III - 2nd Impact : Giant Attack (1997)[CR]11. Street Fighter Alpha 3 [Blue Board] (1998)[CR]12. Street Fighter III - 3rd Strike : Fight For The Future (1999)[CR]13. Hyper Street Fighter II - The Anniversary Edition [Green Board] (2003)[CR]14. Street Fighter IV (2008)[CR]15. Super Street Fighter IV - Arcade Edition (2010)[CR]16. Ultra Street Fighter IV (2014)[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]Here is a list of ports released in North America, Europe, and Australia.[CR]* Consoles : [CR]Sony PlayStation [US] (December 21, 1995) "Street Fighter Alpha - Warriors' Dreams [Model SLUS-00197]" [CR]Sony PlayStation [EU] (May 1996) "Street Fighter Alpha - Warriors' Dreams [Model SLES-00199]" [CR]Sega Saturn [US] (1996) "Street Fighter Alpha - Warriors' Dreams [Model T-1206H]" [CR]Sega Saturn [EU] (January 25, 1996) "Street Fighter Alpha - Warriors' Dreams [Model T-7008H-50]" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [AU] (2006) "Street Fighter Alpha Anthology" by THQ[CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [US] (June 13, 2006) "Street Fighter Alpha Anthology [Model SLUS-21317]" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [EU] (July 7, 2006) "Street Fighter Alpha Anthology [Model SLES-54085]" [CR]* Handhelds : [CR]Nintendo Game Boy Color [EU] (1999) "Street Fighter Alpha - Warriors' Dreams [Model CGB-AFZP-EUR]" [CR]Nintendo Game Boy Color [US] (March 2000) "Street Fighter Alpha - Warriors' Dreams [Model CGB-AFZE-USA]" [CR]* Computers : [CR]PC [Windows 9x, CD-ROM] [US] (June 14, 2000) [CR]* Others : [CR]Mobile Phones [US] (April 2, 2005) "Street Fighter Alpha - Rapid Battle" [CR]Windows Mobile [US] (December 16, 2009)[CR]BlackBerry [US] (December 21, 2009) "Street Fighter Alpha [Model 5342]"[CR]

game.name: Street Fighter Alpha: Warriors' Dreams (Euro 950605)
game.plot: Street Fighter Alpha - Warriors' Dreams (c) 1995 Capcom USA.[CR]North American & European release. Game developed in Japan. For more information about the game itself, please see the original Japanese release entry; "Street Fighter Zero [Green Board]".[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Blue Board [USA & Europe][CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Street Fighter Alpha - Warriors' Dreams was released in June 1995 in North America and Europe.[CR]In these export versions, to maintain consistency with the previous games: [CR]* Nash is named Charlie.[CR]* Gouki is named Akuma.[CR]* Vega is named M. Bison.[CR]Also, the original Japanese version plays an instrumental version of 'Itoshisato Setsunasato Kokorotsuyosato' during Dramatic Battle mode, the song which is played in the animated SFII movie during the 2-on-1 battle between Ryu and Ken with Vega (M. Bison in the export versions). It was not only changed in the export versions, but also in the home ports.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Blue Board revisions:[CR]NOTE: US releases also cover Canada. game.name: Street Fighter Zero 2 Alpha (Asia 960826)
game.plot: Street Fighter Zero 2 Alpha (c) 1996 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]An enhanced version of "Street Fighter Zero 2" released in arcades in Japan, southeast Asia, Brazil, and Hispanic regions. In North America and Europe, where its predecessor is known as "Street Fighter Alpha 2", this enhanced version appears on home consoles only.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Capcom Play System II hardware (CPS II)[CR]Game ID : CP-S II No. 18[CR]Main CPU : Motorola 68000 (@ 11.8 Mhz), Zilog Z80 (@ 8 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : Q-Sound (@ 4 Mhz)[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 6[CR]= > [1] LP, [2] MP, [3] HP[CR]= > [4] LK, [5] MK, [6] HK[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Street Fighter Zero 2 Alpha was released in August 1996. [CR]This game is very similar to it's predecessor, "Street Fighter Zero 2". It is slightly enhanced, giving some of the characters a new move or two. There are also additional game modes added, such as 'Dramatic Battle' (2 vs. 1), 'Shin Akuma Mode' and 'Survival'.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Here is the list of all versions : [CR]960805[CR]* Green Board [Japan] release.[CR]960813[CR]* Orange Board [South America] and Pink Board [Brazil] releases.[CR]960826[CR]* Grey Board [Asia] release.[CR]Unlike most other CPS2 titles, this one never had a Blue Board release in the arcades.[CR]ADDITIONAL NOTES : [CR]In the Green Board [Japan] release : [CR]* Charlie is called 'Nash' [CR]* M. Bison is called 'Vega' [CR]* Akuma is called 'Gouki' [CR]* Evil Ryu is called 'Satsui No Hadou Ni Mezameta Ryu' (translated as "Ryu in which the surge of the intent to kill has awakened")[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Two vs. One Battle : Hold LK+MK+HK and press Start at the start screen. [CR]* Fight Your Mid Boss : Win five rounds with a Super finish or Custom Combo finish, and don't lose a round before the sixth match.[CR]* Fight Shin Akuma : Hold MK+MP and press Start at the start screen. [CR]* Survival Battle : Hold LP+MP+HP and press Start at the start screen. [CR]* SFII' Versions Of Ryu, Ken, Sagat, M. Bison, Dhalsim, Zangief : Highlight the character and press Start. [CR]* Evil Ryu : Highlight Ryu and press Start twice. [CR]* SFII Costume Chun Li, SFII' Chun Li : Highlight Chun Li and press Start once for SFII costume Chun Li, twice for SFII' Chun Li. [CR]* Choose A Win Pose : Hold Start + any attack button after winning a round to determine your win pose.[CR]* Alternate Colors For Sakura : Highlight Sakura and press Start(x5). [CR]* Stage Select : Can only be done when a second player enters the game, therefore the message "Here Comes A New Challenger!!" must appear before returning to the select screen. On the select screen, highlight a character icon and hold Start for 2 seconds. Then choose your fighter. If you want the grassy Australia stage (the tall grass), hold Start on Sagat's icon for 2 seconds then select your character (do not let go of Start). To select the Venezuela stage (the waterfall), do the same steps you would do to select Australia, except hold Start on Charlie's icon instead of Sagat's.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Street Fighter (1987)[CR]2. Street Fighter II - The World Warrior [CP-S No. 14] (1991)[CR]3. Street Fighter II' - Champion Edition [CP-S No. 21] (1992)[CR]4. Street Fighter II' Turbo - Hyper Fighting [CP-S No. 24] (1992)[CR]5. Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [CP-S II No. 01] (1993)[CR]6. Super Street Fighter II X - Grand Master Challenge [CP-S II No. 03 Bis] (1994)[CR]7. Street Fighter Zero [CP-S II No. 11] (1995)[CR]8. Street Fighter Zero 2 [CP-S II No. 15] (1996)[CR]9. Street Fighter Zero 2 Alpha (1996)[CR]10. Street Fighter III - New Generation (1997)[CR]11. Street Fighter III - 2nd Impact : Giant Attack (1997)[CR]12. Street Fighter Zero 3 [CP-S II No. 29] (1998)[CR]13. Street Fighter III - 3rd Strike : Fight For The Future (1999)[CR]14. Hyper Street Fighter II - The Anniversary Edition [CP-S II No. 38] (2003)[CR]15. Street Fighter IV (2008)[CR]16. Super Street Fighter IV (2010)[CR]17. Ultra Street Fighter IV (2014)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Planner : Noritaka Funamizu (Poo), Neo_G, Kanetaka [CR]Programmers : Cham Cho Choy, Pon, Arikichi Kiyoko, Hard.Yas (-Becret Player-), Shinchan (as 'Hyper Shinchan'), Super Sailor (Birdie) [CR]Scroll designers : Konomi, Shibata Kayoko, Daisuke Nakagawa, Y. Kyo, Kisabon, Ohnishi, Tama, M. Chiezou, Kazu.T, Takapon, Yoichi Tanoue (Tanopu), Yamamoto.K, Megu Megu, Buchi, Hirokazu Yonezuka, Kanno, Inoyan, Shinnosuke, Hooly, Fukumoyan, Otsuki Teikoku [CR]Object designers : Eripyon.N (Eri_Eri), Ball Boy, Yu_Suke, Makoto Ishi, A. Iwasaki, Arahi Juf, Seigo Kawakami (Ushi), K.Takechan, Alien Pole, Kuri Geruge, Nasaaki, Masayo Tsujimoto, Shinya Miyamoto, Rumi-Yamaguchi, Chimorin Shogun, H.I = rassi, Takayuki Kosaka, Reiko Komatsu, Sagata [CR]Visual planner : Haruo Murata (as "Mucchi") [CR]Original artwork : Holyhomerun [CR]Sound & voices : Hiroaki Kondo (X68K) [CR]Music compose & Arrange : Syun Nishigaki, Setsuo Yamamoto, Tatsuro Zuzuki (Tatsuro-) [CR]All sound produced by Arcade Sound Team. [CR]Producer : Noritaka Funamizu (Poo) [CR]* Voice Actors : [CR]Ryu : Katashi Ishizuka [CR]Adon, Gen, Zangief, Birdie, Sodom : Wataru Takagi [CR]Chun Li : Yuko Miyamura [CR]Ken Masters, Guy : Tetsuya Iwanaga [CR]Dhalsim : Yoshiharu Yamada [CR]Sakura Kasugano : Yuko Sasamoto [CR]Rolento Schugerg : Jin Yamanoi [CR]Charlie : Toshiyuki Morikawa [CR]Rose : Yuko Miyamura [CR]Sagat : Miki Shinichiro [CR]Akuma, Major Bison : Tomomichi Nishimura [CR]Dan Hibiki : Osamu Hosoi[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]Home versions have three different titles : [CR][JP] "Street Fighter Zero 2 Dash" [CR][EU] "Street Fighter Alpha 2 Dash" [CR][US] "Street Fighter Alpha 2 Gold" [CR]* Consoles : [CR]Sega Saturn [EU] (1997) "Street Fighter Collection [Model T-7033H-50] [Disc 2]" [CR]Sega Saturn [JP] (September 18, 1997) "Street Fighter Collection [Model T-1223G] [Disc 2]" [CR]Sony PlayStation [JP] (October 23, 1997) "Street Fighter Collection [Model SLPS-00801]" [CR]Sega Saturn [US] (November 30, 1997) "Street Fighter Collection [Model T-1222H] [Disc 2]" [CR]Sony PlayStation [US] (November 30, 1997) "Street Fighter Collection [Model SLUS-00584]" [CR]Sony PlayStation [EU] (July 1998) "Street Fighter Collection [Model SLES-10998]" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [AU] (2006) "Street Fighter Alpha Anthology" by THQ[CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [JP] (May 25, 2006) "Street Fighter Zero - Fighters Generation [Model SLPS-66409]" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [US] (June 13, 2006) "Street Fighter Alpha Anthology [Model SLUS-21317]" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [EU] (July 7, 2006) "Street Fighter Alpha Anthology [Model SLES-54085]"[CR]
