game.name: Street Fighter Zero 2 Alpha (Hispanic 960813)
game.plot: Street Fighter Zero 2 Alpha (c) 1996 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]An enhanced version of "Street Fighter Zero 2" released in arcades in Japan, southeast Asia, Brazil, and Hispanic regions. In North America and Europe, where its predecessor is known as "Street Fighter Alpha 2", this enhanced version appears on home consoles only.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Capcom Play System II hardware (CPS II)[CR]Game ID : CP-S II No. 18[CR]Main CPU : Motorola 68000 (@ 11.8 Mhz), Zilog Z80 (@ 8 Mhz)[CR]Sound Chips : Q-Sound (@ 4 Mhz)[CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 6[CR]= > [1] LP, [2] MP, [3] HP[CR]= > [4] LK, [5] MK, [6] HK[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Street Fighter Zero 2 Alpha was released in August 1996. [CR]This game is very similar to it's predecessor, "Street Fighter Zero 2". It is slightly enhanced, giving some of the characters a new move or two. There are also additional game modes added, such as 'Dramatic Battle' (2 vs. 1), 'Shin Akuma Mode' and 'Survival'.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Here is the list of all versions : [CR]960805[CR]* Green Board [Japan] release.[CR]960813[CR]* Orange Board [South America] and Pink Board [Brazil] releases.[CR]960826[CR]* Grey Board [Asia] release.[CR]Unlike most other CPS2 titles, this one never had a Blue Board release in the arcades.[CR]ADDITIONAL NOTES : [CR]In the Green Board [Japan] release : [CR]* Charlie is called 'Nash' [CR]* M. Bison is called 'Vega' [CR]* Akuma is called 'Gouki' [CR]* Evil Ryu is called 'Satsui No Hadou Ni Mezameta Ryu' (translated as "Ryu in which the surge of the intent to kill has awakened")[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Two vs. One Battle : Hold LK+MK+HK and press Start at the start screen. [CR]* Fight Your Mid Boss : Win five rounds with a Super finish or Custom Combo finish, and don't lose a round before the sixth match.[CR]* Fight Shin Akuma : Hold MK+MP and press Start at the start screen. [CR]* Survival Battle : Hold LP+MP+HP and press Start at the start screen. [CR]* SFII' Versions Of Ryu, Ken, Sagat, M. Bison, Dhalsim, Zangief : Highlight the character and press Start. [CR]* Evil Ryu : Highlight Ryu and press Start twice. [CR]* SFII Costume Chun Li, SFII' Chun Li : Highlight Chun Li and press Start once for SFII costume Chun Li, twice for SFII' Chun Li. [CR]* Choose A Win Pose : Hold Start + any attack button after winning a round to determine your win pose.[CR]* Alternate Colors For Sakura : Highlight Sakura and press Start(x5). [CR]* Stage Select : Can only be done when a second player enters the game, therefore the message "Here Comes A New Challenger!!" must appear before returning to the select screen. On the select screen, highlight a character icon and hold Start for 2 seconds. Then choose your fighter. If you want the grassy Australia stage (the tall grass), hold Start on Sagat's icon for 2 seconds then select your character (do not let go of Start). To select the Venezuela stage (the waterfall), do the same steps you would do to select Australia, except hold Start on Charlie's icon instead of Sagat's.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Street Fighter (1987)[CR]2. Street Fighter II - The World Warrior [CP-S No. 14] (1991)[CR]3. Street Fighter II' - Champion Edition [CP-S No. 21] (1992)[CR]4. Street Fighter II' Turbo - Hyper Fighting [CP-S No. 24] (1992)[CR]5. Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [CP-S II No. 01] (1993)[CR]6. Super Street Fighter II X - Grand Master Challenge [CP-S II No. 03 Bis] (1994)[CR]7. Street Fighter Zero [CP-S II No. 11] (1995)[CR]8. Street Fighter Zero 2 [CP-S II No. 15] (1996)[CR]9. Street Fighter Zero 2 Alpha (1996)[CR]10. Street Fighter III - New Generation (1997)[CR]11. Street Fighter III - 2nd Impact : Giant Attack (1997)[CR]12. Street Fighter Zero 3 [CP-S II No. 29] (1998)[CR]13. Street Fighter III - 3rd Strike : Fight For The Future (1999)[CR]14. Hyper Street Fighter II - The Anniversary Edition [CP-S II No. 38] (2003)[CR]15. Street Fighter IV (2008)[CR]16. Super Street Fighter IV (2010)[CR]17. Ultra Street Fighter IV (2014)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Planner : Noritaka Funamizu (Poo), Neo_G, Kanetaka [CR]Programmers : Cham Cho Choy, Pon, Arikichi Kiyoko, Hard.Yas (-Becret Player-), Shinchan (as 'Hyper Shinchan'), Super Sailor (Birdie) [CR]Scroll designers : Konomi, Shibata Kayoko, Daisuke Nakagawa, Y. Kyo, Kisabon, Ohnishi, Tama, M. Chiezou, Kazu.T, Takapon, Yoichi Tanoue (Tanopu), Yamamoto.K, Megu Megu, Buchi, Hirokazu Yonezuka, Kanno, Inoyan, Shinnosuke, Hooly, Fukumoyan, Otsuki Teikoku [CR]Object designers : Eripyon.N (Eri_Eri), Ball Boy, Yu_Suke, Makoto Ishi, A. Iwasaki, Arahi Juf, Seigo Kawakami (Ushi), K.Takechan, Alien Pole, Kuri Geruge, Nasaaki, Masayo Tsujimoto, Shinya Miyamoto, Rumi-Yamaguchi, Chimorin Shogun, H.I = rassi, Takayuki Kosaka, Reiko Komatsu, Sagata [CR]Visual planner : Haruo Murata (as "Mucchi") [CR]Original artwork : Holyhomerun [CR]Sound & voices : Hiroaki Kondo (X68K) [CR]Music compose & Arrange : Syun Nishigaki, Setsuo Yamamoto, Tatsuro Zuzuki (Tatsuro-) [CR]All sound produced by Arcade Sound Team. [CR]Producer : Noritaka Funamizu (Poo) [CR]* Voice Actors : [CR]Ryu : Katashi Ishizuka [CR]Adon, Gen, Zangief, Birdie, Sodom : Wataru Takagi [CR]Chun Li : Yuko Miyamura [CR]Ken Masters, Guy : Tetsuya Iwanaga [CR]Dhalsim : Yoshiharu Yamada [CR]Sakura Kasugano : Yuko Sasamoto [CR]Rolento Schugerg : Jin Yamanoi [CR]Charlie : Toshiyuki Morikawa [CR]Rose : Yuko Miyamura [CR]Sagat : Miki Shinichiro [CR]Akuma, Major Bison : Tomomichi Nishimura [CR]Dan Hibiki : Osamu Hosoi[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]Home versions have three different titles : [CR][JP] "Street Fighter Zero 2 Dash" [CR][EU] "Street Fighter Alpha 2 Dash" [CR][US] "Street Fighter Alpha 2 Gold" [CR]* Consoles : [CR]Sega Saturn [EU] (1997) "Street Fighter Collection [Model T-7033H-50] [Disc 2]" [CR]Sega Saturn [JP] (September 18, 1997) "Street Fighter Collection [Model T-1223G] [Disc 2]" [CR]Sony PlayStation [JP] (October 23, 1997) "Street Fighter Collection [Model SLPS-00801]" [CR]Sega Saturn [US] (November 30, 1997) "Street Fighter Collection [Model T-1222H] [Disc 2]" [CR]Sony PlayStation [US] (November 30, 1997) "Street Fighter Collection [Model SLUS-00584]" [CR]Sony PlayStation [EU] (July 1998) "Street Fighter Collection [Model SLES-10998]" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [AU] (2006) "Street Fighter Alpha Anthology" by THQ[CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [JP] (May 25, 2006) "Street Fighter Zero - Fighters Generation [Model SLPS-66409]" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [US] (June 13, 2006) "Street Fighter Alpha Anthology [Model SLUS-21317]" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [EU] (July 7, 2006) "Street Fighter Alpha Anthology [Model SLES-54085]"[CR]

game.name: Street Fighter Zero 2 (Japan 960430)
game.plot: Street Fighter Zero 2 (c) 1996 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]Eighteen fighters go head-to-head this time around, featuring a few "Final Fight" alumni.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 2.[CR]Control: 8-way joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 6 per player.[CR]= > [1] LP, [2] MP, [3] HP[CR]= > [4] LK, [5] MK, [6] HK[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Street Fighter Zero 2 was released in February 1996 in the Japanese arcades. It was known there as the 15th video game released for the CPS2 hardware.[CR]Known Export releases:[CR]"Street Fighter Alpha 2 [Blue Board]"[CR]"Street Fighter Zero 2 [Grey Board]"[CR]"Street Fighter Zero 2 [Orange Board]"[CR]"Street Fighter Zero 2 [Pink Board]"[CR]Guy, Rolento and Sodom are from Capcom's "Final Fight" - Guy as a selectable character, Sodom as the second boss, and Rolento as the fourth boss. Guy's and Rolento's music are taken from "Final Fight". [CR]In Guy's stage you will see many familiar faces from "Final Fight". There's Mike and Jessica Haggar, Cody, Poison, Andorre and a few other bosses in the background - most of the "Final Fight" characters that have gone on to other games are there. [CR]In Rose's battle location there are represented the 'gondole', the typical elements of another and more famous Italian sea-town, Venice. This is clearly wrong cultural knowledge by Capcom's programmers. [CR]Here is a list of cameos in Ken's Yacht stage : [CR]* Eliza (It's her birthday after all!) [CR]* Captain Commando & Sho [CR]* Strider Hiryu (wielding a teddy bear!) [CR]* Lynn Kurosawa (from Alien Vs Predator) [CR]* Morrigan, Felicia, Zabel Zarock ('Lord Raptor' outside Japan) & Lei-Lei ('Hsien-Ko' outside Japan) (these last two are pretty much alive in this cameo, unlike in the Vampire & Vampire Savior games!) :) [CR]* Michelle Heart (from "Ares no Tsubasa" as another waitress!) [CR]* A few thugs from "Final Fight" (working as waiters?!) [CR]Dan Hibiki, the pink-clad Shotokan fighter, was an attempt by Capcom to make fun of SNK fighting games. Ryo Sakazaki was thought to be so much like Ryu that Capcom had to make a statement. Dan is mainly a hybrid of Ryo Sakazaki and Robert Garcia from the "Art of Fighting" series. This is most evident in his appearance in which he has Robert Garcia's trademark pony tail and Ryo Sakazaki's black undershirt. His animations were heavily tailored to look like a take on the aforemetioned characters. Dan's father was killed by Sagat (This is the man who Sagat hits with a Tiger Uppercut during the Ryu vs. Sagat intro in "Street Fighter Alpha 3"), so Dan developed his own style of fighting called 'Saikyo-ryuu', which is Japanese for 'strongest style', a poke at the "Art of Fighting" 'Kyokugen' karate style ('Kyokugen" is Japanese for 'extreme'). Fei Long makes a guest appearance in Dan's stage. [CR]The sumo wrestler 'Fujinoyama' that Sodom challenges in his ending had so much of a resemblance to E. Honda that Capcom, for "Street Fighter Alpha 3", changed it to E. Honda. [CR]The Australian prairie stage where Sagat fights Ryu is based on the opening scene of the animated 'Street Fighter II Movie', in which Ryu and Sagat fight in a prairie during a thunderstorm. [CR]Victor Entertainment released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Street Fighter Zero 2 : Capcom Game Soundtrack - VIZL-24) on June 21, 1996.[CR]After the first release of SFZ2, an upgraded version of the game called "Street Fighter Zero 2 Alpha" was released in Japanese arcades in August 1996, and to home consoles in North America and Europe in 1997. It included some enhancements like new moves, a unique variation of Sakura, the survival mode, the dramatic battle and the player was able to fight with Zangief, Dhalsim and 'Satsui no Hadou Mezameta Ryu' (Evil Ryu).[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Green Board revisions:[CR]REVISION 1:[CR]* Buid date: 060227[CR]REVISION 2:[CR]* Buid date: 960430[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Alternate Costume Colors : Highlight a fighter at the character selection screen and press punch or kick for the two standard outfits (punch is the original color). For two alternative outfits press two punch or two kick buttons together. [CR]* Alternate Chun-Li Costumes : Hold Start and highlight Chun-Li at the character selection screen. After five seconds, press LP, MP, or HP for a blue costume (without trousers); press LP+MP+HP for a pink costume. [CR]* Play as Satsui no Hadou ni Mezameta Ryu (translated as 'Ryu in which the surge of the intent to kill has awakened'; known as 'Evil Ryu' in Export releases) : Highlight Ryu at the character selection screen, then press Start for one second. Then highlight Adon, Gouki, Adon, then return to Ryu. Then hold Start for one second, while holding start press any attack button. [CR]* Grass Stage : Select two-player mode. Hold Start at the character selection screen, then highlight Sagat for five seconds. Then highlight any character, release Start and press any attack button. [CR]* Waterfall Stage : Select two-player mode. Hold Start at the character selection screen, then highlight Vega for five seconds. Then highlight any character, release Start and press any attack button. [CR]* Sari in Every Stage : In Dhalsim's stage you may have noticed a girl who cheers for him. That is Sari, his wife. When you play as Dhalsim, its possible to make her appear on every fight by holding down LP+HK before the fight starts (You must do this at the beginning of every round). [CR]* Alternate Sodom Stage : An alternate version of Sodom's stage appears every 4096 matches. The artwork on his truck is different. The Japanese text is replaced with English and the man on the side of the trailer is now wearing sunglasses. This alternate version of the stage is the one used in "Street Fighter Zero 2 Alpha". [CR]* Fight against Shin Gouki : It only works with the character's first color (meaning the original color). Fight through the game without losing a single round. Get at least three perfect wins and three super special finishes. Shin Gouki appears as your last boss now.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Street Fighter (1987)[CR]2. Street Fighter II - The World Warrior [CP-S No. 14] (1991)[CR]3. Street Fighter II' - Champion Edition [CP-S No. 21] (1992)[CR]4. Street Fighter II' Turbo - Hyper Fighting [CP-S No. 24] (1992)[CR]5. Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [CP-S II No. 01] (1993)[CR]6. Super Street Fighter II X - Grand Master Challenge [CP-S II No. 03 Bis] (1994)[CR]7. Street Fighter Zero [CP-S II No. 11] (1995)[CR]8. Street Fighter Zero 2 [CP-S II No. 15] (1996)[CR]9. Street Fighter Zero 2 Alpha (1996)[CR]10. Street Fighter III - New Generation (1997)[CR]11. Street Fighter III - 2nd Impact : Giant Attack (1997)[CR]12. Street Fighter Zero 3 [CP-S II No. 29] (1998)[CR]13. Street Fighter III - 3rd Strike : Fight For The Future (1999)[CR]14. game.name: Street Fighter Zero 2 (Japan 960227 Phoenix Edition) (bootleg)
game.plot: Street Fighter Zero 2 (c) 1996 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]Eighteen fighters go head-to-head this time around, featuring a few "Final Fight" alumni.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 2.[CR]Control: 8-way joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 6 per player.[CR]= > [1] LP, [2] MP, [3] HP[CR]= > [4] LK, [5] MK, [6] HK[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Street Fighter Zero 2 was released in February 1996 in the Japanese arcades. It was known there as the 15th video game released for the CPS2 hardware.[CR]Known Export releases:[CR]"Street Fighter Alpha 2 [Blue Board]"[CR]"Street Fighter Zero 2 [Grey Board]"[CR]"Street Fighter Zero 2 [Orange Board]"[CR]"Street Fighter Zero 2 [Pink Board]"[CR]Guy, Rolento and Sodom are from Capcom's "Final Fight" - Guy as a selectable character, Sodom as the second boss, and Rolento as the fourth boss. Guy's and Rolento's music are taken from "Final Fight". [CR]In Guy's stage you will see many familiar faces from "Final Fight". There's Mike and Jessica Haggar, Cody, Poison, Andorre and a few other bosses in the background - most of the "Final Fight" characters that have gone on to other games are there. [CR]In Rose's battle location there are represented the 'gondole', the typical elements of another and more famous Italian sea-town, Venice. This is clearly wrong cultural knowledge by Capcom's programmers. [CR]Here is a list of cameos in Ken's Yacht stage : [CR]* Eliza (It's her birthday after all!) [CR]* Captain Commando & Sho [CR]* Strider Hiryu (wielding a teddy bear!) [CR]* Lynn Kurosawa (from Alien Vs Predator) [CR]* Morrigan, Felicia, Zabel Zarock ('Lord Raptor' outside Japan) & Lei-Lei ('Hsien-Ko' outside Japan) (these last two are pretty much alive in this cameo, unlike in the Vampire & Vampire Savior games!) :) [CR]* Michelle Heart (from "Ares no Tsubasa" as another waitress!) [CR]* A few thugs from "Final Fight" (working as waiters?!) [CR]Dan Hibiki, the pink-clad Shotokan fighter, was an attempt by Capcom to make fun of SNK fighting games. Ryo Sakazaki was thought to be so much like Ryu that Capcom had to make a statement. Dan is mainly a hybrid of Ryo Sakazaki and Robert Garcia from the "Art of Fighting" series. This is most evident in his appearance in which he has Robert Garcia's trademark pony tail and Ryo Sakazaki's black undershirt. His animations were heavily tailored to look like a take on the aforemetioned characters. Dan's father was killed by Sagat (This is the man who Sagat hits with a Tiger Uppercut during the Ryu vs. Sagat intro in "Street Fighter Alpha 3"), so Dan developed his own style of fighting called 'Saikyo-ryuu', which is Japanese for 'strongest style', a poke at the "Art of Fighting" 'Kyokugen' karate style ('Kyokugen" is Japanese for 'extreme'). Fei Long makes a guest appearance in Dan's stage. [CR]The sumo wrestler 'Fujinoyama' that Sodom challenges in his ending had so much of a resemblance to E. Honda that Capcom, for "Street Fighter Alpha 3", changed it to E. Honda. [CR]The Australian prairie stage where Sagat fights Ryu is based on the opening scene of the animated 'Street Fighter II Movie', in which Ryu and Sagat fight in a prairie during a thunderstorm. [CR]Victor Entertainment released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Street Fighter Zero 2 : Capcom Game Soundtrack - VIZL-24) on June 21, 1996.[CR]After the first release of SFZ2, an upgraded version of the game called "Street Fighter Zero 2 Alpha" was released in Japanese arcades in August 1996, and to home consoles in North America and Europe in 1997. It included some enhancements like new moves, a unique variation of Sakura, the survival mode, the dramatic battle and the player was able to fight with Zangief, Dhalsim and 'Satsui no Hadou Mezameta Ryu' (Evil Ryu).[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Green Board revisions:[CR]REVISION 1:[CR]* Buid date: 060227[CR]REVISION 2:[CR]* Buid date: 960430[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Alternate Costume Colors : Highlight a fighter at the character selection screen and press punch or kick for the two standard outfits (punch is the original color). For two alternative outfits press two punch or two kick buttons together. [CR]* Alternate Chun-Li Costumes : Hold Start and highlight Chun-Li at the character selection screen. After five seconds, press LP, MP, or HP for a blue costume (without trousers); press LP+MP+HP for a pink costume. [CR]* Play as Satsui no Hadou ni Mezameta Ryu (translated as 'Ryu in which the surge of the intent to kill has awakened'; known as 'Evil Ryu' in Export releases) : Highlight Ryu at the character selection screen, then press Start for one second. Then highlight Adon, Gouki, Adon, then return to Ryu. Then hold Start for one second, while holding start press any attack button. [CR]* Grass Stage : Select two-player mode. Hold Start at the character selection screen, then highlight Sagat for five seconds. Then highlight any character, release Start and press any attack button. [CR]* Waterfall Stage : Select two-player mode. Hold Start at the character selection screen, then highlight Vega for five seconds. Then highlight any character, release Start and press any attack button. [CR]* Sari in Every Stage : In Dhalsim's stage you may have noticed a girl who cheers for him. That is Sari, his wife. When you play as Dhalsim, its possible to make her appear on every fight by holding down LP+HK before the fight starts (You must do this at the beginning of every round). [CR]* Alternate Sodom Stage : An alternate version of Sodom's stage appears every 4096 matches. The artwork on his truck is different. The Japanese text is replaced with English and the man on the side of the trailer is now wearing sunglasses. This alternate version of the stage is the one used in "Street Fighter Zero 2 Alpha". [CR]* Fight against Shin Gouki : It only works with the character's first color (meaning the original color). Fight through the game without losing a single round. Get at least three perfect wins and three super special finishes. Shin Gouki appears as your last boss now.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Street Fighter (1987)[CR]2. Street Fighter II - The World Warrior [CP-S No. 14] (1991)[CR]3. Street Fighter II' - Champion Edition [CP-S No. 21] (1992)[CR]4. Street Fighter II' Turbo - Hyper Fighting [CP-S No. 24] (1992)[CR]5. Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [CP-S II No. 01] (1993)[CR]6. Super Street Fighter II X - Grand Master Challenge [CP-S II No. 03 Bis] (1994)[CR]7. Street Fighter Zero [CP-S II No. 11] (1995)[CR]8. Street Fighter Zero 2 [CP-S II No. 15] (1996)[CR]9. Street Fighter Zero 2 Alpha (1996)[CR]10. Street Fighter III - New Generation (1997)[CR]11. Street Fighter III - 2nd Impact : Giant Attack (1997)[CR]12. Street Fighter Zero 3 [CP-S II No. 29] (1998)[CR]13. Street Fighter III - 3rd Strike : Fight For The Future (1999)[CR]14. Hyper Street Fighter II - The Anniversary Edition [CP-S II No. 38] (2003)[CR]15. Street Fighter IV (2008)[CR]16. Super Street Fighter IV (2010)[CR]17. Ultra Street Fighter IV (2014)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Planner : Noritaka Funamizu (poo), Neo_G, Kanetaka[CR]Programmers : Cham Cho Choy, Pon, Arikichi Kiyoko, Hard.Yas (-Becret Player-), Shinchan (as 'Hyper Shinchan'), Super Sailor (Birdie)[CR]Scroll designers : Konomi, Shibata Kayoko, Daisuke Nakagawa, Y.Kyo, Kisabon, Ohnishi, Tama, M.Chiezou, Kazu.T, Takapon, Yoichi Tanoue (Tanopu), Yamamoto.K, Megu Megu, Buchi, Hirokazu Yonezuka, Kanno, Inoyan, Shinnosuke, Hooly, Fukumoyan, Otsuki Teikoku[CR]Object Designers : Eripyon.N (Eri-Eri), Ball Boy, Yu-Suke, Makoto Ishi, A. Iwasaki, Arahi Juf, Seigo Kawakami (Ushi), K.Takechan, Alien Pole, Kuri Geruge, Nasaaki, Masayo Tsujimoto, Shinya Miyamoto, Rumi-Yamaguchi, Chimorin Shogun, H.I.=rassi, Takayuki Kosaka, Reiko Komatsu, Sagata[CR]Visual planners : Mucchi (Harvo. M)[CR]Original artwork : Holyhomerun[CR]Sound & voice : Hiroaki Kondo (X68K)[CR]Music compose & arrange : Syun Nishigaki, Setsuo Yamamoto, Tatsuro Zuzuki (Tatsuro-)[CR]All sound produce by Arcade Sound team.[CR]Producer : Noritaka Funamizu (poo)[CR]* Voice Actors :[CR]Ryu : Katashi Ishizuka[CR]Adon, Gen, Zangief, Birdie, Sodom : Wataru Takagi[CR]Chun-Li : Yuko Miyamura[CR]Ken Masters, Guy : Tetsuya Iwanaga[CR]Dhalsim : Yoshiharu Yamada[CR]Sakura Kasugano : Yuko Sasamoto[CR]Rolento Schugerg : Jin Yamanoi[CR]Nash : Toshiyuki Morikawa[CR]Rose : Yuko Miyamura[CR]Sagat : Miki Shinichiro[CR]Gouki, Vega : Tomomichi Nishimura[CR]Dan Hibiki : Osamu Hosoi[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]These are Japanese ports only.[CR]* Consoles : [CR][JP] Sony PlayStation (Aug.9, 1996) "Street Fighter Zero 2 [Model SLPS-00415]" [CR][JP] Sega Saturn (Sep.14, 1996) "Street Fighter Zero 2 [Model T-1212G]" [CR][JP] Nintendo Super Famicom (Dec.20, 1996) "Street Fighter Zero 2 [Model SHVC-AUZJ-JPN]" [CR][JP] Sony PlayStation 2 (May 25, 2006) "Street Fighter Zero - Fighters Generation [Model SLPS-66409]" [CR]* Computers : [CR][JP] PC [MS Windows 9x, CD-ROM] (Mar.12, 1998) : Bundled with the original "Street Fighter Zero"[CR]

Street Fighter II - The World Warrior [CP-S No. 14] (1991)[CR]3. Street Fighter II' - Champion Edition [CP-S No. 21] (1992)[CR]4. Street Fighter II' Turbo - Hyper Fighting [CP-S No. 24] (1992)[CR]5. Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [CP-S II No. 01] (1993)[CR]6. Super Street Fighter II X - Grand Master Challenge [CP-S II No. 03 Bis] (1994)[CR]7. Street Fighter Zero [CP-S II No. 11] (1995)[CR]8. Street Fighter Zero 2 [CP-S II No. 15] (1996)[CR]9. Street Fighter Zero 2 Alpha (1996)[CR]10. Street Fighter III - New Generation (1997)[CR]11. Street Fighter III - 2nd Impact : Giant Attack (1997)[CR]12. Street Fighter Zero 3 [CP-S II No. 29] (1998)[CR]13. Street Fighter III - 3rd Strike : Fight For The Future (1999)[CR]14. Iwasaki, Arahi Juf, Seigo Kawakami (Ushi), K.Takechan, Alien Pole, Kuri Geruge, Nasaaki, Masayo Tsujimoto, Shinya Miyamoto, Rumi-Yamaguchi, Chimorin Shogun, H.I.=rassi, Takayuki Kosaka, Reiko Komatsu, Sagata[CR]Visual planners : Mucchi (Harvo. M)[CR]Original artwork : Holyhomerun[CR]Sound & voice : Hiroaki Kondo (X68K)[CR]Music compose & arrange : Syun Nishigaki, Setsuo Yamamoto, Tatsuro Zuzuki (Tatsuro-)[CR]All sound produce by Arcade Sound team.[CR]Producer : Noritaka Funamizu (poo)[CR]* Voice Actors :[CR]Ryu : Katashi Ishizuka[CR]Adon, Gen, Zangief, Birdie, Sodom : Wataru Takagi[CR]Chun-Li : Yuko Miyamura[CR]Ken Masters, Guy : Tetsuya Iwanaga[CR]Dhalsim : Yoshiharu Yamada[CR]Sakura Kasugano : Yuko Sasamoto[CR]Rolento Schugerg : Jin Yamanoi[CR]Nash : Toshiyuki Morikawa[CR]Rose : Yuko Miyamura[CR]Sagat : Miki Shinichiro[CR]Gouki, Vega : Tomomichi Nishimura[CR]Dan Hibiki : Osamu Hosoi[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]These are Japanese ports only.[CR]* Consoles : [CR][JP] Sony PlayStation (Aug.9, 1996) "Street Fighter Zero 2 [Model SLPS-00415]" [CR][JP] Sega Saturn (Sep.14, 1996) "Street Fighter Zero 2 [Model T-1212G]" [CR][JP] Nintendo Super Famicom (Dec.20, 1996) "Street Fighter Zero 2 [Model SHVC-AUZJ-JPN]" [CR][JP] Sony PlayStation 2 (May 25, 2006) "Street Fighter Zero - Fighters Generation [Model SLPS-66409]" [CR]* Computers : [CR][JP] PC [MS Windows 9x, CD-ROM] (Mar.12, 1998) : Bundled with the original "Street Fighter Zero"[CR]

game.name: Street Fighter Zero 3 (Japan 980904)
game.plot: Street Fighter Zero 3 (c) 1998 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]25 fighters mix it up to have a shot at Shin Vega in the height of his power! Featuring 3 fighting styles for each character.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 2.[CR]Control: 8-way joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 6 per player.[CR]= > [1] LP, [2] MP, [3] HP[CR]= > [4] LK, [5] MK, [6] HK[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Street Fighter Zero 3 was released in June 1998 in the Japananese arcades. It was known as the 29th video game released on the CPS2 hardware.[CR]Known export releases:[CR]"Street Fighter Alpha 3 [Blue Board]"[CR]"Street Fighter Zero 3 [Grey Board]"[CR]"Street Fighter Alpha 3 [Orange Board]"[CR]"Street Fighter Alpha 3 [Pink Board]"[CR]Guy, Cody, Sodom and Rolento are from Capcom's "Final Fight" - Guy and Cody as selectable characters, Sodom as the second boss and Rolento as the fourth boss in "Final Fight". "Final Fight" boss 'Edi E' makes appearances in some of Cody's finishing poses.[CR]The reason for Mike Haggar's (the third selectable character in "Final Fight") non-appearance in Street Fighter was that he was too similar to Zangief. Furthermore, it could be because during the "Street Fighter Zero" storyline, Mike Haggar was assumed to be the mayor of Metro City (a part of New York) at the time. [CR]In Guy's stage there is a group from "Final Fight" cheering Guy on. They consist of: Mike Haggar, Andorre Jr., Axl and poison. Also in the background against one of the buildings there is a advert for a Rockman Drink just under the Capcom Logo. [CR]Karin Kanzuki is the first Street Fighter to have originated from a comic book (actually, a manga). She first appeared in a girls' manga that had Sakura Kasugano as the main character. [CR]The three ISMs have some symbolic meaning : [CR]* X-ISM represents "Super Street Fighter II X - Grand Master Challenge". That is, this ISM matches closely to the gameplay style found therein. There are, however, a few differences between X-ISM in Zero 3 and Super Street Fighter II X, mainly because of the Zero 3 game engine. [CR]* Z-ISM represents Zero. That is, it is closest to the style of the previous Zero games. [CR]* V-ISM represents Variable, as in 'Variable Combination', meaning 'Custom Combo'. This merely represents how you can use your super bar. [CR]Even though "Super Street Fighter II X - Grand Master Challenge" is known as "Super Street Fighter II Turbo" outside Japan, X-ISM is still known as X-ISM in all export releases of Zero 3.[CR]Attack of the Vega Dolls: Each Vega doll is named after a month of the year in the language of their supposed origin. It is said that they wield different tools, but generally share the same style. It is said that they generally worked as a team. [CR]1) Enero (January) from Spain uses a microphone. [CR]2) Fevrier (February) from France uses a gun. [CR]3) Marz (March) from Germany uses a laptop and dyes her hair. Enero and Marz are the information and recon members of the team. [CR]4) Aprile (April) from Italy is the medical member of the team. At the beginning of SFA3, Aprile's brother had asked Rose to find her whereabouts. [CR]5) Satsuki (May) is Japanese and wields a sword. Some say Sakura was supposed to be kidnapped instead of Satsuki, but Sakura evaded capture. This belief is consistent with the fact that all 12 dolls (and Cammy) were 16 at the time of SFA3. [CR]6) Juni (June) is German and fights unarmed. [CR]7) Juli (July) is also German and also fights unarmed. Despite the claims of some sources, Juni and Juli are not related (none of the Bison dolls are). [CR]8) Santamu (August) is Vietnamese, but of African heritage. SANTAMU is the equivalent of Vietnamese's 8th month. However, the Vietnamese's spelling should be 'Thang Tam'. It's a compound word of 'month' & 'eight', obviously. She wields a spear and can also unleash a small monkey to attack for her. [CR]9) Xiayu (September) is Chinese and wields the nunchaku. [CR]10) Jianyu (October) is also Chinese and wields a staff. [CR]11) Noembelu (November) is Mexican and is a member of T. Hawk's tribe (thus T. Hawk was looking for her and not Juli as the story implied). She wields a pair of hatchets on ropes. [CR]12) Decapre (December) is Russian and her appearance is similar to that of Cammy. [CR]Cammy had tried to save the Vega dolls in her SFZ3 ending because, due to the extent of their brainwashing, they would have died with Vega otherwise. It is said that the inspiration of the Vega dolls was Yuka Minakawa's novels named collectively as 'Cammy History'. Before the fight, Cammy throws a red coat, this comes from Street Fighter 2 the Animated Movie. [CR]Various characters of the game make a cameo in a marvel comic-book of Deadpool, the Merc with a mouth, vol.1 number 8. They appear in the shadows like mercenaries of the infernal house, the place where Deadpool obtains his merc jobs. We can recognize Adon, Dhalsim and Akuma as shadows, Sagat appears drawn and coloured. There are two more fighters, one appears to be Cammy. The artist of this Deadpool issue is Ed McGuiness. [CR]In number 27 of Deadpool's comic, the author Joe Kelly, makes a homage to the Street Fighter series. In this comic Deadpool does a "Shoryuken" to Kitty Pride to make Wolverine attack him. [CR]Suleputer released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Street Fighter Zero 3 Original Soundtrack - CPCA-1012, 1013) on September 21, 1998.[CR]An upgraded version of SFZ3 appeared as "Street Fighter Zero 3 Upper" in 2001. Previously hidden characters M. Bison, Juni and Juli are playable from the start. In addition, past Street Fighter legends Guile, Dee Jay, Fei Long and T. Hawk are now playable as well. This brings the total count to 34 playable characters! [CR]An even further upgraded version of SFZ3, called "Street Fighter Zero 3 Double Upper" appeared for the Sony PSP in 2006, and adds Eagle (from the original Street Fighter), Yun (from SFIII), Maki (from the Super Famicom Final Fight 2) and newcomer Ingrid. This now brings the total count of playable characters to 38![CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Green Board revisions : [CR]REVISION 1:[CR]* Build date: 980629[CR]REVISION 2:[CR]* Build date: 980727[CR]REVISION 3:[CR]* Build date: 980904[CR]Revision 1 had two bugs involving Karin : First, she could do her Kanzuki-ryuu Kou'ou Ken super in X-ISM (which she shouldn't be able to do, as it was her second super). Second, Karin's normal throw in Mazi Mode could do 99% damage.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Title Color Chart : The color of the title screen denotes what secrets are currently available. After a few weeks of play, the title screen will change color, so in a few months after your SFZ3 machine has been installed, it should reach the final color (light blue). The explanation of the colors is shown below :[CR]Cream - (default color)[CR]Green - Classical Mode[CR]Red - M. Bison, Juni and Juli become playable[CR]Dark Blue - Mazi Mode[CR]Purple - Saikyou Mode[CR]Light Blue - Can select one of the three Battle Modes[CR]* Random Select : The Random Select squares are normally invisible. But, there are two for the first player and two for the second. The 1P squares are located in the upper-right corner of the diamond and the lower-right. The 2P squares are in the upper-left corner and the lower-left corners.[CR]* Hidden Characters : The three hidden charactes are M. Bison, the boxer and Juni and Juli, two prototype 'dolls' created by Vega's Shadowloo organization. Once the game's title screen has become the proper color (see 'Title Color Chart', above), their score listing will show up in the High Score listing and they become playable...[CR]1) To choose M. Bison, pause on Karin for five seconds, then move to any Random Select square, hold the Start button and press any button.[CR]2) To use Juli, pause on Karin for five seconds, then move to any Random Select square. If the square is on the left side of the screen, choose her by holding Left and pressing any button. If the square is on the right side, then hold Right and press any button instead.[CR]3) To use Juni, pause on Karin for five seconds, then move to any Random Select square. If the square is on the top of the screen, choose her by holding Up and pressing any button. If the square is on the bottom, then hold Down and press any button instead.[CR]* Hidden Modes Of Play : There are three secret modes that affect basic gameplay. Once the game's title screen has become the proper color (see 'Title Color Chart', above), you can select a hidden mode to use...[CR]1) To use Classical Mode, insert your coin, hold down HP+HK and press Start. You can release HP+HK once you're at the Player Select Screen. Then, pick your character. When you start the round your super power bar will be gone and you will have Street Fighter 2 moves.[CR]2) To use Mazi Mode, insert your coin, hold down MP+MK and press Start. You can release HP+HK once you're at the Player Select Screen. Then, pick your character.[CR]3) To use Saikyou Mode, insert your coin, hold down LP+LK and press Start. You can release HP+HK once you're at the Player Select Screen. Then, pick your character.[CR]* Hidden Battle Mode : Once the game's title screen has become the proper color (see 'Title Color Chart', above), you can select a hidden battle mode...[CR]1) Final battle mode : After picking your ISM, hold Start+LP+MK+HP. You'll fight Shin Vega for one battle only. It's just like the last battle; win and you get your ending, lose and you get the bad ending.[CR]2) Dramatic battle mode : Hold LK+MK+HK, then press Start. Keep holding those buttons at Player Select Screen for a moment. You'll fight a 2 on 1 battle for 6 rounds, in which you face two CPU-controlled opponents.[CR]3) Survival mode : Insert your coin(s), hold LP+MP+HP and press Start. Keep holding those buttons at Player Select Screen. You'll get to fight all 27 characters in continuous one-round battles.[CR]* Secret Messages (this trick only works on Japanese SFZ3 machines) : After winning a battle, press and hold Start as well as any other button. Between battles, a message will appear on the screen, depending on the button you're holding.[CR]* Sari In Every Stage : In Dhalsim's stage you may have noticed a girl who cheers for him. That is Sari, his wife. When you play as Dhalsim, its possible to make her appear on every fight by holding down LP+HK before the fight starts (you must do this at the beginning of every round).[CR]* Alternate Sodom BGM : When fighting against Sodom (VS or CPU), you'll get to hear a different tune if it is on X-ISM mode. Apparently the tune is inspired on his boss tune in "Final Fight".[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Street Fighter (1987)[CR]2. Street Fighter II - The World Warrior [CP-S No. 14] (1991)[CR]3. Street Fighter II' - Champion Edition [CP-S No. 21] (1992)[CR]4. Street Fighter II' Turbo - Hyper Fighting [CP-S No. 24] (1992)[CR]5. Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [CP-S II No. 01] (1993)[CR]6. Super Street Fighter II X - Grand Master Challenge [CP-S II No. 03 Bis] (1994)[CR]7. Street Fighter Zero [CP-S II No. 11] (1995)[CR]8. Street Fighter Zero 2 [CP-S II No. 15] (1996)[CR]9. Street Fighter Zero 2 Alpha (1996)[CR]10. Street Fighter III - New Generation (1997)[CR]11. Street Fighter III - 2nd Impact : Giant Attack (1997)[CR]12. Street Fighter Zero 3 [CP-S II No. 29] (1998)[CR]13. Street Fighter III - 3rd Strike : Fight For The Future (1999)[CR]14. Hyper Street Fighter II - The Anniversary Edition [CP-S II No. 38] (2003)[CR]15. Street Fighter IV (2008)[CR]16. Super Street Fighter IV (2010)[CR]17. Ultra Street Fighter IV (2014)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Planner : Noritaka Funamizu[CR]Directors : Maoto Ohta, Mamoru, Buruma, Ohko Zero05[CR]Visual planner : Haruo Murata[CR]Programmers : Cham Cho Choy, Hard.Yas (~?-ISM~), Pon, Shinchan (as 'Hyper Shinchan'), 24 ~Nishi~, Minomi, Reiko Toh, Sen?Knight Rider Giu, Ittetsu[CR]Character designers : Akira Yasuda (Akiman), Osusi[CR]Title designer : Shoei[CR]Object designers : Eripyon.N (Eri-N), Fujihara, Mizuho, Takemoto, Hitoshi Igarashi, Mizupyon, Kimo Kimo (Jinzin), Ball boy, Yuesuke, D-Kurita, A. Iwasaki, Kaname, Fuzii & Peliko, Chimorin Shogun, Sagata, Ikusan Z, Kitasan, You-Ten Nakano, Tomohiro Ohsumi, Hiro, Rumichan, Reiko Komatsu, Kozuchi Tamura, Youichi Matsuo, Makoto Ishii[CR]Scroll designers : Asae Nisituji-Ba, S. Mukai (Jijii), Hirokazu Yonezuka, Kohama Ake&kuro, Yoichi Tanoue (Tanopu), Ryo Uno, Yoko.Fukumoto, Takako Nakamura, Kazu.T, A. Ohnishi, N. Niiyama, C. Iwai, Sawatch, K. Yamahashi, H. Yamahashi, Hiroki Ohnishi[CR]Main music composer : Takayuki Iwai (Anarchy Takapon)[CR]Sub music composer : Yuki Iwai, Isao Abe, Hideki Okugawa, Tetsuya Shibata[CR]Sound direction : Hiroaki Kondo (X68K)[CR]Sound designers : Moe.T, Satoshi Ise[CR]Test players : Nuki, M.P Oni-Suzuki, Skill Smith-Bug, Skill Smith-TTK, M. Kunishige, Miura.F.Katsusuke, Tomita Yoshihiro, Murata Akimori[CR]Market producer : Kouji Nakajima[CR]General producers : Noritaka Funamizu, Yoshiki Okamoto[CR]* Voice Actors :[CR]Ryu : Toshiyuki Morikawa[CR]Edmund Honda : Masashi Sugahara[CR]Cody : Koichi Yamadera[CR]Karin Kanzuki : Miho Yamada[CR]Balrog, Blanka : Yuji Ueda[CR]Ken Masters : Tetsuya Iwanaga[CR]Dhalsim : Yoshiharu Yamada[CR]Sodom, Zangief, Adon, Gen, Birdie : Wataru Takagi[CR]Cammy, Juli, Juni : Akiko Koumoto[CR]Rolento Schugerg : Jin Yamanoi[CR]Sakura Kasugano : Yuko Sasamoto[CR]Rose : Neya Michiko[CR]Dan Hibiki : Osamu Hosoi[CR]Guy : Tetsuya Iwanaga[CR]Rainbow Mika Nanakawa : Junko Takeuchi[CR]Gouki, Vega : Tomomichi Nishimura[CR]Chun-Li : Yuko Miyamura[CR]Nash : Toshiyuki Morikawa[CR]Sagat : Miki Shinichiro[CR]Mike Bison : Koichi Yamadera[CR]Narrator : Greg Irwin[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]NOTE: These are ports released in Japan only.[CR]* Consoles : [CR][JP] Sony PlayStation (Dec.23, 1998) "Street Fighter Zero [Model SLPS-01777]" [CR][JP] Sega Dreamcast (July 8, 1999) "Street Fighter Zero 3 - Saikyooryuu Doujou [Model T-1203M]" [CR][JP] Sega Saturn (Aug.6, 1999) "Street Fighter Zero 3 [Model T-1247G]" [CR][JP] Sony PlayStation 2 (May 25, 2006) "Street Fighter Zero - Fighter's Generation [Model SLPS-66409]" [CR]* Handhelds : [CR][JP] Nintendo Game Boy Advance (Sep.27, 2002) "Street Fighter Zero 3 Upper [Model AGB-AZUJ-JPN]" [CR][JP] Sony PSP (Jan.19, 2006) "Street Fighter Zero 3 Double Upper [Model ULJM-05082]" [CR]For further details on most of these ports, please see the "Street Fighter Zero 3 Upper" entry.[CR]

Once the game's title screen has become the proper color (see 'Title Color Chart', above), you can select a hidden mode to use...[CR]1) To use Classical Mode, insert your coin, hold down HP+HK and press Start. You can release HP+HK once you're at the Player Select Screen. Then, pick your character. When you start the round your super power bar will be gone and you will have Street Fighter 2 moves.[CR]2) To use Mazi Mode, insert your coin, hold down MP+MK and press Start. You can release HP+HK once you're at the Player Select Screen. Then, pick your character.[CR]3) To use Saikyou Mode, insert your coin, hold down LP+LK and press Start. You can release HP+HK once you're at the Player Select Screen. Then, pick your character.[CR]* Hidden Battle Mode : Once the game's title screen has become the proper color (see 'Title Color Chart', above), you can select a hidden battle mode...[CR]1) Final battle mode : After picking your ISM, hold Start+LP+MK+HP. You'll fight Shin Vega for one battle only. It's just like the last battle; win and you get your ending, lose and you get the bad ending.[CR]2) Dramatic battle mode : Hold LK+MK+HK, then press Start. Keep holding those buttons at Player Select Screen for a moment. You'll fight a 2 on 1 battle for 6 rounds, in which you face two CPU-controlled opponents.[CR]3) Survival mode : Insert your coin(s), hold LP+MP+HP and press Start. Keep holding those buttons at Player Select Screen. You'll get to fight all 27 characters in continuous one-round battles.[CR]* Secret Messages (this trick only works on Japanese SFZ3 machines) : After winning a battle, press and hold Start as well as any other button. Between battles, a message will appear on the screen, depending on the button you're holding.[CR]* Sari In Every Stage : In Dhalsim's stage you may have noticed a girl who cheers for him. That is Sari, his wife. When you play as Dhalsim, its possible to make her appear on every fight by holding down LP+HK before the fight starts (you must do this at the beginning of every round).[CR]* Alternate Sodom BGM : When fighting against Sodom (VS or CPU), you'll get to hear a different tune if it is on X-ISM mode. Apparently the tune is inspired on his boss tune in "Final Fight".[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Street Fighter (1987)[CR]2. Street Fighter II - The World Warrior [CP-S No. 14] (1991)[CR]3. Street Fighter II' - Champion Edition [CP-S No. 21] (1992)[CR]4. Street Fighter II' Turbo - Hyper Fighting [CP-S No. 24] (1992)[CR]5. Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [CP-S II No. 01] (1993)[CR]6. Super Street Fighter II X - Grand Master Challenge [CP-S II No. 03 Bis] (1994)[CR]7. Street Fighter Zero [CP-S II No. 11] (1995)[CR]8. Street Fighter Zero 2 [CP-S II No. 15] (1996)[CR]9. Street Fighter Zero 2 Alpha (1996)[CR]10. Street Fighter III - New Generation (1997)[CR]11. Street Fighter III - 2nd Impact : Giant Attack (1997)[CR]12. Street Fighter Zero 3 [CP-S II No. 29] (1998)[CR]13. Street Fighter III - 3rd Strike : Fight For The Future (1999)[CR]14. Hyper Street Fighter II - The Anniversary Edition [CP-S II No. 38] (2003)[CR]15. Street Fighter IV (2008)[CR]16. Super Street Fighter IV (2010)[CR]17. Kunishige, Miura.F.Katsusuke, Tomita Yoshihiro, Murata Akimori[CR]Market producer : Kouji Nakajima[CR]General producers : Noritaka Funamizu, Yoshiki Okamoto[CR]* Voice Actors :[CR]Ryu : Toshiyuki Morikawa[CR]Edmund Honda : Masashi Sugahara[CR]Cody : Koichi Yamadera[CR]Karin Kanzuki : Miho Yamada[CR]Balrog, Blanka : Yuji Ueda[CR]Ken Masters : Tetsuya Iwanaga[CR]Dhalsim : Yoshiharu Yamada[CR]Sodom, Zangief, Adon, Gen, Birdie : Wataru Takagi[CR]Cammy, Juli, Juni : Akiko Koumoto[CR]Rolento Schugerg : Jin Yamanoi[CR]Sakura Kasugano : Yuko Sasamoto[CR]Rose : Neya Michiko[CR]Dan Hibiki : Osamu Hosoi[CR]Guy : Tetsuya Iwanaga[CR]Rainbow Mika Nanakawa : Junko Takeuchi[CR]Gouki, Vega : Tomomichi Nishimura[CR]Chun-Li : Yuko Miyamura[CR]Nash : Toshiyuki Morikawa[CR]Sagat : Miki Shinichiro[CR]Mike Bison : Koichi Yamadera[CR]Narrator : Greg Irwin[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]NOTE: These are ports released in Japan only.[CR]* Consoles : [CR][JP] Sony PlayStation (Dec.23, 1998) "Street Fighter Zero [Model SLPS-01777]" [CR][JP] Sega Dreamcast (July 8, 1999) "Street Fighter Zero 3 - Saikyooryuu Doujou [Model T-1203M]" [CR][JP] Sega Saturn (Aug.6, 1999) "Street Fighter Zero 3 [Model T-1247G]" [CR][JP] Sony PlayStation 2 (May 25, 2006) "Street Fighter Zero - Fighter's Generation [Model SLPS-66409]" [CR]* Handhelds : [CR][JP] Nintendo Game Boy Advance (Sep.27, 2002) "Street Fighter Zero 3 Upper [Model AGB-AZUJ-JPN]" [CR][JP] Sony PSP (Jan.19, 2006) "Street Fighter Zero 3 Double Upper [Model ULJM-05082]" [CR]For further details on most of these ports, please see the "Street Fighter Zero 3 Upper" entry.[CR]

game.name: Street Fighter Zero 3 (Japan 980629)
game.plot: Street Fighter Zero 3 (c) 1998 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]25 fighters mix it up to have a shot at Shin Vega in the height of his power! Featuring 3 fighting styles for each character.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 2.[CR]Control: 8-way joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 6 per player.[CR]= > [1] LP, [2] MP, [3] HP[CR]= > [4] LK, [5] MK, [6] HK[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Street Fighter Zero 3 was released in June 1998 in the Japananese arcades. It was known as the 29th video game released on the CPS2 hardware.[CR]Known export releases:[CR]"Street Fighter Alpha 3 [Blue Board]"[CR]"Street Fighter Zero 3 [Grey Board]"[CR]"Street Fighter Alpha 3 [Orange Board]"[CR]"Street Fighter Alpha 3 [Pink Board]"[CR]Guy, Cody, Sodom and Rolento are from Capcom's "Final Fight" - Guy and Cody as selectable characters, Sodom as the second boss and Rolento as the fourth boss in "Final Fight". "Final Fight" boss 'Edi E' makes appearances in some of Cody's finishing poses.[CR]The reason for Mike Haggar's (the third selectable character in "Final Fight") non-appearance in Street Fighter was that he was too similar to Zangief. Furthermore, it could be because during the "Street Fighter Zero" storyline, Mike Haggar was assumed to be the mayor of Metro City (a part of New York) at the time. [CR]In Guy's stage there is a group from "Final Fight" cheering Guy on. They consist of: Mike Haggar, Andorre Jr., Axl and poison. Also in the background against one of the buildings there is a advert for a Rockman Drink just under the Capcom Logo. [CR]Karin Kanzuki is the first Street Fighter to have originated from a comic book (actually, a manga). She first appeared in a girls' manga that had Sakura Kasugano as the main character. [CR]The three ISMs have some symbolic meaning : [CR]* X-ISM represents "Super Street Fighter II X - Grand Master Challenge". That is, this ISM matches closely to the gameplay style found therein. There are, however, a few differences between X-ISM in Zero 3 and Super Street Fighter II X, mainly because of the Zero 3 game engine. [CR]* Z-ISM represents Zero. That is, it is closest to the style of the previous Zero games. [CR]* V-ISM represents Variable, as in 'Variable Combination', meaning 'Custom Combo'. This merely represents how you can use your super bar. [CR]Even though "Super Street Fighter II X - Grand Master Challenge" is known as "Super Street Fighter II Turbo" outside Japan, X-ISM is still known as X-ISM in all export releases of Zero 3.[CR]Attack of the Vega Dolls: Each Vega doll is named after a month of the year in the language of their supposed origin. It is said that they wield different tools, but generally share the same style. It is said that they generally worked as a team. [CR]1) Enero (January) from Spain uses a microphone. [CR]2) Fevrier (February) from France uses a gun. [CR]3) Marz (March) from Germany uses a laptop and dyes her hair. Enero and Marz are the information and recon members of the team. [CR]4) Aprile (April) from Italy is the medical member of the team. At the beginning of SFA3, Aprile's brother had asked Rose to find her whereabouts. [CR]5) Satsuki (May) is Japanese and wields a sword. Some say Sakura was supposed to be kidnapped instead of Satsuki, but Sakura evaded capture. This belief is consistent with the fact that all 12 dolls (and Cammy) were 16 at the time of SFA3. [CR]6) Juni (June) is German and fights unarmed. [CR]7) Juli (July) is also German and also fights unarmed. Despite the claims of some sources, Juni and Juli are not related (none of the Bison dolls are). [CR]8) Santamu (August) is Vietnamese, but of African heritage. SANTAMU is the equivalent of Vietnamese's 8th month. However, the Vietnamese's spelling should be 'Thang Tam'. It's a compound word of 'month' & 'eight', obviously. She wields a spear and can also unleash a small monkey to attack for her. [CR]9) Xiayu (September) is Chinese and wields the nunchaku. [CR]10) Jianyu (October) is also Chinese and wields a staff. [CR]11) Noembelu (November) is Mexican and is a member of T. Hawk's tribe (thus T. Hawk was looking for her and not Juli as the story implied). She wields a pair of hatchets on ropes. [CR]12) Decapre (December) is Russian and her appearance is similar to that of Cammy. [CR]Cammy had tried to save the Vega dolls in her SFZ3 ending because, due to the extent of their brainwashing, they would have died with Vega otherwise. It is said that the inspiration of the Vega dolls was Yuka Minakawa's novels named collectively as 'Cammy History'. Before the fight, Cammy throws a red coat, this comes from Street Fighter 2 the Animated Movie. [CR]Various characters of the game make a cameo in a marvel comic-book of Deadpool, the Merc with a mouth, vol.1 number 8. They appear in the shadows like mercenaries of the infernal house, the place where Deadpool obtains his merc jobs. We can recognize Adon, Dhalsim and Akuma as shadows, Sagat appears drawn and coloured. There are two more fighters, one appears to be Cammy. The artist of this Deadpool issue is Ed McGuiness. [CR]In number 27 of Deadpool's comic, the author Joe Kelly, makes a homage to the Street Fighter series. In this comic Deadpool does a "Shoryuken" to Kitty Pride to make Wolverine attack him. [CR]Suleputer released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Street Fighter Zero 3 Original Soundtrack - CPCA-1012, 1013) on September 21, 1998.[CR]An upgraded version of SFZ3 appeared as "Street Fighter Zero 3 Upper" in 2001. Previously hidden characters M. Bison, Juni and Juli are playable from the start. In addition, past Street Fighter legends Guile, Dee Jay, Fei Long and T. Hawk are now playable as well. This brings the total count to 34 playable characters! [CR]An even further upgraded version of SFZ3, called "Street Fighter Zero 3 Double Upper" appeared for the Sony PSP in 2006, and adds Eagle (from the original Street Fighter), Yun (from SFIII), Maki (from the Super Famicom Final Fight 2) and newcomer Ingrid. This now brings the total count of playable characters to 38![CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Green Board revisions : [CR]REVISION 1:[CR]* Build date: 980629[CR]REVISION 2:[CR]* Build date: 980727[CR]REVISION 3:[CR]* Build date: 980904[CR]Revision 1 had two bugs involving Karin : First, she could do her Kanzuki-ryuu Kou'ou Ken super in X-ISM (which she shouldn't be able to do, as it was her second super). Second, Karin's normal throw in Mazi Mode could do 99% damage.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Title Color Chart : The color of the title screen denotes what secrets are currently available. After a few weeks of play, the title screen will change color, so in a few months after your SFZ3 machine has been installed, it should reach the final color (light blue). The explanation of the colors is shown below :[CR]Cream - (default color)[CR]Green - Classical Mode[CR]Red - M. Bison, Juni and Juli become playable[CR]Dark Blue - Mazi Mode[CR]Purple - Saikyou Mode[CR]Light Blue - Can select one of the three Battle Modes[CR]* Random Select : The Random Select squares are normally invisible. But, there are two for the first player and two for the second. The 1P squares are located in the upper-right corner of the diamond and the lower-right. The 2P squares are in the upper-left corner and the lower-left corners.[CR]* Hidden Characters : The three hidden charactes are M. Bison, the boxer and Juni and Juli, two prototype 'dolls' created by Vega's Shadowloo organization. Once the game's title screen has become the proper color (see 'Title Color Chart', above), their score listing will show up in the High Score listing and they become playable...[CR]1) To choose M. Bison, pause on Karin for five seconds, then move to any Random Select square, hold the Start button and press any button.[CR]2) To use Juli, pause on Karin for five seconds, then move to any Random Select square. If the square is on the left side of the screen, choose her by holding Left and pressing any button. If the square is on the right side, then hold Right and press any button instead.[CR]3) To use Juni, pause on Karin for five seconds, then move to any Random Select square. If the square is on the top of the screen, choose her by holding Up and pressing any button. If the square is on the bottom, then hold Down and press any button instead.[CR]* Hidden Modes Of Play : There are three secret modes that affect basic gameplay. Once the game's title screen has become the proper color (see 'Title Color Chart', above), you can select a hidden mode to use...[CR]1) To use Classical Mode, insert your coin, hold down HP+HK and press Start. You can release HP+HK once you're at the Player Select Screen. Then, pick your character. When you start the round your super power bar will be gone and you will have Street Fighter 2 moves.[CR]2) To use Mazi Mode, insert your coin, hold down MP+MK and press Start. You can release HP+HK once you're at the Player Select Screen. Then, pick your character.[CR]3) To use Saikyou Mode, insert your coin, hold down LP+LK and press Start. You can release HP+HK once you're at the Player Select Screen. Then, pick your character.[CR]* Hidden Battle Mode : Once the game's title screen has become the proper color (see 'Title Color Chart', above), you can select a hidden battle mode...[CR]1) Final battle mode : After picking your ISM, hold Start+LP+MK+HP. You'll fight Shin Vega for one battle only. It's just like the last battle; win and you get your ending, lose and you get the bad ending.[CR]2) Dramatic battle mode : Hold LK+MK+HK, then press Start. Keep holding those buttons at Player Select Screen for a moment. You'll fight a 2 on 1 battle for 6 rounds, in which you face two CPU-controlled opponents.[CR]3) Survival mode : Insert your coin(s), hold LP+MP+HP and press Start. Keep holding those buttons at Player Select Screen. You'll get to fight all 27 characters in continuous one-round battles.[CR]* Secret Messages (this trick only works on Japanese SFZ3 machines) : After winning a battle, press and hold Start as well as any other button. Between battles, a message will appear on the screen, depending on the button you're holding.[CR]* Sari In Every Stage : In Dhalsim's stage you may have noticed a girl who cheers for him. That is Sari, his wife. When you play as Dhalsim, its possible to make her appear on every fight by holding down LP+HK before the fight starts (you must do this at the beginning of every round).[CR]* Alternate Sodom BGM : When fighting against Sodom (VS or CPU), you'll get to hear a different tune if it is on X-ISM mode. Apparently the tune is inspired on his boss tune in "Final Fight".[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Street Fighter (1987)[CR]2. Street Fighter II - The World Warrior [CP-S No. 14] (1991)[CR]3. Street Fighter II' - Champion Edition [CP-S No. 21] (1992)[CR]4. Street Fighter II' Turbo - Hyper Fighting [CP-S No. 24] (1992)[CR]5. Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [CP-S II No. 01] (1993)[CR]6. Super Street Fighter II X - Grand Master Challenge [CP-S II No. 03 Bis] (1994)[CR]7. Street Fighter Zero [CP-S II No. 11] (1995)[CR]8. Street Fighter Zero 2 [CP-S II No. 15] (1996)[CR]9. Street Fighter Zero 2 Alpha (1996)[CR]10. Street Fighter III - New Generation (1997)[CR]11. Street Fighter III - 2nd Impact : Giant Attack (1997)[CR]12. Street Fighter Zero 3 [CP-S II No. 29] (1998)[CR]13. Street Fighter III - 3rd Strike : Fight For The Future (1999)[CR]14. Hyper Street Fighter II - The Anniversary Edition [CP-S II No. 38] (2003)[CR]15. Street Fighter IV (2008)[CR]16. Super Street Fighter IV (2010)[CR]17. This brings the total count to 34 playable characters! [CR]An even further upgraded version of SFZ3, called "Street Fighter Zero 3 Double Upper" appeared for the Sony PSP in 2006, and adds Eagle (from the original Street Fighter), Yun (from SFIII), Maki (from the Super Famicom Final Fight 2) and newcomer Ingrid. This now brings the total count of playable characters to 38![CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Green Board revisions : [CR]REVISION 1:[CR]* Build date: 980629[CR]REVISION 2:[CR]* Build date: 980727[CR]REVISION 3:[CR]* Build date: 980904[CR]Revision 1 had two bugs involving Karin : First, she could do her Kanzuki-ryuu Kou'ou Ken super in X-ISM (which she shouldn't be able to do, as it was her second super). Second, Karin's normal throw in Mazi Mode could do 99% damage.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Title Color Chart : The color of the title screen denotes what secrets are currently available. After a few weeks of play, the title screen will change color, so in a few months after your SFZ3 machine has been installed, it should reach the final color (light blue). The explanation of the colors is shown below :[CR]Cream - (default color)[CR]Green - Classical Mode[CR]Red - M. Bison, Juni and Juli become playable[CR]Dark Blue - Mazi Mode[CR]Purple - Saikyou Mode[CR]Light Blue - Can select one of the three Battle Modes[CR]* Random Select : The Random Select squares are normally invisible. But, there are two for the first player and two for the second. The 1P squares are located in the upper-right corner of the diamond and the lower-right. The 2P squares are in the upper-left corner and the lower-left corners.[CR]* Hidden Characters : The three hidden charactes are M. Bison, the boxer and Juni and Juli, two prototype 'dolls' created by Vega's Shadowloo organization. Once the game's title screen has become the proper color (see 'Title Color Chart', above), their score listing will show up in the High Score listing and they become playable...[CR]1) To choose M. Bison, pause on Karin for five seconds, then move to any Random Select square, hold the Start button and press any button.[CR]2) To use Juli, pause on Karin for five seconds, then move to any Random Select square. If the square is on the left side of the screen, choose her by holding Left and pressing any button. If the square is on the right side, then hold Right and press any button instead.[CR]3) To use Juni, pause on Karin for five seconds, then move to any Random Select square. If the square is on the top of the screen, choose her by holding Up and pressing any button. If the square is on the bottom, then hold Down and press any button instead.[CR]* Hidden Modes Of Play : There are three secret modes that affect basic gameplay. Once the game's title screen has become the proper color (see 'Title Color Chart', above), you can select a hidden mode to use...[CR]1) To use Classical Mode, insert your coin, hold down HP+HK and press Start. You can release HP+HK once you're at the Player Select Screen. Then, pick your character. When you start the round your super power bar will be gone and you will have Street Fighter 2 moves.[CR]2) To use Mazi Mode, insert your coin, hold down MP+MK and press Start. You can release HP+HK once you're at the Player Select Screen. Then, pick your character.[CR]3) To use Saikyou Mode, insert your coin, hold down LP+LK and press Start. You can release HP+HK once you're at the Player Select Screen. Then, pick your character.[CR]* Hidden Battle Mode : Once the game's title screen has become the proper color (see 'Title Color Chart', above), you can select a hidden battle mode...[CR]1) Final battle mode : After picking your ISM, hold Start+LP+MK+HP. You'll fight Shin Vega for one battle only. It's just like the last battle; win and you get your ending, lose and you get the bad ending.[CR]2) Dramatic battle mode : Hold LK+MK+HK, then press Start. Keep holding those buttons at Player Select Screen for a moment. You'll fight a 2 on 1 battle for 6 rounds, in which you face two CPU-controlled opponents.[CR]3) Survival mode : Insert your coin(s), hold LP+MP+HP and press Start. Keep holding those buttons at Player Select Screen. You'll get to fight all 27 characters in continuous one-round battles.[CR]* Secret Messages (this trick only works on Japanese SFZ3 machines) : After winning a battle, press and hold Start as well as any other button. Between battles, a message will appear on the screen, depending on the button you're holding.[CR]* Sari In Every Stage : In Dhalsim's stage you may have noticed a girl who cheers for him. That is Sari, his wife. When you play as Dhalsim, its possible to make her appear on every fight by holding down LP+HK before the fight starts (you must do this at the beginning of every round).[CR]* Alternate Sodom BGM : When fighting against Sodom (VS or CPU), you'll get to hear a different tune if it is on X-ISM mode. Apparently the tune is inspired on his boss tune in "Final Fight".[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Street Fighter (1987)[CR]2. Street Fighter II - The World Warrior [CP-S No. 14] (1991)[CR]3. Street Fighter II' - Champion Edition [CP-S No. 21] (1992)[CR]4. Street Fighter II' Turbo - Hyper Fighting [CP-S No. 24] (1992)[CR]5. Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [CP-S II No. 01] (1993)[CR]6. Super Street Fighter II X - Grand Master Challenge [CP-S II No. 03 Bis] (1994)[CR]7. Street Fighter Zero [CP-S II No. 11] (1995)[CR]8. Street Fighter Zero 2 [CP-S II No. 15] (1996)[CR]9. Street Fighter Zero 2 Alpha (1996)[CR]10. Street Fighter III - New Generation (1997)[CR]11. Street Fighter III - 2nd Impact : Giant Attack (1997)[CR]12. Street Fighter Zero 3 [CP-S II No. 29] (1998)[CR]13. Street Fighter III - 3rd Strike : Fight For The Future (1999)[CR]14. Hyper Street Fighter II - The Anniversary Edition [CP-S II No. 38] (2003)[CR]15. Street Fighter IV (2008)[CR]16. Super Street Fighter IV (2010)[CR]17. Ultra Street Fighter IV (2014)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Planner : Noritaka Funamizu[CR]Directors : Maoto Ohta, Mamoru, Buruma, Ohko Zero05[CR]Visual planner : Haruo Murata[CR]Programmers : Cham Cho Choy, Hard.Yas (~?-ISM~), Pon, Shinchan (as 'Hyper Shinchan'), 24 ~Nishi~, Minomi, Reiko Toh, Sen?Knight Rider Giu, Ittetsu[CR]Character designers : Akira Yasuda (Akiman), Osusi[CR]Title designer : Shoei[CR]Object designers : Eripyon.N (Eri-N), Fujihara, Mizuho, Takemoto, Hitoshi Igarashi, Mizupyon, Kimo Kimo (Jinzin), Ball boy, Yuesuke, D-Kurita, A. Iwasaki, Kaname, Fuzii & Peliko, Chimorin Shogun, Sagata, Ikusan Z, Kitasan, You-Ten Nakano, Tomohiro Ohsumi, Hiro, Rumichan, Reiko Komatsu, Kozuchi Tamura, Youichi Matsuo, Makoto Ishii[CR]Scroll designers : Asae Nisituji-Ba, S. Mukai (Jijii), Hirokazu Yonezuka, Kohama Ake&kuro, Yoichi Tanoue (Tanopu), Ryo Uno, Yoko.Fukumoto, Takako Nakamura, Kazu.T, A. Ohnishi, N. Niiyama, C. Iwai, Sawatch, K. Yamahashi, H. Yamahashi, Hiroki Ohnishi[CR]Main music composer : Takayuki Iwai (Anarchy Takapon)[CR]Sub music composer : Yuki Iwai, Isao Abe, Hideki Okugawa, Tetsuya Shibata[CR]Sound direction : Hiroaki Kondo (X68K)[CR]Sound designers : Moe.T, Satoshi Ise[CR]Test players : Nuki, M.P Oni-Suzuki, Skill Smith-Bug, Skill Smith-TTK, M. Kunishige, Miura.F.Katsusuke, Tomita Yoshihiro, Murata Akimori[CR]Market producer : Kouji Nakajima[CR]General producers : Noritaka Funamizu, Yoshiki Okamoto[CR]* Voice Actors :[CR]Ryu : Toshiyuki Morikawa[CR]Edmund Honda : Masashi Sugahara[CR]Cody : Koichi Yamadera[CR]Karin Kanzuki : Miho Yamada[CR]Balrog, Blanka : Yuji Ueda[CR]Ken Masters : Tetsuya Iwanaga[CR]Dhalsim : Yoshiharu Yamada[CR]Sodom, Zangief, Adon, Gen, Birdie : Wataru Takagi[CR]Cammy, Juli, Juni : Akiko Koumoto[CR]Rolento Schugerg : Jin Yamanoi[CR]Sakura Kasugano : Yuko Sasamoto[CR]Rose : Neya Michiko[CR]Dan Hibiki : Osamu Hosoi[CR]Guy : Tetsuya Iwanaga[CR]Rainbow Mika Nanakawa : Junko Takeuchi[CR]Gouki, Vega : Tomomichi Nishimura[CR]Chun-Li : Yuko Miyamura[CR]Nash : Toshiyuki Morikawa[CR]Sagat : Miki Shinichiro[CR]Mike Bison : Koichi Yamadera[CR]Narrator : Greg Irwin[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]NOTE: These are ports released in Japan only.[CR]* Consoles : [CR][JP] Sony PlayStation (Dec.23, 1998) "Street Fighter Zero [Model SLPS-01777]" [CR][JP] Sega Dreamcast (July 8, 1999) "Street Fighter Zero 3 - Saikyooryuu Doujou [Model T-1203M]" [CR][JP] Sega Saturn (Aug.6, 1999) "Street Fighter Zero 3 [Model T-1247G]" [CR][JP] Sony PlayStation 2 (May 25, 2006) "Street Fighter Zero - Fighter's Generation [Model SLPS-66409]" [CR]* Handhelds : [CR][JP] Nintendo Game Boy Advance (Sep.27, 2002) "Street Fighter Zero 3 Upper [Model AGB-AZUJ-JPN]" [CR][JP] Sony PSP (Jan.19, 2006) "Street Fighter Zero 3 Double Upper [Model ULJM-05082]" [CR]For further details on most of these ports, please see the "Street Fighter Zero 3 Upper" entry.[CR]

game.name: Street Fighter Zero (Japan 950727)
game.plot: Street Fighter Zero (c) 1995 Capcom Co, Limited.[CR]The new look of the Street Fighter series, with ten characters including old favorites and new surprises.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 2.[CR]Control: 8-way joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 6 per player.[CR]= > [1] LP, [2] MP, [3] HP [CR]= > [4] LK, [5] MK, [6] HK[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Street Fighter Zero was released in June 1995 in the Japanese arcades. It was known there as the 11th video game released for the CPS2 hardware.[CR]Known Export releases:[CR]"Street Fighter Alpha - Warriors' Dreams [Blue Board]"[CR]"Street Fighter Zero [Grey Board]"[CR]"Street Fighter Zero [Orange Board]"[CR]"Street Fighter Zero [Pink Board]"[CR]The Zero series of games take place between the original Street Fighter and Street Fighter II. The scar on Sagat's chest in SFII is said to be from Ryu's Shouryuuken during the final battle in the original Street Fighter. In SF Zero, Sagat has the scar on his chest, so it must take place after the first Street Fighter. The character Nash was mentioned in Guile's ending in SFII. He is a friend of Guile who was killed by Vega. Since Nash is still alive in the Zero series, it must take place before SFII.[CR]This is the first Street Fighter game to have the Dramatic Battle Mode, a feature no doubt inspired by the Japanese animated movie, 'Street Fighter II', where Ken and Ryu team up to fight M. Bison in the final battle.[CR]This game marks the first time Gouki's name is displayed on-screen in the game.[CR]Ryu / Guy stages : [CR]The "Son Son" convenience store in Ryu and Guy's stages is named after an earlier Capcom game of the same name. [CR]A poster for the animated feature film version of Street Fighter II can be seen on display.[CR]The kanji on the small sign on the bath-house means 'Honda Bath'. [CR]The curtain on the bath-house (in Guy's version of the stage) says 'yu' in hiragana, which is the reading for the 'bath' kanji on the 'Honda Bath' sign. [CR]In "Street Fighter Zero 3", Edmond Honda's stage is in front of this (or a similar-looking) bath-house with slightly different signs on it. [CR]In "Street Fighter II - The World Warrior" (and all its follow-ups), Honda's stage is inside of a bath house.[CR]Guy and Sodom are from Capcom's "Final Fight" - Guy as selectable character and Sodom as the second boss in Final Fight. Guy's music is taken from "Final Fight".[CR]Sodom is a westerner who is obsessed with Japanese culture and apparently doesn't speak Japanese very well. In the Japanese versions of these games, Sodom's victory quotes are meaningless sentences composed of English words (e.g., 'SHOW BY HUNG JAW') followed by a Japanese translation of what he actually meant to say. In Sodom's ending, he claims about reforming and renaming the Mad Gear gang into something with four kanji. Those kanji read 'Ma-do-gi-a'. Now this could just be random kanji that, when strung together, sound like 'Mad Gear', but by the same token, it can sound like 'Mad Doggie'. The jitte weapons Sodom uses were used by policemen in feudal Japan.[CR]Change of Race: In the original "Street Fighter", Birdie looked Caucasian. In SF Alpha, Birdie is black. The reason for this change is explained in one of Birdie's "Street Fighter Zero 3" win quotes (he was sick at the time of the first Street Fighter).[CR]Sony Music Entertainment released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Street Fighter Zero Arcade Game Track - SRCL-3297) on August 21, 1995.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Green Board releases:[CR]REVISION 1:[CR]* Build date: 950605[CR]REVISION 2:[CR]* Build date: 950627[CR]REVISION 3:[CR]* Build date: 950727[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Play as Gouki: Put the cursor on the [?] on your side and hold Start, then press... [CR]Player 1 : Down(x3), Left(x3), LK+HK (or for different costume press LP+HP). [CR]Player 2 : Down(X3), Right(x3), LK+HK (or for different costume press LP+HP). [CR]* Play as Vega: Put the cursor on the [?] on your side and hold Start, then press... [CR]Player 1 : Down(x2), Left(x2), Down, Left(x2), LK+HK (or for different costume press LP+HP) [CR]Player 2 : Down(x2), Right(x2), Down, Right(x2), LK+HK (or for different costume press LP+HP) [CR]* Play as Dan: After inserting a coin, press and hold Start. Then on the character selection screen go to the [?] box. Then quickly press LP, LK, MK, HK, HP, MP. To get the alternate costume (green) press HP, HK, MK, LK, LP, MP. [CR]* Dramatic Battle Mode : In 2-player mode, have Player 1 highlight Ryu and Player 2 highlight Ken at the character selection screen. [CR]1) Have Player 1 hold Start and press Up, Up. [CR]2) Release Start then press Up, Up, LP. [CR]3) Have Player 2 hold Start and press Up, Up. [CR]4) Release Start then press Up, Up, HP. If done correctly, Ryu and Ken will face M. Bison.[CR]* Alternate Costume Colors : Highlight a fighter at the character selection screen and press LK, MK or HK.[CR]* Fight against Gouki: Highlight a fighter at the character selection screen. Hold Start+MP+MK until Akuma appears and beats up your opponent on the first stage. You will now fight him instead.[CR]* Fight against Dan: Select any player. End each match with the same winning quote. Do not lose any of your first five matches. When you reach your sixth opponent, the message 'Here comes a new challenger' will appear and you will fight Dan (Dan's stage is basically the same as Adon's and Sagat's, except it is sunset). After the match, the game will continue in its normal fashion. (NOTE : To select a winning quote, just hold down and a certain button combination of 3 total buttons when you win your second round. This varies from character to character, but every character can select 2 by holding down with 3 punches or down with 3 kicks).[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Street Fighter (1987)[CR]2. Street Fighter II - The World Warrior [CP-S No. 14] (1991)[CR]3. Street Fighter II' - Champion Edition [CP-S No. 21] (1992)[CR]4. Street Fighter II' Turbo - Hyper Fighting [CP-S No. 24] (1992)[CR]5. Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [CP-S II No. 01] (1993)[CR]6. Super Street Fighter II X - Grand Master Challenge [CP-S II No. 03 Bis] (1994)[CR]7. Street Fighter Zero [CP-S II No. 11] (1995)[CR]8. Street Fighter Zero 2 [CP-S II No. 15] (1996)[CR]9. Street Fighter Zero 2 Alpha (1996)[CR]10. Street Fighter III - New Generation (1997)[CR]11. Street Fighter III - 2nd Impact : Giant Attack (1997)[CR]12. Street Fighter Zero 3 [CP-S II No. 29] (1998)[CR]13. Street Fighter III - 3rd Strike : Fight For The Future (1999)[CR]14. Hyper Street Fighter II - The Anniversary Edition [CP-S II No. 38] (2003)[CR]15. Street Fighter IV (2008)[CR]16. Super Street Fighter IV (2010)[CR]17. Ultra Street Fighter IV (2014)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Planners : Noritaka Funamizu (Poo), Haruo Murata (Mucchi), H. Itsuno (-Tomoshibi-)[CR]Programmers : Cham Cho Choy, Egw, "Tege Killer" Jyaian, Knight Rider Giu, Ogt_Dm, Pon, Arikichi Kiyoko, Hard.Yas (-Gouki-), Hamachan, Shinchan (as 'Hyper Shinchan'), Super Sailor (Vega), Matsushita -Adon- Masakazu[CR]Scroll designers : Konomi, Buppo, Shibata Kayoko, Akiko Matsunaga, Daisuke Nakagawa, Maeno Megumi, Isono, Sm, Mago, Mr. Oranda[CR]Object designers : Eripyon.N (Dokkim), Yatsunonawa (D), Jun Matsumura (27), Makoto Ishii, Chama(c), Gonta, Ari Inukichi, Seigo Kawakami (Ushi), M. Nakatani (KotatuToNeko), Alien Pole, Kuriotoko, Chimorin Syogun, K.Takechan, Masaaki, Dway Nishimura, Norihide = Fnyako.F, Shin-Ya.M, Super-8, Masayo Tsujimoto (Noriko), R, Sagata, Takayuki Kosaka[CR]Music composers : Isao Abe (Oyaji), Syun Nishigaki (Kobekko), Setsuo Yamamoto (Purple), Kadota Yuko (Pop'n), Kuru-Kuru Chance Iwami, Mizuta Naoshi (Groovy)[CR]Sound designers : Hiroaki Kondo (X68K), Ryoji[CR]Producer : Iyono Pon[CR]* Voice Actors :[CR]Ryu, Charlie : Toshiyuki Morikawa[CR]Chun-Li : Yuko Miyamura[CR]Ken, Guy : Tetsuya Iwanaga[CR]Adon, Birdie, Sodom : Wataru Takagi[CR]Rose : Yuko Miyamura[CR]Sagat : Miki Shinichiro[CR]Akuma, M. Bison : Tomomichi Nishimura[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]Here is a list of Japanese ports.[CR]* Consoles : [CR]Sony PlayStation [JP] (December 22, 1995) "Street Fighter Zero [Model SLPS-00176]" [CR]Sega Saturn [JP] (January 26, 1996) "Street Fighter Zero [Model T-1206G]" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [JP] (May 25, 2006) "Street Fighter Zero - Fighters Generation [Model SLPS-66409]" [CR]* Handhelds : [CR]Nintendo Game Boy Color [JP] (March 30, 2001) "Street Fighter Alpha - Warriors' Dreams [Model CGB-BFZJ-JPN]" [CR]* Computers : [CR]PC [MS Windows 9x] [JP] (1997) : Bundled with "Street Fighter Zero 2"[CR]* Others : [CR]CPS Changer [JP] (1995)[CR]
