game.name: Street Fighter Zero (Japan 950605)
game.plot: Street Fighter Zero (c) 1995 Capcom Co, Limited.[CR]The new look of the Street Fighter series, with ten characters including old favorites and new surprises.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 2.[CR]Control: 8-way joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 6 per player.[CR]= > [1] LP, [2] MP, [3] HP [CR]= > [4] LK, [5] MK, [6] HK[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Street Fighter Zero was released in June 1995 in the Japanese arcades. It was known there as the 11th video game released for the CPS2 hardware.[CR]Known Export releases:[CR]"Street Fighter Alpha - Warriors' Dreams [Blue Board]"[CR]"Street Fighter Zero [Grey Board]"[CR]"Street Fighter Zero [Orange Board]"[CR]"Street Fighter Zero [Pink Board]"[CR]The Zero series of games take place between the original Street Fighter and Street Fighter II. The scar on Sagat's chest in SFII is said to be from Ryu's Shouryuuken during the final battle in the original Street Fighter. In SF Zero, Sagat has the scar on his chest, so it must take place after the first Street Fighter. The character Nash was mentioned in Guile's ending in SFII. He is a friend of Guile who was killed by Vega. Since Nash is still alive in the Zero series, it must take place before SFII.[CR]This is the first Street Fighter game to have the Dramatic Battle Mode, a feature no doubt inspired by the Japanese animated movie, 'Street Fighter II', where Ken and Ryu team up to fight M. Bison in the final battle.[CR]This game marks the first time Gouki's name is displayed on-screen in the game.[CR]Ryu / Guy stages : [CR]The "Son Son" convenience store in Ryu and Guy's stages is named after an earlier Capcom game of the same name. [CR]A poster for the animated feature film version of Street Fighter II can be seen on display.[CR]The kanji on the small sign on the bath-house means 'Honda Bath'. [CR]The curtain on the bath-house (in Guy's version of the stage) says 'yu' in hiragana, which is the reading for the 'bath' kanji on the 'Honda Bath' sign. [CR]In "Street Fighter Zero 3", Edmond Honda's stage is in front of this (or a similar-looking) bath-house with slightly different signs on it. [CR]In "Street Fighter II - The World Warrior" (and all its follow-ups), Honda's stage is inside of a bath house.[CR]Guy and Sodom are from Capcom's "Final Fight" - Guy as selectable character and Sodom as the second boss in Final Fight. Guy's music is taken from "Final Fight".[CR]Sodom is a westerner who is obsessed with Japanese culture and apparently doesn't speak Japanese very well. In the Japanese versions of these games, Sodom's victory quotes are meaningless sentences composed of English words (e.g., 'SHOW BY HUNG JAW') followed by a Japanese translation of what he actually meant to say. In Sodom's ending, he claims about reforming and renaming the Mad Gear gang into something with four kanji. Those kanji read 'Ma-do-gi-a'. Now this could just be random kanji that, when strung together, sound like 'Mad Gear', but by the same token, it can sound like 'Mad Doggie'. The jitte weapons Sodom uses were used by policemen in feudal Japan.[CR]Change of Race: In the original "Street Fighter", Birdie looked Caucasian. In SF Alpha, Birdie is black. The reason for this change is explained in one of Birdie's "Street Fighter Zero 3" win quotes (he was sick at the time of the first Street Fighter).[CR]Sony Music Entertainment released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Street Fighter Zero Arcade Game Track - SRCL-3297) on August 21, 1995.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Green Board releases:[CR]REVISION 1:[CR]* Build date: 950605[CR]REVISION 2:[CR]* Build date: 950627[CR]REVISION 3:[CR]* Build date: 950727[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Play as Gouki: Put the cursor on the [?] on your side and hold Start, then press... [CR]Player 1 : Down(x3), Left(x3), LK+HK (or for different costume press LP+HP). [CR]Player 2 : Down(X3), Right(x3), LK+HK (or for different costume press LP+HP). [CR]* Play as Vega: Put the cursor on the [?] on your side and hold Start, then press... [CR]Player 1 : Down(x2), Left(x2), Down, Left(x2), LK+HK (or for different costume press LP+HP) [CR]Player 2 : Down(x2), Right(x2), Down, Right(x2), LK+HK (or for different costume press LP+HP) [CR]* Play as Dan: After inserting a coin, press and hold Start. Then on the character selection screen go to the [?] box. Then quickly press LP, LK, MK, HK, HP, MP. To get the alternate costume (green) press HP, HK, MK, LK, LP, MP. [CR]* Dramatic Battle Mode : In 2-player mode, have Player 1 highlight Ryu and Player 2 highlight Ken at the character selection screen. [CR]1) Have Player 1 hold Start and press Up, Up. [CR]2) Release Start then press Up, Up, LP. [CR]3) Have Player 2 hold Start and press Up, Up. [CR]4) Release Start then press Up, Up, HP. If done correctly, Ryu and Ken will face M. Bison.[CR]* Alternate Costume Colors : Highlight a fighter at the character selection screen and press LK, MK or HK.[CR]* Fight against Gouki: Highlight a fighter at the character selection screen. Hold Start+MP+MK until Akuma appears and beats up your opponent on the first stage. You will now fight him instead.[CR]* Fight against Dan: Select any player. End each match with the same winning quote. Do not lose any of your first five matches. When you reach your sixth opponent, the message 'Here comes a new challenger' will appear and you will fight Dan (Dan's stage is basically the same as Adon's and Sagat's, except it is sunset). After the match, the game will continue in its normal fashion. (NOTE : To select a winning quote, just hold down and a certain button combination of 3 total buttons when you win your second round. This varies from character to character, but every character can select 2 by holding down with 3 punches or down with 3 kicks).[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Street Fighter (1987)[CR]2. Street Fighter II - The World Warrior [CP-S No. 14] (1991)[CR]3. Street Fighter II' - Champion Edition [CP-S No. 21] (1992)[CR]4. Street Fighter II' Turbo - Hyper Fighting [CP-S No. 24] (1992)[CR]5. Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [CP-S II No. 01] (1993)[CR]6. Super Street Fighter II X - Grand Master Challenge [CP-S II No. 03 Bis] (1994)[CR]7. Street Fighter Zero [CP-S II No. 11] (1995)[CR]8. Street Fighter Zero 2 [CP-S II No. 15] (1996)[CR]9. Street Fighter Zero 2 Alpha (1996)[CR]10. Street Fighter III - New Generation (1997)[CR]11. Street Fighter III - 2nd Impact : Giant Attack (1997)[CR]12. Street Fighter Zero 3 [CP-S II No. 29] (1998)[CR]13. Street Fighter III - 3rd Strike : Fight For The Future (1999)[CR]14. Hyper Street Fighter II - The Anniversary Edition [CP-S II No. 38] (2003)[CR]15. Street Fighter IV (2008)[CR]16. Super Street Fighter IV (2010)[CR]17. Ultra Street Fighter IV (2014)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Planners : Noritaka Funamizu (Poo), Haruo Murata (Mucchi), H. Itsuno (-Tomoshibi-)[CR]Programmers : Cham Cho Choy, Egw, "Tege Killer" Jyaian, Knight Rider Giu, Ogt_Dm, Pon, Arikichi Kiyoko, Hard.Yas (-Gouki-), Hamachan, Shinchan (as 'Hyper Shinchan'), Super Sailor (Vega), Matsushita -Adon- Masakazu[CR]Scroll designers : Konomi, Buppo, Shibata Kayoko, Akiko Matsunaga, Daisuke Nakagawa, Maeno Megumi, Isono, Sm, Mago, Mr. Oranda[CR]Object designers : Eripyon.N (Dokkim), Yatsunonawa (D), Jun Matsumura (27), Makoto Ishii, Chama(c), Gonta, Ari Inukichi, Seigo Kawakami (Ushi), M. Nakatani (KotatuToNeko), Alien Pole, Kuriotoko, Chimorin Syogun, K.Takechan, Masaaki, Dway Nishimura, Norihide = Fnyako.F, Shin-Ya.M, Super-8, Masayo Tsujimoto (Noriko), R, Sagata, Takayuki Kosaka[CR]Music composers : Isao Abe (Oyaji), Syun Nishigaki (Kobekko), Setsuo Yamamoto (Purple), Kadota Yuko (Pop'n), Kuru-Kuru Chance Iwami, Mizuta Naoshi (Groovy)[CR]Sound designers : Hiroaki Kondo (X68K), Ryoji[CR]Producer : Iyono Pon[CR]* Voice Actors :[CR]Ryu, Charlie : Toshiyuki Morikawa[CR]Chun-Li : Yuko Miyamura[CR]Ken, Guy : Tetsuya Iwanaga[CR]Adon, Birdie, Sodom : Wataru Takagi[CR]Rose : Yuko Miyamura[CR]Sagat : Miki Shinichiro[CR]Akuma, M. Bison : Tomomichi Nishimura[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]Here is a list of Japanese ports.[CR]* Consoles : [CR]Sony PlayStation [JP] (December 22, 1995) "Street Fighter Zero [Model SLPS-00176]" [CR]Sega Saturn [JP] (January 26, 1996) "Street Fighter Zero [Model T-1206G]" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [JP] (May 25, 2006) "Street Fighter Zero - Fighters Generation [Model SLPS-66409]" [CR]* Handhelds : [CR]Nintendo Game Boy Color [JP] (March 30, 2001) "Street Fighter Alpha - Warriors' Dreams [Model CGB-BFZJ-JPN]" [CR]* Computers : [CR]PC [MS Windows 9x] [JP] (1997) : Bundled with "Street Fighter Zero 2"[CR]* Others : [CR]CPS Changer [JP] (1995)[CR]

game.plot: Super Muscle Bomber - The International Blowout (c) 1994 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]Fourteen selectable wrestlers fight to win the belt in this cross over wrestling/2D fighting game.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 2.[CR]Control: 8-way joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 5 per player.[CR]=> [1] Grab, [2] LP, [3] HP[CR]=> [5] LK, [6] HK[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Super Muscle Bomber was released in August 1994 in the Japanese arcades. It was known as the 6th video game released on the CPS2 hardware.[CR]This game is known outside Japan as "Ring of Destruction - Slammasters II". Here is a list of known Export releases:[CR]"Ring of Destruction - Slammasters II [Blue Board]"[CR]"Ring of Destruction - Slammasters II [Grey Board]"[CR]"Ring of Destruction - Slammasters II [Orange Board]"[CR]Hara Tetsuo, who designed the characters in the Muscle Bomber games, is a popular manga artist in Japan. He is famous for his work on Hokuto no Ken (aka Fist of the North Star).[CR]Sony Music Entertainment released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Super Muscle Bomber Arcade Game Track - SRCL-2919) on October 21, 1994.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* BIFF[CR]- SUPER 1 : Catch then Up, UpLeft, Left[CR]- SUPER 2 : Catch then Up, UpLeft, Left then Catch[CR]* BLACK WIDOW[CR]- SUPER 1 : Catch then Down, Left, Up[CR]- SUPER 2 : Catch then Down, Left, Up then Catch[CR]* GRATER[CR]- SUPER 1 : Catch then Right, UpRight, Up[CR]- SUPER 2 : Catch then Right, UpRight, Up then Catch[CR]* GUNLOC[CR]- SUPER 1 : Catch then Up, UpLeft, Left[CR]- SUPER 2 : Catch then Up, UpLeft, Left then Catch[CR]* HAGGAR[CR]- SUPER 1 : Catch then 360°[CR]- SUPER 2 : Catch then 360° then Catch[CR]* JUMBO[CR]- SUPER 1 : Catch then Half Circle toward[CR]- SUPER 2 : Catch then Half Circle toward then Catch[CR]* ONI[CR]- SUPER 1 : Catch then 360°[CR]- SUPER 2 : Catch then 360° then Catch[CR]* ORTEGA[CR]- SUPER 1 : Catch then Left, Down, DownLeft[CR]- SUPER 2 : Catch then Left, Down, DownLeft then Catch[CR]* RASTA[CR]- SUPER 1 : Catch then Down, Up[CR]- SUPER 2 : Catch then Down, Up then Catch[CR]* SABER[CR]- SUPER 1 : Catch then DownRight, UpRight[CR]- SUPER 2 : Catch then DonwRight, UpRight then Catch[CR]* SCORPION[CR]- SUPER 1 : Catch then Up, Down[CR]- SUPER 2 : Catch then Up, Down then Catch[CR]* STINGRAY[CR]- SUPER 1 : Catch then Right, Down, DownRight[CR]- SUPER 2 : Catch then Right, Down, DownRight then Catch[CR]* TITAN[CR]- SUPER 1 : Catch then DonwLeft, Down, Up[CR]- SUPER 2 : Catch then DonwLeft, Down, Up then Catch[CR]* WRAITH[CR]- SUPER 1 : Catch then Right, UpRight, Up[CR]- SUPER 2 : Catch then Right, UpRight, Up then Catch[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. game.name: Super Puzzle Fighter II X (Japan 960531)
game.plot: Super Puzzle Fighter II X (c) 1996 Capcom Co, Limited.[CR]Super Puzzle Fighter II X is a puzzle game for one or two players based upon Capcom's legendary "Street Fighter" and "Vampire" series of fighting games. [CR]Super Puzzle Fighter II X's gameplay is reminiscent of Sega's superb 1992 puzzle game, "Puyo Puyo" with players taking on the role of one of the famous Street Fighter characters, represented visually between the two play areas in the middle of the screen. The aim is to manipulate falling coloured gem blocks, matching the colours to gems already in the play area; before finally destroying them with orbs of a like colour. [CR]Gems can only be eliminated by coming into contact with a 'Crash Gem' of the same colour. This eliminates all adjacent gems of that colour, setting up the potential for huge chain reactions. [CR]As gems are eliminated, garbage blocks called 'Counter Gems' will drop into the opponent's playfield; these will eventually become normal gems, but only after they count down to zero (most Counter Gem countdowns start at '5' and are reduced by one each time a new pair of gems is dropped on that board), until that time they cannot be eliminated by normal means. The only way to eliminate Counter Gems before they become normal gems is to place a Crash Gem of that colour nearby so it eliminates at least one normal gem. If this is done, all Counter Gems immediately adjacent to the Crash Gem will be taken out as well. [CR]Additionally, gems of the same colour that form squares or rectangles (of at least two blocks tall and wide) in the pit become a giant Power Gem of that size and color; eliminating these as part of a combo increases the number of Counter Gems that would otherwise normally appear on the opponent's board. [CR]The only other type of piece to appear is a diamond, which eliminates all the normal, Power, Counter and Crash gems of whichever colour gem it lands on. This, too, will cause Counter Gems to appear on the opponent's board. [CR]Whenever a player destroys a number of blocks, their on-screen Street Fighter counter-part will be shown attacking the opponent character. The fighting move used is dependent on both the colour and number of blocks the player has destroyed. [CR]The available in-game characters, and games from which they are taken (based on first appearance) are : [CR]* Ryu ("Street Fighter") [CR]* Ken ("Street Fighter") [CR]* Chun-Li ("Street Fighter II - The World Warrior") [CR]* Sakura ("Street Fighter Zero 2 [CP-S II No. 15]") [CR]* Morrigan ("Vampire - The Night Warriors [CP-S II No. 05]") [CR]* Donovan ("Vampire Hunter - Darkstalkers' Revenge [CP-S II No. 09]") [CR]* Lei Lei ("Vampire Hunter - Darkstalkers' Revenge [CP-S II No. 09]") [CR]* Felicia ("Vampire - The Night Warriors [CP-S II No. 05]") [CR]Hidden characters:[CR]* Gouki ("Super Street Fighter II X - Grand Master Challenge [CP-S II No. 03 Bis]") [CR]* Dan ("Street Fighter Zero [CP-S II No. 11]") [CR]* Devilotte ("Cyberbots - Fullmetal Madness [CP-S II No. 10]")[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 2.[CR]Control: 8-way joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 2 per player.[CR]=> ROTATE LEFT, ROTATE RIGHT[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Super Puzzle Fighter II X was released in May 1996 in the Japanese Arcades. It was known there as the 16th video game released for the CPS2 hardware.[CR]The title is derived from "Super Street Fighter II X - Grand Master Challenge", but most of the graphics, sounds, and presentation is inspired by "Street Fighter Zero".[CR]The game is known outside Japan as "Super Puzzle Fighter II Turbo". Here are some known Export releases : [CR]"Super Puzzle Fighter II Turbo [Blue Board]"[CR]"Super Puzzle Fighter II Turbo [Orange Board]"[CR]"Super Puzzle Fighter II Turbo [Grey Board]"[CR]Devilot (secret character) is from "Cyberbots - Fullmetal Madness" (on the S-008 Super-8).[CR]In the background of Chun-Li's stage, there is "Son Son" flying around on a cloud.[CR]Sakura's stage is based on Ryu and Guy's stages from "Street Fighter Zero".[CR]Ryu's stage is a variation of this, with a bunch of strange stuff in the background.[CR]Ken's stage is based on Ken and Nash's stages from "Street Fighter Zero".[CR]Dan's stage is a variation of this stage, set at a different time of day.[CR]Gouki's stage is based on his "Street Fighter Zero 2" stage.[CR]Victor Entertainment released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Quiz Nanairo Dreams Nijiirochou no Kiseki, Super Puzzle Fighter II X - VICL-40210) on January 22, 1997.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Play as Gouki : Move to Morrigan if you're player one or to Felicia if you're player two. Move the joystick Left, Down, Left, Down, Left, Down and then hold Left and press any button. Player two should move the joystick Right, Down, Right, Down, Right, Down then hold Right and press any button.[CR]* Play as Dan : Move to Morrigan if you're player one or to Felicia if you're player two. Press and hold Start, move the joystick Down 13 times and then hit any other button.[CR]* Play as Devilot : Move to Morrigan if you're player one or to Felicia if you're player two. Press and hold the Start button and move the joystick Down 13 times. Wait for the clock to reach 10 seconds and then hit any other button.[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Game designers : Murasaki Umagoyasi, SPP Iorya[CR]Programmers : Knight Rider Giu, Cham Cho Choy, Shinchan, Eternal Sailor, Team Dirtyberet[CR]Scroll designers : Nissui, Iwai, Meiko. K, Saru, Hisoya Akemi, Ojiji, S. Kuwatch, Takky, Konsutantinkun, Hiro[CR]Character designers : Edayan, Goidanokei[CR]Object designers : Masarusan N, Ino, Aska[CR]Sound designer : Hiroaki Kondo (X68K)[CR]Sound assists : Satoshi Ise[CR]Music & Arrangement composers : Tatsuro Zuzuki (Tatsuro-), Isao Abe, Yuko Kadota, Syun Nishigaki, Setsuo Yamamoto, Takayuki Iwai (Anarchy Takapon)[CR]Producers : Noritaka Funamizu, Saddy[CR]Sound staff : Hideki Okugawa, Ryoji Yamamoto[CR]Design staff : Daigo Ikeno, Masae Okano, Satoshi Ukai, Shinchiro Komizu[CR]Producer : Yoshimi Ohnishi[CR]General producer : Noritaka Funamizu[CR]Supervisor : Yoshiki Okamoto[CR]* Cast :[CR]Felicia, Lei Lei, narration : Araki Kae[CR]Devilot, Morrigan : Jinguuji Yayoi[CR]Chun Li : Miyamura Yuko[CR]Sakura : Sakamoto Yuko[CR]Ryu : Hoshi Souichirou[CR]Dan : Hosoi Osamu[CR]Ken, Donovan : Iwanaga Tetsuya[CR]Gouki : Tomomichi Nishimura[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]Here is a list of ports released in Japan. For ports released outside Japan, please see the Export version entry; "Super Puzzle Fighter II Turbo [Blue Board]".[CR]* Consoles :[CR]Sega Saturn [JP] (December 6, 1996) "Super Puzzle Fighter II X [Model T-1213G]" [CR]Sony PlayStation [JP] (December 6, 1996) "Super Puzzle Fighter II X [Model SLPS-00611]" [CR]Sega Dreamcast [JP] (July 5, 2001) "Super Puzzle Fighter II X for Matching Service [Model T-1250M]" [CR]* Handhelds : [CR]Nintendo Game Boy Advance [JP] [Unreleased][CR]

game.plot: Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers (c) 1993 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]Export release. Game developed in Japan. For more information about the game itself, please see the original Japanese version entry; "Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [Green Board]".[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Blue Board [USA & Etc.][CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]In M. Bison's ending in the Export versions, Bison says 'Not even the 'Ancient One' dared to challenge me!'. In the original Japanese version, where he's known as Vega, he doesn't say anything like this.[CR]Localizations liberties were taken with Cammy's and Fei-Long's endings in the Export versions of SSFII, changing their whole context.[CR]Some of the voice samples of Cammy and Dee Jay were changed from the original version:[CR](Japanese version quote - Export version quote.)[CR]* Cammy : 'Spiral Arrow' - 'Cannon Drill'[CR]* Cammy : 'Cannon Spike' - 'Thrust Kick'[CR]* Dee Jay : 'Slash' - 'Max Out'[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Blue Board revisions : [CR]REVISION 1:[CR]* Build date: 930911[CR]* WORLD and USA releases[CR]REVISION 2:[CR]* Build date: 931005[CR]* WORLD release[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]Here is a list of ports released in regions where the arcade version was released as a Blue Board : [CR]* Consoles : [CR]Nintendo SNES [EU] (September 1994) "Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [Model SNSP-XW-EUR]" [CR]Nintendo SNES [US] (June 1994) "Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [Model SNS-XW-USA]" [CR]Sega Genesis [US] (1994) "Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [Model T-12056]" [CR]Sega Mega Drive [EU] (June 1994) Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [Model 670-5448-50]" [CR]Sega Saturn [EU] (1997) "Street Fighter Collection [Model T-7033H-50] [Disc 1]" [CR]Sega Saturn [US] (November 30, 1997) "Street Fighter Collection [Model T-1222H] [Disc 1]" [CR]Sony PlayStation [US] (November 30, 1997) "Street Fighter Collection [Model SLUS-00423]" [CR]Sony PlayStation [EU] (July 1998) "Street Fighter Collection [Model SLES-00998]" [CR]* Computers : [CR]Commodore Amiga [EU] (1995) [CR]PC [MS-DOS, CD-ROM] [US] [EU] (1996)[CR]

game.name: Super Street Fighter II: The New Challengers (Japan 931005)
game.description: Super Street Fighter II: The New Challengers (Japan 931005)
game.title_clean: Super Street Fighter II: The New Challengers
game.plot: Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers (c) 1993 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]The fourth game in the SFII series featured all new graphics, redone sounds, and above all, four characters new to the series. Here is a full list of changes from previous SFII games:[CR]* New title screen with new music. [CR]* Completely new portraits for all characters. M. Bison ('Vega' in Japan) now has a winged-skull on his hat instead of a star. [CR]* New endings for the bosses. The last part of Chun Li's ending is also modified, letting the player choose whether she should now live a normal girl's life or continue being a detective. [CR]* Vega ('Balrog' in Japan) no longer climbs the fence on his stage prior to doing his 'Flying Barcelona Attack' or 'Izuna Drop' moves. He now just jumps to the edge of the screen and jumps off, as he does in the other stages. [CR]* Voice samples for all characters and announcer re-recorded with different actors. Each character now have their own unique voice so there is no more shared voice samples (e.g. the male 'KO' scream). [CR]* Background music playback is handled differently. The background music will play continuously from Round 1 to Round 2 until a character causes the KO sign to flash on Round 2, which will trigger the 'Heavy Damage' version of the music. From Round 3 onward, the music is played in the same format as in previous SFII games. [CR]* Four completely new stage backgrounds with new background music to accompany the New Challengers. [CR]* Color schemes for the twelve original stage backgrounds have changed once again : [CR]1) Ryu stage: The sky is now near evening, and the moon is now white with a touch of light blue. [CR]2) E. Honda stage: The walls are now light blue, and the big picture (excluding the sun) is now red-orange. [CR]3) Blanka stage: The vine where the snake is coiled is now light green, and people to the right have changed a bit. The river behind the village is now a clear blue. [CR]4) Guile stage: The sky is back to daytime, the canopy on the jet is now clear, and the people in the background are now dressed in blue. The symbol on the ground is back to blue, but the missile linings are still red. [CR]5) Ken stage: The tugboat has been replaced with a yacht, the two guys on the top now wear orange clothes and white clothes. On the bottom, the first person now wears a green shirt and has gray hair, the second person now wears white t-shirt and yellow pants, the third person now has long hair and wears white top and pink skirt, the fourth person now wears light blue shirt and orange pants, and the guy in the trenchcoat and hat is now replaced by a new person in blue shirt and navy blue pants.[CR]6) Chun Li stage: The sky is now sunset, the two customers now wear orange, the meat store's roof is now green with its sign back to red, the guy holding the chicken now wears blue, the "Shanghai Friend Corridor" sign is now red-orange with yellow letters, the guy to the right now wears green pants, and the water sign is now blue.[CR]7) Zangief stage: The stage floor is now green, and the area to the left is back to red. In addition, the fence on the left foreground is now lowered a bit. [CR]8) Dhalsim stage: The curtains and stone floor are now green, and the carpet is back to red. [CR]9) Balrog ([JP] M. Bison) stage: While the stage floor is still purple, the 'Las Vegas' on the floor is now yellow. The car to the left is now blue, and the car to the right is now green. The guy throwing the confetti at win/lose now wears yellow, the guy next to the car to the left now wears purple and the guy next to the guy throwing the confetti has been redesigned.[CR]10) Vega ([JP] Balrog) stage: The stage floor now shows off a green hue, and the fence now comes crashing down at the start of the fight. [CR]11) Sagat stage: Buddhist statue is still gold, and now it's sunset. In addition, a big city is now visible in the distance. [CR]12) M. Bison ([JP] Vega) stage: The sky is now back to daytime, and the guys sitting Indian style praying (and stands up angrily after breaking a big statue) are now dark-skinned. The roof of the palace is now red with green trim, and the linings on the giant bell that were previously red are now black.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 2. [CR]Control: 8-way joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 6 per player.[CR]= > [1] LP (Jab), [2] MP (Strong), [3] HP (Fierce) [CR]= > [4] LK (Short), [5] MK (Forward), [6] HK (Roundhouse)[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]September 1993 was the first revision of the game, but most arcades didn't get the game until October 1993. It was known as the first CPS2 video game released.[CR]Known Export releases:[CR]"Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [Blue Board]"[CR]"Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [Grey Board]"[CR]"Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [Orange Board]"[CR]While New Challengers Cammy, Fei Long and T. Hawk were created by Japanese employees at Capcom, the Jamaican kickboxer Dee Jay is the first and only Street Fighter to have been created by an American Capcom employee (James Goddard). Dee Jay's pant leg was originally going to have 'MANTIS' written on it instead of 'MAXIMUM'. It was changed so that when the sprite was flipped over (when Dee Jay faces the opposite direction), the letters would not appear to be backwards. That is, all of the letters in 'MAXIMUM' look the same when flipped over, but the 'N' and 'S' in 'MANTIS' will be backwards when flipped. [CR]Fei Long is Capcom's homage to Bruce Lee. [CR]Sony Records released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Super Street Fighter II Arcade Game Track - SRCL-2822) on January 21, 1994. [CR]Michael Jackson used to own this game (serial number: 21900255228). It was sold at the official Michael Jackson Auction on April 24, 2009.[CR]A special version of this game is known as "Super Street Fighter II - The Tournament Battle".[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Green Board revisions : [CR]REVISION 1:[CR]* Build date: 930910[CR]REVISION 2:[CR]* Build date: 930911[CR]REVISION 3:[CR]* Build date: 931005[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Each character has eight outfit colors. Press LP to choose the original Street Fighter II color, MP for the Champion Edition color, HP for the Turbo (i.e. 'Hyper Fighting') color, any Kick button or the Start button for one of 4 new colors, or hold any button (except the Start button) for 3 seconds for the secret color.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Street Fighter (1987)[CR]2. Street Fighter II - The World Warrior [B-Board 90629B] (1991)[CR]3. Street Fighter II' - Champion Edition [B-Board 91634B-2] (1992)[CR]4. game.name: Super Street Fighter II: The New Challengers (Japan 930911)
game.description: Super Street Fighter II: The New Challengers (Japan 930911)
game.title_clean: Super Street Fighter II: The New Challengers
game.plot: Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers (c) 1993 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]The fourth game in the SFII series featured all new graphics, redone sounds, and above all, four characters new to the series. Here is a full list of changes from previous SFII games:[CR]* New title screen with new music. [CR]* Completely new portraits for all characters. M. Bison ('Vega' in Japan) now has a winged-skull on his hat instead of a star. [CR]* New endings for the bosses. The last part of Chun Li's ending is also modified, letting the player choose whether she should now live a normal girl's life or continue being a detective. [CR]* Vega ('Balrog' in Japan) no longer climbs the fence on his stage prior to doing his 'Flying Barcelona Attack' or 'Izuna Drop' moves. He now just jumps to the edge of the screen and jumps off, as he does in the other stages. [CR]* Voice samples for all characters and announcer re-recorded with different actors. Each character now have their own unique voice so there is no more shared voice samples (e.g. the male 'KO' scream). [CR]* Background music playback is handled differently. The background music will play continuously from Round 1 to Round 2 until a character causes the KO sign to flash on Round 2, which will trigger the 'Heavy Damage' version of the music. From Round 3 onward, the music is played in the same format as in previous SFII games. [CR]* Four completely new stage backgrounds with new background music to accompany the New Challengers. [CR]* Color schemes for the twelve original stage backgrounds have changed once again : [CR]1) Ryu stage: The sky is now near evening, and the moon is now white with a touch of light blue. [CR]2) E. Honda stage: The walls are now light blue, and the big picture (excluding the sun) is now red-orange. [CR]3) Blanka stage: The vine where the snake is coiled is now light green, and people to the right have changed a bit. The river behind the village is now a clear blue. [CR]4) Guile stage: The sky is back to daytime, the canopy on the jet is now clear, and the people in the background are now dressed in blue. The symbol on the ground is back to blue, but the missile linings are still red. [CR]5) Ken stage: The tugboat has been replaced with a yacht, the two guys on the top now wear orange clothes and white clothes. On the bottom, the first person now wears a green shirt and has gray hair, the second person now wears white t-shirt and yellow pants, the third person now has long hair and wears white top and pink skirt, the fourth person now wears light blue shirt and orange pants, and the guy in the trenchcoat and hat is now replaced by a new person in blue shirt and navy blue pants.[CR]6) Chun Li stage: The sky is now sunset, the two customers now wear orange, the meat store's roof is now green with its sign back to red, the guy holding the chicken now wears blue, the "Shanghai Friend Corridor" sign is now red-orange with yellow letters, the guy to the right now wears green pants, and the water sign is now blue.[CR]7) Zangief stage: The stage floor is now green, and the area to the left is back to red. In addition, the fence on the left foreground is now lowered a bit. [CR]8) Dhalsim stage: The curtains and stone floor are now green, and the carpet is back to red. [CR]9) Balrog ([JP] M. Bison) stage: While the stage floor is still purple, the 'Las Vegas' on the floor is now yellow. The car to the left is now blue, and the car to the right is now green. The guy throwing the confetti at win/lose now wears yellow, the guy next to the car to the left now wears purple and the guy next to the guy throwing the confetti has been redesigned.[CR]10) Vega ([JP] Balrog) stage: The stage floor now shows off a green hue, and the fence now comes crashing down at the start of the fight. [CR]11) Sagat stage: Buddhist statue is still gold, and now it's sunset. In addition, a big city is now visible in the distance. [CR]12) M. Bison ([JP] Vega) stage: The sky is now back to daytime, and the guys sitting Indian style praying (and stands up angrily after breaking a big statue) are now dark-skinned. The roof of the palace is now red with green trim, and the linings on the giant bell that were previously red are now black.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 2. [CR]Control: 8-way joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 6 per player.[CR]= > [1] LP (Jab), [2] MP (Strong), [3] HP (Fierce) [CR]= > [4] LK (Short), [5] MK (Forward), [6] HK (Roundhouse)[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]September 1993 was the first revision of the game, but most arcades didn't get the game until October 1993. It was known as the first CPS2 video game released.[CR]Known Export releases:[CR]"Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [Blue Board]"[CR]"Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [Grey Board]"[CR]"Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [Orange Board]"[CR]While New Challengers Cammy, Fei Long and T. Hawk were created by Japanese employees at Capcom, the Jamaican kickboxer Dee Jay is the first and only Street Fighter to have been created by an American Capcom employee (James Goddard). Dee Jay's pant leg was originally going to have 'MANTIS' written on it instead of 'MAXIMUM'. It was changed so that when the sprite was flipped over (when Dee Jay faces the opposite direction), the letters would not appear to be backwards. That is, all of the letters in 'MAXIMUM' look the same when flipped over, but the 'N' and 'S' in 'MANTIS' will be backwards when flipped. [CR]Fei Long is Capcom's homage to Bruce Lee. [CR]Sony Records released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Super Street Fighter II Arcade Game Track - SRCL-2822) on January 21, 1994. [CR]Michael Jackson used to own this game (serial number: 21900255228). It was sold at the official Michael Jackson Auction on April 24, 2009.[CR]A special version of this game is known as "Super Street Fighter II - The Tournament Battle".[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Green Board revisions : [CR]REVISION 1:[CR]* Build date: 930910[CR]REVISION 2:[CR]* Build date: 930911[CR]REVISION 3:[CR]* Build date: 931005[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Each character has eight outfit colors. Press LP to choose the original Street Fighter II color, MP for the Champion Edition color, HP for the Turbo (i.e. 'Hyper Fighting') color, any Kick button or the Start button for one of 4 new colors, or hold any button (except the Start button) for 3 seconds for the secret color.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Street Fighter (1987)[CR]2. Street Fighter II - The World Warrior [B-Board 90629B] (1991)[CR]3. Street Fighter II' - Champion Edition [B-Board 91634B-2] (1992)[CR]4. Street Fighter II' - Hyper Fighting [B-Board 91635B-2] (1992)[CR]5. Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [Green Board] (1993)[CR]6. Super Street Fighter II Turbo [Blue Board] (1994)[CR]7. Street Fighter Alpha - Warriors' Dreams [Blue Board] (1995)[CR]8. Street Fighter Alpha 2 [Blue Board] (1996)[CR]9. Street Fighter III - New Generation (1997)[CR]10. Street Fighter III - 2nd Impact : Giant Attack (1997)[CR]11. Street Fighter Alpha 3 [Blue Board] (1998)[CR]12. Street Fighter III - 3rd Strike : Fight For The Future (1999)[CR]13. Hyper Street Fighter II - The Anniversary Edition [Green Board] (2003)[CR]14. Street Fighter IV (2008)[CR]15. Super Street Fighter IV - Arcade Edition (2010)[CR]16. Ultra Street Fighter IV (2014)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Planners : Noritaka Funamizu (Poo), Haruo Murata (Mucchi)[CR]Character Designers : Kurisan, Ikusan Z, Q, Yorio, Tanuki, Katuragi, Matsunaga, Rikagon, Simpsons, Pei, Mikiman, Buppo, M. Okazaki, Taka, Akiko. O, K. Crown, Hiroshi Shibata (Shibataro)[CR]Programmers : Shin., Kid, Min, EGW, Aoi Mix, Tarabar Hori (Tarabar)[CR]Music : Syun Nishigaki (Syun), Isao Abe (Oyaji)[CR]Sound : Nobuhiro Oouchi (Nobu. Oouchi), Toshio Kajino (Toshio)[CR]Special Thanks : Akira Nishitani (Nin), Akira Yasuda (Akiman), CBX, David Winstead (Dr. Dave), Alex Jimenez (Raven Jimenez)[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]Here is a list of ports released in Japan (where the arcade version was released as a Green Board) : [CR]* Consoles : [CR]Nintendo Super Famicom [JP] (June 25, 1994) "Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [Model SHVC-XW]" [CR]Sega Mega Drive [JP] (June 25, 1994) "Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [Model T-12043]" [CR]FM Towns Marty [JP] (October 28, 1994) "Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [Model HMF-162]" [CR]Sega Saturn [JP] (September 18, 1997) "Street Fighter Collection [Model T-1223G] [Disc 1]" [CR]Sony PlayStation [JP] (October 23, 1997) "Street Fighter Collection [Model SLPS-00800]" [CR]* Computers : [CR]Sharp X68000 [JP] (September 30, 1994) [CR]* Others : [CR]LCD handheld game (19??) released by Tiger Electronics. [CR]LCD Barcodzz handheld game (19??) released by Tiger Electronics.[CR]

game.name: Super Street Fighter II Turbo (World 940223)
game.plot: Super Street Fighter II Turbo (c) 1994 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]Export release. Game developed in Japan. For more information about the game itself, please see the original Japanese release entry; "Super Street Fighter II X - Grand Master Challenge [Green Board]".[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Blue Board [USA & World][CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Super Street Fighter II Turbo was released in February 1994 outside Japan. It is known in Japan as "Super Street Fighter II X - Grand Master Challege".[CR]In these Export versions, Gouki is named Akuma and all of Akuma's dialogue was removed instead of being translated. If Akuma wins a battle in SSF2 Turbo, he has no victory quotes.[CR]Akuma's ending was all completely removed from the Export versions, with only a credit roll if you beat the game with him, along with pictures of his defeated opponents.[CR]Some characters' endings are translated inaccurately.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Blue Board revisions : [CR]REVISION 1:[CR]* Build date: 940223[CR]* WORLD and USA releases[CR]REVISION 2:[CR]* Build date: 940323[CR]* USA release[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Street Fighter (1987)[CR]2. Street Fighter II - The World Warrior [B-Board 90629B] (1991)[CR]3. Street Fighter II' - Champion Edition [B-Board 91634B-2] (1992)[CR]4. Street Fighter II' - Hyper Fighting [B-Board 91635B-2] (1992)[CR]5. Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [Green Board] (1993)[CR]6. Super Street Fighter II Turbo [Blue Board] (1994)[CR]7. Street Fighter Alpha - Warriors' Dreams [Blue Board] (1995)[CR]8. Street Fighter Alpha 2 [Blue Board] (1996)[CR]9. Street Fighter III - New Generation (1997)[CR]10. Street Fighter III - 2nd Impact : Giant Attack (1997)[CR]11. Street Fighter Alpha 3 [Blue Board] (1998)[CR]12. Street Fighter III - 3rd Strike : Fight For The Future (1999)[CR]13. Hyper Street Fighter II - The Anniversary Edition [Green Board] (2003)[CR]14. Street Fighter IV (2008)[CR]15. Super Street Fighter IV - Arcade Edition (2010)[CR]16. Ultra Street Fighter IV (2014)[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]Here is a list of ports released in regions where the arcade version was released as a Blue Board.[CR]* Consoles : [CR]Panasonic 3DO [US] (1994) "Super Street Fighter II Turbo [Model FZ-SM3851]" [CR]Panasonic 3DO [EU] (1994) "Super Street Fighter II Turbo [Model FZ-SE3851]" [CR]Commodore Amiga CD32 [EU] (1996) [CR]Sega Saturn [EU] (1997) "Street Fighter Collection [Model T-7033H-50] [Disc 1]" [CR]Sega Saturn [US] (November 30, 1997) "Street Fighter Collection [Model T-1222H] [Disc 1]" [CR]Sony PlayStation [US] (November 30, 1997) "Street Fighter Collection [Model SLUS-00423]" [CR]Sony PlayStation [EU] (July 1998) "Street Fighter Collection [Model SLES-00998]" [CR]Microsoft XBOX [US] (November 24, 2006) "Capcom Classics Collection Vol. 2" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [US] (November 24, 2006) "Capcom Classics Collection Vol. 2 [Model SLUS-21473]" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [AU] (April 11, 2007) "Capcom Classics Collection Vol. 2 [Model SLES-54561]" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [EU] (April 13, 2007) "Capcom Classics Collection Vol. 2 [Model SLES-54561]" [CR]Microsoft XBOX 360 [XBLA] [US] [EU] (November 26, 2008) "Super Street Fighter II Turbo HD Remix" [CR]Sony PlayStation 3 [PSN] [US] (November 25, 2008) "Super Street Fighter II Turbo HD Remix" [CR]Sony PlayStation 3 [PSN] [EU] (February 19, 2009) "Super Street Fighter II Turbo HD Remix" [CR]* Handhelds : [CR]Nintendo Game Boy Advance [US] (October 30, 2001) "Super Street Fighter II Turbo Revival [Model AGB-AG5E-USA]" [CR]Nintendo Game Boy Advance [EU] (November 2, 2001) "Super Street Fighter II Turbo Revival [Model NTR-AXRP]" [CR]* Computers : [CR]Commodore Amiga [US] (1995) [CR]Commodore Amiga [EU] (1996) [CR]PC [MS-DOS, CD-ROM] [US] (May 1995) by GameTek[CR]

game.name: Super Street Fighter II: The Tournament Battle (World 931119)
game.description: Super Street Fighter II: The Tournament Battle (World 931119)
game.title_clean: Super Street Fighter II: The Tournament Battle
game.plot: Super Street Fighter II - The Tournament Battle (c) 1993 Capcom.[CR]An exclusive 8-player single-elimination tournament mode of "Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers", only available when four SSFII cabinets are connected together and all of them configured to "Tournament" mode. This special mode consists of four simultaneous matches: the initial eliminations, the simifinals, and the finals.[CR]After the first set of matches is over, players are re-arranged accordingly based on their position: winners are sent to either of the two cabinets on the left and losers are sent to either of the two cabinets on the right. In the finals, the players competing for first place are sent to the first (leftmost) cabinet, the third-place players to the second cabinet, etc.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Capcom Play System II hardware (CPS II) [CR]Main CPU : Motorola 68000 (@ 11.8 Mhz), Zilog Z80 (@ 8 Mhz) [CR]Sound Chips : Q-Sound (@ 4 Mhz) [CR]Players : 2 [CR]Control : 8-way joystick [CR]Buttons : 6 [CR]= > [1] LP (Jab), [2] MP (Strong), [3] HP (Fierce) [CR]= > [4] LK (Short), [5] MK (Forward), [6] HK (Roundhouse)[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]SSFII The Tournament Battle was released in September 1993.[CR]If you have ever wondered why the characters in "Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers" have a ridiculous eight costume colors, then now you will know. This special version is quite rare but allows eight players to fight in a tournament. The reason for the eight costume colors is so all eight players can choose the same character and not get confused about which one they are.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Here is the list of all revisions : [CR]930911 [CR]* Blue board (World)[CR]* Green board (Japan) [CR]911005[CR]* Orange board (South America)[CR]931119 [CR]* Blue board (World)[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Super Secret Colors : Hold down the button you use to select your character for three seconds or so and you can get what is called the 'super' secret color (Note: You can't use the 1P or 2P start buttons to get the secret color).[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]This special "Tournament Battle" is available as the 'Tournament' game mode (selectable item on the Main Menu screen) only on the Nintendo Super NES/Super Famicom and Sega Genesis/Mega Drive ports of "Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers". [CR]For information on release dates and regions where available, please see the "Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers" entry, "Ports" section.[CR]

game.name: Super Street Fighter II: The Tournament Battle (World 931119 Phoenix Edition) (bootleg)
game.description: Super Street Fighter II: The Tournament Battle (World 931119 Phoenix Edition) (bootleg)
game.title_clean: Super Street Fighter II: The Tournament Battle
game.plot: Super Street Fighter II - The Tournament Battle (c) 1993 Capcom.[CR]An exclusive 8-player single-elimination tournament mode of "Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers", only available when four SSFII cabinets are connected together and all of them configured to "Tournament" mode. This special mode consists of four simultaneous matches: the initial eliminations, the simifinals, and the finals.[CR]After the first set of matches is over, players are re-arranged accordingly based on their position: winners are sent to either of the two cabinets on the left and losers are sent to either of the two cabinets on the right. In the finals, the players competing for first place are sent to the first (leftmost) cabinet, the third-place players to the second cabinet, etc.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Capcom Play System II hardware (CPS II) [CR]Main CPU : Motorola 68000 (@ 11.8 Mhz), Zilog Z80 (@ 8 Mhz) [CR]Sound Chips : Q-Sound (@ 4 Mhz) [CR]Players : 2 [CR]Control : 8-way joystick [CR]Buttons : 6 [CR]= > [1] LP (Jab), [2] MP (Strong), [3] HP (Fierce) [CR]= > [4] LK (Short), [5] MK (Forward), [6] HK (Roundhouse)[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]SSFII The Tournament Battle was released in September 1993.[CR]If you have ever wondered why the characters in "Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers" have a ridiculous eight costume colors, then now you will know. This special version is quite rare but allows eight players to fight in a tournament. The reason for the eight costume colors is so all eight players can choose the same character and not get confused about which one they are.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Here is the list of all revisions : [CR]930911 [CR]* Blue board (World)[CR]* Green board (Japan) [CR]911005[CR]* Orange board (South America)[CR]931119 [CR]* Blue board (World)[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Super Secret Colors : Hold down the button you use to select your character for three seconds or so and you can get what is called the 'super' secret color (Note: You can't use the 1P or 2P start buttons to get the secret color).[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]This special "Tournament Battle" is available as the 'Tournament' game mode (selectable item on the Main Menu screen) only on the Nintendo Super NES/Super Famicom and Sega Genesis/Mega Drive ports of "Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers". [CR]For information on release dates and regions where available, please see the "Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers" entry, "Ports" section.[CR]

For more information about the game itself, please see the original Japanese release entry; "Super Street Fighter II X - Grand Master Challenge [Green Board]".[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Blue Board [USA & World][CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Super Street Fighter II Turbo was released in February 1994 outside Japan. It is known in Japan as "Super Street Fighter II X - Grand Master Challege".[CR]In these Export versions, Gouki is named Akuma and all of Akuma's dialogue was removed instead of being translated. If Akuma wins a battle in SSF2 Turbo, he has no victory quotes.[CR]Akuma's ending was all completely removed from the Export versions, with only a credit roll if you beat the game with him, along with pictures of his defeated opponents.[CR]Some characters' endings are translated inaccurately.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Blue Board revisions : [CR]REVISION 1:[CR]* Build date: 940223[CR]* WORLD and USA releases[CR]REVISION 2:[CR]* Build date: 940323[CR]* USA release[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. For more information about the game itself, please see the original Japanese version entry; "Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [Green Board]".[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Blue Board [USA & Etc.][CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]In M. Bison's ending in the Export versions, Bison says 'Not even the 'Ancient One' dared to challenge me!'. In the original Japanese version, where he's known as Vega, he doesn't say anything like this.[CR]Localizations liberties were taken with Cammy's and Fei-Long's endings in the Export versions of SSFII, changing their whole context.[CR]Some of the voice samples of Cammy and Dee Jay were changed from the original version:[CR](Japanese version quote - Export version quote.)[CR]* Cammy : 'Spiral Arrow' - 'Cannon Drill'[CR]* Cammy : 'Cannon Spike' - 'Thrust Kick'[CR]* Dee Jay : 'Slash' - 'Max Out'[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Blue Board revisions : [CR]REVISION 1:[CR]* Build date: 930911[CR]* WORLD and USA releases[CR]REVISION 2:[CR]* Build date: 931005[CR]* WORLD release[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]Here is a list of ports released in regions where the arcade version was released as a Blue Board : [CR]* Consoles : [CR]Nintendo SNES [EU] (September 1994) "Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [Model SNSP-XW-EUR]" [CR]Nintendo SNES [US] (June 1994) "Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [Model SNS-XW-USA]" [CR]Sega Genesis [US] (1994) "Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [Model T-12056]" [CR]Sega Mega Drive [EU] (June 1994) Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [Model 670-5448-50]" [CR]Sega Saturn [EU] (1997) "Street Fighter Collection [Model T-7033H-50] [Disc 1]" [CR]Sega Saturn [US] (November 30, 1997) "Street Fighter Collection [Model T-1222H] [Disc 1]" [CR]Sony PlayStation [US] (November 30, 1997) "Street Fighter Collection [Model SLUS-00423]" [CR]Sony PlayStation [EU] (July 1998) "Street Fighter Collection [Model SLES-00998]" [CR]* Computers : [CR]Commodore Amiga [EU] (1995) [CR]PC [MS-DOS, CD-ROM] [US] [EU] (1996)[CR]

game.name: Super Street Fighter II X: Grand Master Challenge (Japan 940311)
game.description: Super Street Fighter II X: Grand Master Challenge (Japan 940311)
game.title_clean: Super Street Fighter II X: Grand Master Challenge
game.plot: Super Street Fighter II X - Grand Master Challenge (c) 1994 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]Here is a list of changes from "Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers" : [CR]* Modified title screen with new music. [CR]* The 'Character Select' screen's background music is changed. The new song is based on the title screen theme of the CPS1 SFII games. [CR]* After each character's ending, a new piece of artwork is displayed for that character. In Ryu's new art, the kanji 'Fuurinkazan' are written on his belt. These are the same kanji that are displayed on the breakable signs in Ryu's stage in "Street Fighter II - The World Warrior" and "Hyper Street Fighter II - The Anniversary Edition". [CR]* New artwork in Dhalsim's ending. The picture of Dhalsim and his son is replaced with a new picture of Dhalsim with his wife and son. The photograph on the wall now shows Dhalsim with Sagat and Vega (It used to show two generic guys). [CR]* All bonus games have been removed.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 2. [CR]Control: 8-way joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 6 per player.[CR]= > [1] LP (Jab), [2] MP (Strong), [3] HP (Fierce) [CR]= > [4] LK (Short), [5] MK (Forward), [6] HK (Roundhouse)[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Super Street Fighter II X - Grand Master Challenge was released in February 1994 in the Japanese arcade. It was known as the 'third bis' video game released for the CPS2 hardware.[CR]The game is known outside Japan as "Super Street Fighter II Turbo". Here are some known Export releases:[CR]"Super Street Fighter II Turbo [Blue Board]"[CR]"Super Street Fighter II Turbo [Grey Board]"[CR]"Super Street Fighter II Turbo [Orange Board]"[CR]Also a special 'Rent' version known as "Super Street Fighter II X - Grand Master Challenge [Yellow Board]" has been found.[CR]Originally all of the additional features that were added in this game (Gouki, Supers, etc.) were planned for the original SSFII, but were left out due to time restraints. [CR]Origins of Gouki ('Akuma' outside Japan) : The name 'Sheng Long' comes from the Japanese 'shouryuu', meaning 'rising dragon'. The kanji used in 'shouryuu' was pronounced as if it was Cantonese. One of Ryu's win quotes in the English version of "Street Fighter II" said, 'You must defeat Sheng Long to stand a chance'. At the time, fans of Street Fighter II thought that Sheng Long had referred to a person - the supposed master of Ryu and Ken, and not one of Ryu's moves (the Shouryuu Ken). [CR]The creation of Gouki comes from an April Fool's joke in Electronic Gaming Monthly magazine where the editors claimed that you could fight Sheng Long in the game by not touching Vega ('M. Bison' outside Japan), the final boss of "Street Fighter II". Sheng Long would then come out of nowhere and kill Vega, and you would fight him. Sheng Long was supposed to have the moves of Ryu and Ken, but did much more damage and was also faster. To make this joke more believable, fake screenshots were made. Soon after, many fans, believing that the joke was true, flocked to "Street Fighter II" machines, hoping that they could fight a non-existent character. When asked about whether the joke was true, Capcom did not confirm nor deny it as the sudden infusion of money into their machines was driving up business; Capcom USA was taken in by the gag, and actually contact Capcom Japan and asked if the Sheng Long thing was legit. Only much later was this joke was revealed as such, by Electronic Gaming Monthly themselves. Ironically, in "Super Street Fighter II Turbo", parts of this story became true. Like the joke, Akuma would appear from out of nowhere and kill Bison, and you would fight him, and similarly, Akuma had the moves of Ryu and Ken, and was much faster and dealt much more damage. As many people were accustomed to Sheng Long, many people called Akuma erroneously by the name Akuma Long. The move that was used to kill Bison (the Shun Goku Satsu) was also erroneously called the Bison Killer. [CR]Shin-Gouki, Shin-Gouki and Shin-Gouki : Depending on the kanji that's used for 'Shin', Gouki is of one of several personalities. As regular Gouki (considered to be an evil character by Capcom of America, but just an antihero by Capcom of Japan), he does not condone unnecessary roughness (he helps out those in need and only fights when either under self-defense or when challenged to a match - and any match is a deathmatch in his book). Shin-Gouki found in "Street Fighter Zero 2" is just regular Gouki not pulling his punches (it's the unnecessary roughness thing). Another note: Gouki lives and trains on the island of Gokuentou, reported to have been destroyed in "Street Fighter Zero 2" (but Ryu was the only witness). Or, if you believe the non-canonical Pocket Fighter, turned into a tourist trap :-p [CR]All of Gouki's voice samples are actually recycled voice samples from the other male characters.[CR]In this Japanese version only, Gouki had two text endings, which translate as follows... [CR]1) -If the last fight was against Vega- [CR]Gouki : Evil Emperor, you say... nothing more than words. Real victory can only come from a fist. That is all. [CR]There was no one to stop Gouki from that moment onwards. [CR]2) -If the last fight was against Gouki- [CR]Gouki : Something within... what's this ? [CR]?? : I am the shadow of the condemned. You have killed the demon of this curse, and so you shall be condemned no more! [CR]Gouki : I now reside in darkness. Even death is beneath me... excellent! [CR]....That man returned to the darkness and disappeared. [CR]The character select music is a remixed version of the music found in the attract mode intro of the CPS1 SFII games. This is the first SFII game not to use some variation of the character select music from the CPS1 games.[CR]Sony Records released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Super Street Fighter II Arcade Game Track - SRCL-2822) on January 21, 1994.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Play as Old-version Characters : Select your character with LP, then enter the code below while the plane flies to the top of the screen then press LP again. If done correctly you should hear a sound and your character's costume colors in their portrait should change. Old-version characters have no super combos and cannot reduce throw damage... [CR]Old Chun Li : Down(x3), Up [CR]Old Dee Jay : Down(x2), Up(x2) [CR]Old Bison : Down, Up(x2), Down [CR]Old Dhalsim : Down, Up(x3) [CR]Old Ken : Left(x3), Right [CR]Old Fei Long : Left(x2), Right(x2) [CR]Old Vega : Left, Right(x2), Left [CR]Old T. Hawk : Right(x2), Left(x2) [CR]Old Ryu : Right(x3), Left [CR]Old Guile : Up, Down(x3) [CR]Old Sagat : Up, Down(x2), Up [CR]Old Cammy : Up(x2), Down(x2) [CR]Old Honda : Up(x3), Down [CR]* Play as Gouki : At the character select screen, highlight Ryu and hold for 3 sec., highlight T. Hawk and hold for 3 sec., highlight Guile and hold for 3 sec., highlight Cammy and hold for 3 sec., highlight Ryu and hold for 3 sec., press all 3 punches and Start at the same time at the end of you counting. [CR]* Gouki as Final Boss : If you reach the final stage on a single credit (no continues), you will fight Gouki instead of Vega. [CR]* Each character has 8 outfit colors. Press LP to choose the new Super Turbo color, MP for the Champion Edition color, HP for the Hyper Fighting color, any Kick button or the Start button for one of four Super colors, or hold any attack button (except the Start button) for 3 seconds for the secret color. If you use the old version of a character, you will see that character's original "Street Fighter II" color. [CR]* End Credits : If you beat the entire game without continuing, you will get to see the ending credits. If you don't lose a single round, the new ending artwork for each character is shown during the credits. Otherwise, you will see demos of the different characters fighting each other on various stages during the credits.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Street Fighter (1987)[CR]2. Street Fighter II - The World Warrior [CP-S No. 14] (1991)[CR]3. Street Fighter II' - Champion Edition [CP-S No. 21] (1992)[CR]4. Street Fighter II' Turbo - Hyper Fighting [CP-S No. 24] (1992)[CR]5. Super Street Fighter II - The New Challengers [CP-S II No. 01] (1993)[CR]6. Super Street Fighter II X - Grand Master Challenge [CP-S II No. 03 Bis] (1994)[CR]7. Street Fighter Zero [CP-S II No. 11] (1995)[CR]8. Street Fighter Zero 2 [CP-S II No. 15] (1996)[CR]9. Street Fighter Zero 2 Alpha (1996)[CR]10. Street Fighter III - New Generation (1997)[CR]11. Street Fighter III - 2nd Impact : Giant Attack (1997)[CR]12. Street Fighter Zero 3 [CP-S II No. 29] (1998)[CR]13. Street Fighter III - 3rd Strike : Fight For The Future (1999)[CR]14. Hyper Street Fighter II - The Anniversary Edition [CP-S II No. 38] (2003)[CR]15. Street Fighter IV (2008)[CR]16. Super Street Fighter IV (2010)[CR]17. Ultra Street Fighter IV (2014)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Planners : Noritaka Funamizu (Poo), Haruo Murata (Mucchi), Hassy, Kimo Kimo [CR]Character designers : Akira Yasuda (Akiman), Kurisan, Hayashi, Tanuki, Erichan, Ikusan Z, Q, Yu-Suke, Youjiro, Inukichi, Fukumoyan, Buppo, Angus, SM, S. Kuwajima, Kisabon, Hiroki Ohnishi, Takky, Matsuchan, May, Kazu, Iwai, N-Gawa, RK., Shochan [CR]Programmers : Shin., Min, Kid, Mitsu, Garamon, Domesan, Ouchi, Chabin, Kimoto, Inaba [CR]Music : Syun Nishigaki (Syun), Isao Abe (Oyaji) [CR]Sound : Nobuhiro Oouchi (Nobu. Oouchi), Toshio Kajino[CR]Special Thanks : CBX, EGW, Sado, Tetsuya Iijima (Iijima), M. Michi, E-Bou[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]Here is a list of ports released in Japan (where the arcade version was released as a Green Board).[CR]* Consoles : [CR]Panasonic 3DO [JP] (November 13, 1994) "Super Street Fighter II X - Grand Master Challenge [Model FZ-SJ3851]" [CR]Sega Saturn [JP] (September 18, 1997) "Street Fighter Collection [Model T-1223G] [Disc 1]" [CR]Sony PlayStation [JP] (October 23, 1997) "Street Fighter Collection [Model SLPS-00800]" [CR]Sega Dreamcast [JP] (December 22, 2000) "Super Street Fighter II X for Matching Service [Model T-1236M]" [CR]* Handhelds : [CR]Nintendo Game Boy Advance [JP] (July 13, 2001) "Super Street Fighter II X - Revival [Model AGB-AXRJ-JPN]"[CR]

game.name: Ultimate Ecology (Japan 931203)
game.plot: Ultimate Ecology (c) 1993 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]Ultimate Ecology is a side-scrolling shoot-em-up with an ecological theme, in which the player must battle a ruthless mega corporation that is slowly destroying the Earth's eco systems with its industrial machines. [CR]As well as superbly rendered graphics, Eco Fighters features an interesting play mechanic with the addition of an extended metal arm mounted on the side of the player's ship. On the end of the arm is a weapon that can be rotated through 360 degrees. This weapon comes in four different forms; Energy Ball, Long-range Hammer, Laser Sword or Scatter-Bomb foil. The rotatable weapon can be powered up before being fired, in a similar fashion to the 'Force' weapon that featured in Irem's "R*Type". The rotatable weapon is also impervious to all enemy contact and can be used as a shield. [CR]In addition to the rotating weapon, the player's ship is also equipped with forward-firing laser guns. Both the guns and rotatable weapon can be powered-up with greater shot power when the relevant icon is picked up.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 2.[CR]Control: 8-way joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 3 per player.[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Ultimate Ecology was originally released in December 1993 in Japan. It was known as the third video game released on the CPS-II hardware.[CR]The game was actually designed by a Japanese gamer, who won a Capcom-sponsored competition to design a game for the arcade giant.[CR]The game is known outside Japan as "Eco Fighters". Here is a list of known export releases:[CR]"Eco Fighters [Blue Board]"[CR]"Eco Fighters [Grey Board]"[CR]"Eco Fighters [Orange Board]"[CR]Shinseisha/Gamest released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Ultimate Ecology - GCD-2) on January 22, 1994.[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Object Designers: S.Y, Imomushi, Chama(c), The Pin K, Dway Nishimura (Dway!), Ovava, Minobe Hiroaki (Minobeyan), Kakunaka[CR]Scroll Designers: Go, Y.N, May, Ziggy, Oyami, Hiropon[CR]Programmers: Yuuka, A. Komorini, Tilde Kaw, Commander Guchi, Some-P[CR]Sound Designers: Toshio Kajino, Hiroaki Kondo[CR]Music Composer: Syun Nishigaki (Syun)[CR]Voices: Nishihara K-ta, Nemoto Yoshiya, Yokoyama Chisa[CR]Planners: Meshi, Konou, Etos[CR]Special Thanks To: Sho, Sensei, Nezumi, Buppo, Shin, Aoi Mix, Tarabar Hori (Tarabar), Y. Ida, Takuya Shiraiwa (Mr. Shiraiwa), Gamest[CR]Producer: Yoshiki Okamoto (Kihaji Okamoto)[CR]Original Planner: Mori Keisuke[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Handhelds : [CR]Sony PSP [JP] (September 7, 2006) "Capcom Classic Collection [Model ULJM-05104]"[CR]

game.name: Vampire: The Night Warriors (Japan 940705)
game.plot: Vampire - The Night Warriors (c) 1994 Capcom Co, Limited.[CR]A one-on-one fighting game featuring ten horror-themed characters, such as werewolves, mummies, vampires, etc. duking it out "Street Fighter" style. After defeating nine standard opponents, two end bosses must be beaten before the game is completed.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-way joystick[CR]Buttons : 6[CR]=> [1] LP (Jab), [2] MP (Short), [3] HP (Firece) [CR]=> [4] LK (Strong), [5] MK (Forward), [6] HK (Roundhouse)[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Vampire - The Night Warriors was released in June 1994 in Japan. It was known as the 5th CPS-II game.[CR]The game is known outside Japan as "Darkstalkers - The Night Warriors". Here are some known export releases:[CR]"Darkstalkers - The Night Warriors [Blue Board]"[CR]"Darkstalkers - The Night Warriors [Grey Board]"[CR]"Darkstalkers - The Night Warriors [Orange Board]"[CR]Suleputer released a limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Vampire - The Night Warriors Arcade Game Track - SRCL-2969) on September 7, 1994.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Green Board revisions : [CR]REVISION 1[CR]* Build date: 940630[CR]REVISION 2[CR]* Build date: 940705[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Character Select In Attract Mode : In attract mode, when the computer is on the Character Select screen, it's possible to choose the characters with the 1p & 2p Start buttons.[CR]* Alternate Costume Color : Highlight a fighter at the character selection screen and press Start.[CR]* Hidden Tune : Beat the game with one credit, after inputting your name hold Down+LK+MK until the end credits appear. If done correctly, you'll be listening to the secret ending tune.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Vampire - The Night Warriors [Green Board] (1994, Arcade)[CR]2. Vampire Hunter - Darkstalkers' Revenge [Green Board] (1995, Arcade)[CR]3. Vampire Savior - The Lord of Vampire [Green Board] (1997, Arcade)[CR]4. Vampire Savior 2 - The Lord of Vampire [Green Board] (1997, Arcade)[CR]5. Vampire Hunter 2 - Darkstalkers' Revenge [Green Board] (1997, Arcade)[CR]6. Darkstalkers 3 - Vampire Savior (1999, PlayStation)[CR]7. Darkstalkers Chronicles - The Chaos Tower (2005, PSP)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]Planners : Junichi Ohno, Gyo, Jun Koike[CR]Programmers : Atsushi Ohuchi, Akiyoshi Eshiro, Toshihiko Tsuji, Morimichi Suzuki, Hiroshi Inaba[CR]Object Designers : Kurisan, Hiroshi Shibata, Keiko Kitayama, Mizuho Kageyama, Takashi Hayashi, Q, Toshikazu Matsumoto, Kimo Kimo, Who, Tohru Takaoko, Mizupyon[CR]Scroll Designers : Yuki Kyotani, Kaori Matsumoto, Hiroyuki Imahori, Akemi Isoe, Tamayo Takeo, Miyuki Hongoh, Saru[CR]Sound Designers : Toshio Kajino (1970.2.25), Tomuyuki Kawakami (T.K NY) (1971.8.31)[CR]Music Composers : Takayuki Iwai (Anarchy Takapon) (1969.11.19), Hideki Okugawa (Hideki.OK) (1970.3.28)[CR]* Voice Actors : [CR]Demitri : Nobuyuki Hiyama[CR]Gallon, Zabel Zarock, Aulbath : Yuji Ueda[CR]Morrigan : Yayoi Jinguji[CR]Felicia : Kae Araki[CR]Sasquatch, Bishamon, Anakaris, Victor, Narration : Kan Tokumaru[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]Here is a list of ports released in Japan only.[CR]* Consoles :[CR]Sony PlayStation [JP] (March 22, 1996) Vampire - The Night Warriors [Model SLPS-00036]" [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [JP] (May 19, 2005) "Vampire - Darkstalkers Collection [Model SLPM-65998]"[CR]

game.name: Vampire Hunter 2: Darkstalkers Revenge (Japan 970929)
game.plot: Vampire Hunter 2 - Darkstalkers' Revenge (c) 1997 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]Fourteen well-animated creatures from Hell rip, tear and otherwise fight for control of the nether-realms.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 2.[CR]Control: 8-way joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 6 per player.[CR]= > [1] LP, [2] MP, [3] HP[CR]= > [4] LK, [5] MK, [6] HK[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Vampire Hunter 2 was released in September 1997 only in Japan. It was known there as the 27th video game released for the CPS2 hardware.[CR]This game is not a actual sequel, but rather a redesigned version, using the newest Darkstalkers engine. It even includes a reworked version of "Vampire Savior 2"'s intro, which removes all references to Jedah, Bulleta, Q-Bee and Lilith.[CR]Capcom cheated with Vampire Hunter 2, since, chronologically, Anita would be in her teens by the time of Vampire Savior, but they removed Donovan from "Vampire Savior"'s storyline, bringing in Bulleta, instead.[CR]Huitzil (Phobos' name outside of Japan) is the diminutive of 'Huitzilopochtli' (which means 'Blue Hummingbird on the Left'). He was the chief god of the great Aztec city Tenochtitlan and became after his death the Aztec god of the Sun and War.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Green Board revisions : [CR]REVISION 1:[CR]* Build date: 970913[CR]REVISION 2:[CR]* Build date: 970929[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Hidden Warriors: The first will appear if you make 3 'DARK FORCE' or 3 'EX FINISH' without losing a round. The second will appear after 6 'EX FINISH' without losing a round.[CR]* Shoul Mode: On the character select screen, go to the [?] box, press Start 5 times, then push any punch or kick button.[CR]* Alternate Shoul Mode: on the character select screen, go to the character whom you would like to use first stage, then press Start 3 times, after that go to the [?] box, press Start 5 times, then push any punch or kick button.[CR]* Marionette Mode: On the character select screen, go to the [?] box, press Start 7 times, then push any punch or kick button.[CR]* Priest Bishamon: On the character select screen, go to Bishamon, hold Start and press any punch or kick button.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Vampire - The Night Warriors [Green Board] (1994, Arcade)[CR]2. Vampire Hunter - Darkstalkers' Revenge [Green Board] (1995, Arcade)[CR]3. Vampire Savior - The Lord of Vampire [Green Board] (1997, Arcade)[CR]4. Vampire Savior 2 - The Lord of Vampire [Green Board] (1997, Arcade)[CR]5. Vampire Hunter 2 - Darkstalkers' Revenge [Green Board] (1997, Arcade)[CR]6. Darkstalkers 3 - Vampire Savior (1999, PlayStation)[CR]7. Darkstalkers Chronicles - The Chaos Tower (2005, PSP)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]* Voice Actors :[CR]Demitri, Donovan, Pyron : Nobuyuki Hiyama[CR]Gallon, Zabel Zarock, Aulbath : Yuuji Ueda[CR]Morrigan : Yayoi Jinguji[CR]Felicia : Kae Araki[CR]Victor, Bishamon, Sasquatch, Anakaris : Kan Tokumaru[CR]Lei Lei : Michiko Neya[CR]Phobos : Jyurouta Kosugi[CR]Cecil : Kyoko Hikami[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles : [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [JP] (May 19, 2005) "Vampire - Darkstalkers Collection [Model SLPM-65998]"[CR]

game.name: Vampire Hunter 2: Darkstalkers Revenge (Japan 970913)
game.plot: Vampire Hunter 2 - Darkstalkers' Revenge (c) 1997 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]Fourteen well-animated creatures from Hell rip, tear and otherwise fight for control of the nether-realms.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 2.[CR]Control: 8-way joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 6 per player.[CR]= > [1] LP, [2] MP, [3] HP[CR]= > [4] LK, [5] MK, [6] HK[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Vampire Hunter 2 was released in September 1997 only in Japan. It was known there as the 27th video game released for the CPS2 hardware.[CR]This game is not a actual sequel, but rather a redesigned version, using the newest Darkstalkers engine. It even includes a reworked version of "Vampire Savior 2"'s intro, which removes all references to Jedah, Bulleta, Q-Bee and Lilith.[CR]Capcom cheated with Vampire Hunter 2, since, chronologically, Anita would be in her teens by the time of Vampire Savior, but they removed Donovan from "Vampire Savior"'s storyline, bringing in Bulleta, instead.[CR]Huitzil (Phobos' name outside of Japan) is the diminutive of 'Huitzilopochtli' (which means 'Blue Hummingbird on the Left'). He was the chief god of the great Aztec city Tenochtitlan and became after his death the Aztec god of the Sun and War.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Green Board revisions : [CR]REVISION 1:[CR]* Build date: 970913[CR]REVISION 2:[CR]* Build date: 970929[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Hidden Warriors: The first will appear if you make 3 'DARK FORCE' or 3 'EX FINISH' without losing a round. The second will appear after 6 'EX FINISH' without losing a round.[CR]* Shoul Mode: On the character select screen, go to the [?] box, press Start 5 times, then push any punch or kick button.[CR]* Alternate Shoul Mode: on the character select screen, go to the character whom you would like to use first stage, then press Start 3 times, after that go to the [?] box, press Start 5 times, then push any punch or kick button.[CR]* Marionette Mode: On the character select screen, go to the [?] box, press Start 7 times, then push any punch or kick button.[CR]* Priest Bishamon: On the character select screen, go to Bishamon, hold Start and press any punch or kick button.[CR][B]Game Series[/B][CR]1. Vampire - The Night Warriors [Green Board] (1994, Arcade)[CR]2. Vampire Hunter - Darkstalkers' Revenge [Green Board] (1995, Arcade)[CR]3. Vampire Savior - The Lord of Vampire [Green Board] (1997, Arcade)[CR]4. Vampire Savior 2 - The Lord of Vampire [Green Board] (1997, Arcade)[CR]5. Vampire Hunter 2 - Darkstalkers' Revenge [Green Board] (1997, Arcade)[CR]6. Darkstalkers 3 - Vampire Savior (1999, PlayStation)[CR]7. Darkstalkers Chronicles - The Chaos Tower (2005, PSP)[CR][B]Staff[/B][CR]* Voice Actors :[CR]Demitri, Donovan, Pyron : Nobuyuki Hiyama[CR]Gallon, Zabel Zarock, Aulbath : Yuuji Ueda[CR]Morrigan : Yayoi Jinguji[CR]Felicia : Kae Araki[CR]Victor, Bishamon, Sasquatch, Anakaris : Kan Tokumaru[CR]Lei Lei : Michiko Neya[CR]Phobos : Jyurouta Kosugi[CR]Cecil : Kyoko Hikami[CR][B]Game Ports[/B][CR]* Consoles : [CR]Sony PlayStation 2 [JP] (May 19, 2005) "Vampire - Darkstalkers Collection [Model SLPM-65998]"[CR]

game.name: Vampire Hunter: Darkstalkers' Revenge (Japan 950316)
game.plot: Vampire Hunter - Darkstalkers' Revenge (c) 1995 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]The second game in the Darkstalkers series includes 14 horrific fighters.[CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players : 2[CR]Control : 8-Way Joystick[CR]Buttons : 6[CR]=> [1] LP (Jab), [2] MP (Short), [3] HP (Fierce)[CR]=> [4] LK (Strong), [5] MK (Forward), [6] HK (Roundhouse)[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Vampire Hunter was released in March 1995 in Japanese arcades. It was known as the 9th video game released on the CPS-II hardware.[CR]The game was known outside Japan as Night Warriors, here is a list of known Export releases:[CR]"Night Warriors - Darkstalkers' Revenge [Blue Board]"[CR]"Night Warriors - Darkstalkers' Revenge [Grey Board]"[CR]"Night Warriors - Darkstalkers' Revenge [Orange Board]"[CR]"Night Warriors - Darkstalkers' Revenge [Pink Board]"[CR]Sony Records released a 2-CD limited-edition soundtrack album for this game (Vampire Hunter: Darkstalker's Revenge - SRCL-3197/8) on May 21, 1995.[CR][B]Updates[/B][CR]Green Board releases:[CR]REVISION 1:[CR]* Build Date: 950302[CR]REVISION 2:[CR]* Build Date: 950307[CR]REVISION 3:[CR]* Build Date: 950316[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Alternate Costume Colors : highlight a fighter at the character selection screen. [CR]1) Press Roundhouse to select the costume color from Darkstalkers. [CR]2) Press Start to select the secondary costume color from Darkstalkers. [CR]3) Press Jab+Forward to select the dark costume version. [CR]* Secret End Tune : beat the game with one credit, after your character's victory pic appears on the screen, hold Up. The secret tune shall then appear as the credits start. [CR]* SPECIAL [CR]Anakaris : [CR]1) (3/4 max) Naraku no Ana : Left, DownLeft, Down, DownRight, Right + 2 Kicks [CR]2) (1/2 max) Pharaon Magic : MK, LP, Down, LK, MP [CR]3) (Anywhere) Pharaon Split : LP, LP, Down, MK, HK [CR]Bishamon : [CR]1) (Close) Oni Kubi Hineri : Right, DownRight, Down, DownLeft, Left + 2 Punches [CR]2) (Anywhere) Kasane Giri : Left, DownLeft, Down, DownRight + 2 Kicks [CR]Demitri : [CR]1) (Far) Demon Blast : Down, Right, DownRight + 2 Kicks [CR]2) (Close) Midnight Pleasure : Down, Right, DownRight + 2 Punches [CR]Donovan : [CR]1) (Anywhere) Change Immortal : MP, LP, Left, LK, MK [CR]2) (Anywhere) Press of Death : Left, DownLeft, Down, DownRight, Right + Kick (LK = close, MK = medium, HK = far) [CR]Felicia : [CR]1) (3/4 max) Dancing Flash : Right, Down, DownRight + 2 Punches [CR]2) (Anywhere) Please Help Me : Left, DownLeft, Down, DownRight, Right + 2 Kicks [CR]Jon Talbain ('Gallon' in Japan) : [CR]1) (Anywhere) Mirage Body : Left, DownLeft, Down, game.description: Vampire Savior 2: The Lord of Vampire (Japan 970913)
game.title_clean: Vampire Savior 2: The Lord of Vampire
game.plot: Vampire Savior 2 - The Lord of Vampire (c) 1997 Capcom Company, Limited.[CR]Fifteen characters fight to end the reign of Jedah, the Vampire Savior and save their own souls![CR][B]Technical[/B][CR]Runs on the "CP System II" hardware.[CR]Green Board [Japan][CR]Players: Up to 2.[CR]Control: 8-way joystick per player.[CR]Buttons: 6 per player.[CR]= > [1] LP, [2] MP, [3] HP[CR]= > [4] LK, [5] MK, [6] HK[CR][B]Trivia[/B][CR]Vampire Savior 2 was released in September 1997 in the Japanese arcades. It was known there as the 26th video game released for the CPS2 hardware.[CR]During the intro, a fast montage of images appears in a snap second. If you slow down the emulation, you'll find that the images are actually sketches of various characters from the game (Notably, "Vampire Hunter 2" had a fast montage too, at the same point in the intro, but with different artwork).[CR]Donovan's appearance in this game is part of a lie by Capcom : In the original draft for Vampire Savior, Donovan would have been turned into a type of demon, while Anita, now in her teens, would be added to the roster, most likely as a 'new' character. However, instead, both characters were cut, and only restored, suddenly ageless, for Vampire Savior 2, without the changes.[CR]This game is not canon due to the above errata, and other chronological faults, like the inclusion of Pyron, who was destroyed in the original tournament.[CR][B]Tips and Tricks[/B][CR]* Hidden Warriors: the first will appear if you make 3 'DARK FORCE' or 3 'EX FINISH' without losing a round. The second will appear after 6 'EX FINISH' without losing a round. [CR]* Shoul Mode: on the character select screen, go to the [?] box, press Start 5 times, then push any punch or kick button. [CR]* Alternate Shoul Mode: on the character select screen, go to the character whom you would like to use in the first stage, press Start 3 times, after that go to the [?] box, press Start 5 times, then push any punch or kick button. [CR]* Marionette Mode: on the character select screen, go to the [?] box, press Start 7 times, then push any punch or kick button. [CR]* Priest Bishamon: on the character select screen, go to Bishamon, hold Start and press any punch or kick button. [CR]* Vampire Hunter 2 Phobos: Hold start and select Phobos. He will have the gameplay of Vampire Hunter 2. [CR]* EX MOVES [CR]Anakaris : [CR]1) (3/4 max) In the Sarcophage : Left, DownLeft, Down, DownRight, Right + 2 Punches [CR]2) (1/2 max) Pharao Magic I : MK, LP, Down, LK, MP [CR]3) [Need 2 powers] (1/2 max) Pharao Magic II : HK, MP, Down, MK, HP [CR]4) [Need 3 powers] (1/2 max) Pharao Magic III : HK, MP, LK, Down, LP, MK, HP [CR]Baby Bonnie Hood ('Bulleta' in Japan) : [CR]1) (Anywhere) Hunt the Duck : Left, DownLeft, Down, DownRight, Right + 2 Punches [CR]2) (Near) Beautiful Memory : Left, DownLeft, Down, DownRight, Right + 2 Kicks [CR]3) (Close) Apple Blast : Right, DownRight, Down, DownLeft, Left + 2 Kicks [CR]Bishamon : [CR]1) (Close) Oni Kubi Hineri : Right, DownRight, Down, DownLeft, Left + 2 Punches [CR]2) (Anywhere) Enma Seki : Left, DownLeft, Down, DownRight + 2 Kicks [CR]Demitri : [CR]1) (3/4 max) Demon Pillion : Down, Right, DownRight + 2 Kicks [CR]2) (Sweep distance) Sucking the Blood : Right, Down, DownRight + 2 Punches [CR]3) [Need 2 powers] (Sweep Distance) Midnight Pleasure : LP, MP, Right, MK, MK [CR]Donovan : [CR]1) (Anywhere) Immortal Transformation : MP, LP, Left, LK, MK [CR]2) (Anywhere) Breath of Death : Left, DownLeft, Down, DownRight, Right + Kick (LK = close, MK = medium, HK = far) [CR]Felicia : [CR]1) (3/4 max) Weapon X - 11 hit : Left, DownLeft, Down, DownRight, Right + 2 Punches [CR]2) (Anywhere) Help Me, Please - 34 hit : Left, DownLeft, Down,
